Zoologist Marion Petrie and her team from the Open University are studying these peacocks to find answers, a century after Darwin's death. Darwin believed that animals evolved through natural selection, meaning the fittest survive and reproduce. However, he also suggested a different idea called 'sexual selection' to explain the peacock's tail. He thought females chose mates based on beauty alone.

Darwin's friend, Alfred Russel Wallace, disagreed. He believed that if peahens chose the most beautiful males, there must be a reason beyond just looks. The tails might signal some hidden quality that helps survival.

Today, the debate continues because studying peafowl behavior is challenging. At Whipsnade, 200 peacocks live in conditions similar to the wild, providing a unique chance to study them. Petrie and her team focus on two main questions: Do peahens really prefer males with the showiest tails? And do these males have other advantages, as Wallace suggested?

Observations show that peahens do prefer males with more eye-spots on their tails, which are linked to tail length. These males attract more mates. However, it's still unclear if these males are better in other ways.

William Hamilton from Oxford University proposed that showy male birds might be healthier and free of parasites, which their plumage might indicate. While this is true for some birds, Petrie's team hasn't been able to test this in Whipsnade peacocks yet. This year, they are comparing the offspring of attractive and less attractive males to see if the former grow faster or are healthier. If so, it would support Wallace's idea that female choice is practical.

There's another theory by R.A. Fisher called 'Fisher's Runaway.' It suggests that if a female chooses a male with a slightly better tail, their offspring will inherit these traits. Over generations, this preference could lead to increasingly extravagant tails, supporting Darwin's idea of 'beauty for beauty's sake.'

**THE BOAT OF MY DREAMS**

Tom Cunliffe believes the best boat design should mix old and new ideas. He did this with his own boat, 'The Westerman'. This week, the Summer Boat Show in London is full of modern yachts with the latest technology. Most of these yachts are based on a design change from 25 years ago. In contrast, my boat is quietly anchored on a tidal creek on the south coast. It was designed last year, but it looks like it could be 100 years old. Some might think I'm a romantic dreamer, and maybe I am, but this boat uses both traditional design and modern technology. 

Modern technology is essential in boat design and building today, but it often separates sailors from the real experiences of being at sea. These are the experiences they wanted to find by sailing. I'm not saying sailors should suffer, but I believe boats should have basic comforts like a coal stove for warmth and comfortable beds. However, if every sail operates automatically, why go sailing? Handling sails is part of a sailor's life. Also, why move the steering from the safe back of the boat to a risky spot in the middle? This change is often made to create more space inside, like a big cabin on a cruise ship. For me, a boat should be a boat, not a floating house.

When I bought my previous boat, Hirta, for a TV race around Britain, the former owner said it had comfort but no luxury. During my time with Hirta, I learned he was right. Her sails were heavy, and she had no running water, little electricity, no fridge, no central heating, no winches, and no electronics, especially for navigation. Yet, she was the easiest and kindest boat I ever sailed. However, classic boats need a lot of care. After a back injury, I realized I had to let her go. I couldn't find a suitable new boat, so I decided to build one from scratch.

The Westerman has never let me down. Designer Nigel Irens and his assistant Ed Burnett are skilled with computer design, but Irens first sketched the boat on a napkin and later used a computer. After creating a design, he carved a model, like in the old days. We reviewed the model and made changes on the computer. The final design was perfect. The finished boat has crossed the North Atlantic and won four out of six races. She looks timeless, sails smoothly, and her interior, made from reclaimed wood, feels peaceful. This is because she was designed as a sailing boat first, without focusing on interior furniture. This traditional method proves that you don't need to follow trends to be satisfied and that history can teach us valuable lessons. Built with wood treated with a special glue, she is completely waterproof. She has all the advantages of a fiberglass boat but looks, feels, and sails like a classic wooden boat.

**RETREAT, RELAX, RECHARGE**

Health farms and country house hotels with spa facilities are doing very well. We asked five journalists to visit some of these places.

**A. HENLOW GRANGE**

I was excited to visit Henlow Grange for six days because I was tired and needed to relax. My room in the large 18th-century house was very comfortable, and I felt calm right away. On the first day, I did nothing and slept a lot. From the second day, I joined body conditioning classes like stretch and tone, yoga, and body alignment. The instructors are very skilled, and I felt more flexible as the week went on. They offer many treatments, including aromatherapy, seaweed baths, manicures, and pedicures. The one-hour facial made me feel like a new person. The staff in the treatment rooms were friendly and professional. The atmosphere is full of energy and enthusiasm. Henlow is planning a big renovation this year, adding a half-size Olympic swimming pool and a Light Diet Room. You can also ride bicycles around the grounds. If you prefer to relax, you can read a magazine or take a peaceful walk in the garden. During my stay, my mood and appetite improved. I left feeling wonderful and full of energy, which lasted a long time. I definitely want to visit again. This is the perfect break for a stressed working woman. Save Room 5 for me! Marcella D'Argy Smith

**B. SHRUBLAND HALL**

The calm and relaxing atmosphere of this stately home was clear from the moment I climbed the large staircase to the reception area. The Hall has a beautifully decorated library, a charming conservatory, and lots of space, so you don't have to talk to anyone if you don't want to. On arrival, everyone gets a medical check, including weight and blood pressure. We were all called patients, which felt strange since I'm healthy. However, I was impressed that a shoulder problem found during the check was immediately shared with the fitness instructor, and we worked on it in group workshops and an extra individual session. Each patient gets a specific diet. I lost weight without fasting, but I was hungry enough to get a headache on the second day. My typical daily menu was grapefruit and honey for breakfast, a choice of salads for lunch, and exotic fruit, yogurt, and hot broth for supper. If you're not fasting or on a light diet, you eat in the main dining hall, where the food is tasty and nicely presented, so you don't suffer too much! You have a massage or water therapy on alternate days. All extra treatments are reasonably priced. Liz Gregory

**C. CAREYS MANOR**

Careys is not a health farm and doesn't claim to be. It's a lovely old manor with inviting log fires and a spacious lounge. If you're counting calories, you'll have to skip the gourmet food. The French chef creates rich sauces and delightful creamy desserts. Luckily, the hotel has a fully-equipped gym and soft-water pool to work off some of the tempting treats. (You can choose a 'health-conscious' diet if you want to lose weight.) There is a spa bath, steam room, Swiss shower, sauna, and treatment rooms. A big attraction is the sports injury clinic. I got expert advice on an old shoulder injury. The physiotherapist recommended good posture, exercises, and massage. Careys is comfortable and luxurious, relaxed and calm. If you want to explore, there is beautiful countryside around. Beverly D'Silva

**D. CLIVEDEN**

Cliveden is a grand country home and a five-star hotel that treats guests like royalty. It offers health and beauty treatments, a well-equipped gym, saunas, swimming pool, tennis, horse riding, and more. There are beautiful woodland walks and gardens on the 376-acre National Trust estate. Waldo's, a highly-acclaimed restaurant, offers dishes that are hard to resist. It took me half an hour to read the dinner menu; the choice was amazing. The meal was wonderful, especially the sticky-toffee pudding with banana ice-cream. I went to bed a happy woman! The next morning, I spent a few hours in the gym to burn off some calories before my next meal. In the Pavilion, I enjoyed a facial with gentle heat and essential oils, followed by an aromatherapy massage. I thought of all the other reports my fellow journalists would make about fitness assessments, workouts, and beauty treatments to tone and firm the body. Cliveden has all these if you want to use them—before enjoying yourself at Waldo's. Kay Letch

**E. SPRINGS HYDRO**

The best and worst thing about Springs Hydro is the carrot cake. The best because it's the most delicious I've ever tasted. The worst because it's a large piece with 360 calories, which is not good if you want to lose weight. You have been warned! The second best thing is the fabulous aromatherapy massage. I chose relaxing oils, fell asleep twice during the massage, and had my most refreshing night's sleep in years. The premises are modern and purpose-built, efficiently run, with up-to-date facilities and luxurious bedrooms. There are plenty of therapists and beauty rooms, so it's easy to schedule appointments. A variety of treatments are available, from manicures and pedicures to deep-cleansing facials and body treatments. The guests are a mix of people—from entire football teams to mums and daughters, best friends, and singles. Ideally, I would have a break here about once a month. Eve Cameron

**NATURAL TALENTS**

In the seven million years since humans split from chimpanzees, we haven't changed much genetically. We are still more than 98% identical to chimps. On an evolutionary scale, what makes humans different from animals is a recent development. Our ability to make art and other uniquely human traits must come from a small part of our genes. This means that the differences between us and animals are mostly small. For example, both humans and animals use tools: chimpanzees use sticks, and sea otters use rocks. Monkeys have simple language with different sounds for 'leopard', 'eagle', and 'snake'. These findings show that there are few absolute differences between us and animals, except for art.

If human art comes from a unique genetic trait, it's interesting that our ancestors didn't create art for most of the time since they split from chimps. Early art forms might have been wood carvings or body painting, but these don't last over time. Clear evidence of human art appears with the Cro-Magnons around 35,000 years ago, with cave paintings, statues, necklaces, and musical instruments.

If we say our recent creativity sets us apart, how is our art different from animal creations? Three main differences are often suggested: human art is non-utilitarian, made for aesthetic pleasure, and learned rather than instinctive.

First, as Oscar Wilde said, "All art is quite useless." This means human art doesn't help us survive or reproduce, unlike most animal behaviors. While human art can communicate thoughts or feelings, it doesn't pass on genes. In contrast, birdsong helps defend territory or attract mates, which does pass on genes. By this measure, human art seems different.

The second claim is that only human art is motivated by aesthetic pleasure. We can't ask birds if they enjoy their songs, but they mostly sing during breeding season, suggesting they sing for reasons other than pleasure. Again, human art seems unique here.

The third distinction is that human art is learned, not instinctive. Each human group has its own art styles that are learned. For example, songs in Tokyo and Paris are different, but people can learn each other's songs. Some birds, however, inherit their songs and would sing them even without hearing them. It's like a French baby raised in Japan singing the French national anthem without learning it.

The role of learning in human art is clear in how quickly styles change. Geese honked 2,000 years ago as they do today, but human art changes rapidly. Even a casual museum-goer can tell a twentieth-century painting from the Mona Lisa. Experts can often identify when and who painted a work. However, they might mistake the works of two mid-twentieth-century artists, Congo and Betsy, who were actually chimpanzees. Congo made up to 33 paintings in one day and got upset when his pencil was taken away. Their paintings were shown in a 1957 exhibition in London, and most were sold, which many human artists can't claim.

These paintings by chimps blur the lines between human art and animal activities. Like human art, the ape paintings had no practical purpose and were made for the painter's satisfaction. You might argue that human art is different because it's meant to communicate, but even some famous human art was created for the artist's personal satisfaction.

**An Exciting Adventure**

The Taklamakan Desert in western China is one of the last unexplored places on earth. It is also one of the most dangerous. Charles Blackmore crossed it and lived to tell the tale. There are very few big adventures left and very few heroes. Children's stories used to be about them—brave explorers with sunburnt skin and eyes narrowed from looking into the distance on their journeys into the unknown. These days, you don't find such people in stories, let alone in real life. Or so I thought until I met Charles Blackmore.

Blackmore's great adventure was leading an expedition across the Taklamakan Desert in western China. Its name means 'once entered you never come out', but local people call it the Desert of Death. He remembered the dangers and excitement of that amazing journey while sitting calmly at home. The team he led included four Britons (one was the medical officer), an American photographer, four Chinese experts on the area, 30 camels, and six camel handlers. It turned out that the camel handlers had never worked with camels before; they were long-distance truck drivers. This misunderstanding could have been very dangerous and put the expedition at risk.

This group set out to cross 1,200 kilometers of the world's least hospitable desert, and Charles Blackmore has written a fascinating account of their journey. At the time, he was about to leave the Army after 14 happy years. He started the expedition for fun, to fill a gap in his life, to prove something. 'I had always thought I'd spend my whole life in the Army. I had been offered a promotion, but suddenly I felt I wanted to see who Charles Blackmore really was, outside all that. It was a big risk. Tina, my wife, was very worried that I wouldn't come back as nobody had ever done that route; we went into it blind. In the end, it took 59 days to cross from west to east, and the desert was very kind to us.'

Anyone reading his extraordinary account of that crossing will wonder at the use of the word 'kind'. The team suffered terrible hardships: dysentery; extreme temperatures; severe thirst and dehydration; the loss of part of their precious water supply. 'But', Blackmore explains, 'when we were at the limits of our endurance and the camels had gone without water for seven days, we managed to find some. We didn't experience the Taklamakan's legendary sandstorms. And we never faced the raw, biting desert cold that would have totally stopped us. That's not to say that we weren't fighting against challenges the whole time. The fine sand got into everything, especially blisters and wounds. The high dunes were torture to climb, for us and for the heavily loaded camels, which often rolled over onto us.

'What drove me on more than anything else was the need to survive. We had no backup plan. Neither our budget nor time allowed one. No aircraft ever flew over us. Once we got into the sandhills, we were completely on our own. 'I knew I had the mental strength for the trip, but I was very scared of my physical ability to do it. I remember day one—we sat at the edge of the desert, and it was so hot that you couldn't breathe. I thought, "We've got to do it now!" At that moment, I was a very scared man.'

If it was like that at the beginning, how did they feel towards the end? 'When you've walked for 1,000 kilometers, you're not going to give up. You've endured so much; you've got so much behind you. We were very thin, but very muscular and strong despite our physical exhaustion. My body was well-toned, and my legs were like pistons. I could walk over anything.'

Midway through the book, Blackmore describes lying in the desert, looking up at a full moon, thinking of his family. How aware was he of the ordeal it must have been for them? 'Inside me, there's someone trying to find peace with himself. When I have doubts about myself now, I go back to the image of the desert and think, well, we managed to pull that together. As a personal achievement, I feel prouder of that expedition than of anything else I've done. Yet in terms of a lifetime's achievement, I think of my family and the happiness we share—against that measure, the desert does not compare.'

Has Charles Blackmore found peace? 'I yearn for the challenge—for the open spaces—the resolve of it all. We were lifted by the sense of purpose. I find it difficult now to be part of the uniformity of modern life.'

Life was becoming overwhelming for Susan Harr, so she decided to unplug her gadgets and enjoy manual work again. Everyone loves technology because it gives us gadgets that make life easier and give us more free time. However, we've been subtly convinced that technology is essential, which might not be true. Using our hands doesn't harm the environment, unlike machines. A recent problem with my word processor, which cost a lot to fix, made me question if gadgets are worth the trouble. Are we as dependent on technology as we think? Gradually, I've been letting go of household gadgets as they break down. This makes me wonder what 'extra time' technology really gives us. Is it just time to buy more gadgets? If so, the marketers have tricked us. When my machine started making strange noises, even when unplugged, I left it in the backyard. Now, I'm not tied to a noisy machine and can take my time sewing by hand. I was always a bit scared of electric machines that move quickly towards your fingers. Plus, I can easily take my sewing with me anywhere. Of course, there are some gadgets I wouldn't want to live without. A year without a washing machine showed me how useful it is. But losing some gadgets has been surprisingly nice. We were watching too much TV, so I returned the rented color TV and went back to a small black-and-white one. It's hard on the eyes but makes us focus on what's worth watching. Now, we spend more time walking the dog, reading, talking, or doing other hobbies. One of my hobbies is sewing, and I stopped using my old sewing machine, which is now a plant stand. I can't afford a new one, so I sew by hand. We've come to believe we can't live without technology, but we don't want to give it up. We feel sorry for past generations who worked hard without machines. Computers now do amazing calculations and entertain us. But sewing by hand is not boring; it's relaxing. I can sew and listen to the radio or talk with family and friends. If it's a simple task, I can watch TV and feel less guilty about sitting in front of it. It's nice to sit by the fire and sew with a cup of tea. I used to think sewing by hand was hard work, but it's actually soothing and satisfying. I find things get done quickly, and life slows down to my own pace. I'm also free from the rush of modern life. I've taken back control of my sink, where I enjoy washing dishes and daydreaming. Now, I look around the house and wonder if we really need the freezer, microwave, or lawnmower. We could save a lot of money by doing without electric lights!

Charles Hurst is a cabinet-maker who earns his living by creating beautifully crafted furniture. When I meet him at his workshop in East London, he seems to be in a hurry. He greets me quickly and says, "Well, fire away then!" It's not clear if he's naturally brusque or just shy. His workshop is busy, filled with half-made furniture and colorful planks of wood. Hurst has been in this business for ten years and has a great reputation. His schedule is always full months in advance, even though he doesn't advertise. People know that if they want quality furniture like cupboards, tables, or bookcases, Hurst is the person to go to.

Finding a furniture-maker isn't hard, but finding one like Hurst, who focuses on clean, simple designs, is rare. "There are few real cabinet-makers now," Hurst says. He is disappointed by some modern furniture and criticizes mass-produced, low-quality pieces. His quest for perfection and his talent are keys to his success. Hurst is confident in his skills, saying, "I have a huge natural ability." He is self-taught and learned by asking the right questions.

Most of his work comes from private clients, and some return for more. "You end up doing the whole of their house. That is very satisfying," he says. However, he admits that not all client relationships are smooth. He prefers clients who know exactly what they want.

Hurst is also willing to praise others when deserved. He acknowledges that some people are better than him and admires their work. However, he criticizes craftsmen who take too long to make a single piece and students who try to make fashion statements with their furniture. For Hurst, furniture should be practical and usable.

Despite his confidence, Hurst is humble about his work. As I leave, he says, "After all, I am only making furniture."

Text: 'Three theories about sleep People spend about one-third of their lives asleep. It seems clear, therefore, that sleep has an important role. However, what that role might be is still debated. Scientists do not fully agree on why we spend so much time sleeping. There are three main theories. The most popular theory says that the main reasons for sleep are related to our body. It suggests that we sleep to keep our body healthy. In other words, while we sleep, biological processes work to fix any damage done during the day and to restore our full efficiency. However, a second theory focuses more on the learning benefits of sleep. This theory suggests that sleep helps us process the information we learn during the day, and claims that, without sleep, learning would not happen. A third popular theory is about energy, saying that we need sleep to recharge our energy, so we have enough for the next day.'

**ECCENTRICS**

An eccentric is someone whose behavior is unusual and who does not follow the accepted norms of society. This raises the question, "What is normal?" Most of us have our own quirks and oddities. It could be a passion for entering newspaper competitions, collecting beer mats, or writing letters to the press about various topics. Eccentricity is about expressing our individuality. Inside us, there is a constant conflict between wanting to be unique and wanting to fit in. It's like having two trains on the same track, one called individualism and the other conformity. For most people, conformity is stronger. We want to be accepted, loved, and feel connected with others more than we want to stand out.

People with unusual hobbies or behaviors often gather together. They form clubs and hold meetings to share their interests, which others might see as odd. Being part of a group, even a small one, is comforting. We all feel a tension between individualism and conformity. While we often follow the crowd, we don't like to admit it. We want to show our individuality, like when someone at a bar says, "I say what I think," or when a new acquaintance says, "You must take me as you find me."

At any time, we can choose to express our individuality. Many successful people have done this. For example, Bob Dylan, the American singer, said, "When you feel in your gut what you are doing and then pursue it without backing down, you'll mystify people." However, this self-conscious assertion of individuality is not eccentricity, at least not at first. When a pop singer wears strange clothes for publicity or a society hostess makes shocking comments to get noticed, that is not eccentricity. But if they continue these actions until they become a natural part of who they are, then they might be considered eccentric.

The key to eccentricity is its naturalness. Eccentrics do not try to be odd; they simply are. They are not concerned with public opinion and are barely aware of it. This makes them different from enthusiasts, practical jokers, criminals, exhibitionists, and recluses, who are all very aware of society. Eccentrics go their own way, regardless of what others think.

**Natural Books**

We asked four well-known naturalists to share the wildlife book that has influenced them the most.

**A Geoffrey Lean**

Choosing the author was easy for me. As an environmental journalist, I've been lucky to meet some of the great thinkers in this field. Among them, Barbara Ward stands out. She was deeply involved in environmental issues in post-war Europe and developed her own powerful philosophy from her experiences. As a young journalist, she helped me understand the field better than anyone else. Choosing the book was harder. It could have been "Only One Earth" or "Progress for a Small Planet." But for me, "The Home of Man" is her most important work. It focuses on the rapid growth of cities and the major themes she dedicated her life to. It's a passionate call for what we now call 'sustainable human development.' I've read many books since, but none have matched it.

**B Linda Bennett**

When I read "Signals for Survival" by Niko Tinbergen, I can almost hear the calls of herring gulls and remember the smell of the colony. This book wonderfully explains animal communication through words and pictures. After reading it, watching a gull colony changes from chaos to a well-organized social structure. You can see which birds are partners and recognize families later in the season. Niko Tinbergen was a respected behaviorist who wanted to share his findings with everyone. His work with wildlife artist Eric Ennion in this book was inspiring. Ennion's art, based on years of observing birds, shows how one gull is aggressive and another is peaceful with just a few lines and colors. This is the work of a true field naturalist.

**C Lee Durrell**

"My Family and Other Animals" by Gerald Durrell is the book that has most influenced my life. It led me to a wonderful husband and a career in conservation. This book confirmed my love for the natural world. I first read it while researching animal sounds in Madagascar. I was facing many challenges, but reading this book made everything seem brighter. It beautifully combines animals, people, joy, and beauty, showing a world worth saving. Some say humans are the worst species because of the harm we've done. But I remember Gerald as a boy in the book, seeing the world as a family, with all its good and bad parts connected. This is a concept we all need to understand.

**D Bruce Pearson**

I found "The Shell Bird Book" by James Fisher in my school library soon after it was published in 1966. I was immediately drawn to the 48 color plates of birds by Eric Ennion. These images captured my attention. I already had other bird books and had spent holidays learning to identify birds, which encouraged me to start sketching them. But "The Shell Bird Book" offered much more. It included chapters on bird migration, the history of birds in Britain, and even birds in music, literature, and art. This wide range of information and the exciting images led me to appreciate birds and nature more broadly. The book showed me that my emotional and creative response to nature was as valid as a scientific one. Since art was a stronger subject for me than math or physics, I saw new opportunities opening up.

**DO REVIEWS SELL BOOKS?**

We asked five top British publishers about how book reviews affect a book's success. Here is what they said:

**Publisher A**  
Reviews are crucial for publishers; they are the first part of the newspaper we look at. The Book Marketing Council found that when people were asked why they bought a book, more mentioned reviews than any other reason (like ads, word of mouth, or bookshop displays). Authors and publishers react differently to reviews. Both dislike getting no reviews, but publishers are usually calmer about bad reviews. They believe that any mention, whether good or bad, can boost sales as readers decide to see for themselves. Publishers enjoy reviews that match their own opinion of a book since they are often the first to read it.

**Publisher B**  
Publishers and the press both care about book review pages, but their needs are different. Newspapers and magazines want to entertain their readers, while publishers want their books reviewed positively. Book reviewing is better now than 40 years ago, being more diverse and less elitist. However, there is still a tendency to overlook paperbacks, which are read by most people. Weekly roundups aren't enough, even if done well. Publishers shouldn't complain too much, though. Like readers and writers, they need reviews, which are a cost-effective way to make a book and author known. A lively review by a trusted name can boost sales, especially if there are several reviews. Fame helps get a book into readers' hands.

**Publisher C**  
Reviews are vital for literary publishing; without them, we would lose an essential source of life. We publish books by authors who are not well-known, so we rely on literary editors to give space to our books. Good reviews are worth more than any advertisement because readers trust that they are not influenced by the publisher's marketing budget. Good reviews can launch a book and a career, but they need to be combined with other factors like word-of-mouth recommendations, support from the book trade, and smart marketing.

**Publisher D**  
The relationship between publishing and reviewing in Britain is unclear. In the US, the New York Times can make or break a book with one review. Here, bookshops often don't seem to pay much attention to reviews. It can take 20 years of great reviews for people to start reading a good writer's work. Yet, some poorly reviewed books or books not reviewed at all are the biggest sellers. It's unpredictable, though non-fiction reviews often focus more on what the reviewer knows about the subject than the book itself.

**Publisher E**  
All publishers and writers dream of long, positive reviews. But do they sell books? I once published a biography that got great reviews, but it didn't sell because people felt they didn't need to buy the book after reading the reviews. Does the reviewer's name matter? Thirty years ago, if certain reviewers praised a book, the public listened. Now, it's more about the choice of an unexpected reviewer or the power, wit, or originality of the review that encourages people to buy the book.

**WEATHERVANE MAKER**

The making of weathervanes is an ancient skill, dating back to early Egyptian times. Today, this craft is still alive in the workshop of Graham Smith. He is one of the few people in the country who make hand-cut weathervanes. Graham's designs are individually created and tailored to his customers' specific needs. "That way I can produce a unique personalized item," he explains. "Many of my customers are women buying presents for their husbands. They want a special gift that represents the man's business or hobbies."

This is very different from the traditional cockerel, the most common weathervane design. Graham's first weathervane was not a cockerel but a witch on a broomstick, which he made as a surprise present for his wife. Friends admired it and began asking him to make weathervanes for them. "I realized that the possibilities for designs were limitless," he says. Graham decided to focus on a weathervane business. He had trained as a precision engineer and worked in that field for 15 years. Then he and his wife, Liz, decided to swap roles—she went to work as an architectural assistant, and he stayed home to look after the children and build the business. That was five years ago, and he has no regrets about his new path. "My previous work didn't have an artistic element, but this is exciting and creative," he says. "I really enjoy the design side."

Graham has now perfected over 100 original designs. He works with very fine detail, always getting approval for the silhouette design from the customer before hand-cutting it. Graham also keeps many traditional designs in stock, as they are as popular as the custom ones. "It seems that people are attracted to hand-crafting," Graham says. "They like the chance to get something a little bit different."

Graham has no plans to expand, as he wants to keep the business as a rural craft. "I have found my place in the market. People love the individuality, and I get a lot of satisfaction from seeing a simple shape turn into something almost lifelike," he says. "For centuries, weathervanes have helped communities stay in touch with the weather by showing changes in wind direction," he explains. "Nowadays, with more people moving to the country, they want to add a unique touch to their homes. This has helped crafts like mine."

Graham has become increasingly busy, supplying flat-packed weathervanes to clients worldwide. American and Danish buyers, in particular, are interested. "Pricing," he explains, "depends on the complexity of the design." His most recent request was for a curly-coated dog. Whatever the occasion, Graham can create a gift with a difference.

**Beginner Takes All**

Before it was even published, *The Horse Whisperer* was the most talked-about book of the year. This first novel by British screenwriter Nicholas Evans earned him record-breaking amounts of money. Here, he shares his inspiration and success story.

The start of the year was tough for Nicholas Evans, who was a screenwriter, producer, and aspiring director. Things went wrong when *Life and Limb*, a film he had been working on for months, suddenly fell apart. He was worried because it had been two years since he last earned any money, and this film was his only hope to keep the bank happy. A sensible person might have found a job, perhaps returning to television work. Instead, Evans made a bold decision. He bought a ticket to America to research his first novel for three months.

The idea for the story had been with him for a while, inspired by a farrier he met on Dartmoor. The farrier told him about a calm horse that suddenly became wild. Its owners were desperate until they found a gypsy who calmed the horse just by talking to it. Such people were called 'horse whisperers'. Evans was fascinated and started researching the topic, initially thinking of writing a screenplay. But after *Life and Limb* failed, he decided to write a book instead.

In the spring, he traveled across the US, visiting ranches and learning about horses and the people who work with them. "It was a strange time," he recalls. "I was observing people, but I felt alone and as if my life was falling apart. I had tried for ten years to succeed as a filmmaker, and now I was in debt, worried about feeding my children, and wondering if it was all a mistake."

By August, he had returned home and written half of the book. The bank was pressuring him, and he needed to know if it was worth continuing. He showed the draft to a friend who was a literary agent. The agent thought it was "fine" and estimated Evans might get $30,000 as an advance. Evans needed more than that to pay off some debt and keep going. He had already spent seven months on the book and needed at least two more. He was also advised to write a 12-page summary of the rest of the book.

In October, the first 200 pages and the summary were sent to seven UK publishers just before the Frankfurt Book Fair. Within days, his agent called to say he had turned down an offer of $75,000. "I said, 'You what?' And he said, 'It's OK, I just sense something is happening.'"

What happened next was remarkable. Within a week, the novel was sold to Transworld Publications in the UK for $550,000 and to Delacorte in the US for $3.15 million, both record-breaking advances for a first novel. "We couldn't believe it; we were shocked. We never sent the manuscript to New York, and we still don't know how it got there," Evans says. It wasn't sent to Hollywood either, but soon major studios were competing for it. "My UK agent wisely involved an agent there, and when he called to say, 'I think we can get $3 million outright,' we laughed in disbelief."

The studios agreed to this amount, and they each made their case to Evans. One night in October, he sat in his study while four top filmmakers called, one after the other, to offer $3 million for an unfinished novel.

Evans shared this story while we drank coffee on the verandah of his home. He mentioned that he had turned down an offer to write the screenplay for *The Horse Whisperer*. "It's been such a fairy tale so far. I don't want to ruin it. Writing at that level is tough, and I don't want to become an employee of people I like and who have paid me so much. I'd hate to write a draft or two and then have them say, 'Thanks, Nick, but now we'll bring in someone else.'"

He planned to stay involved but from a distance. The success of his novel also brought new interest in *Life and Limb*, but he wasn't sure he wanted to make it anymore. "I think it would be wise to write another novel," he said.

Text: 'Young Masters Age is a challenge for Bobby Fischer as he tries to make a comeback. Chess is now more than ever a game for young people. After 20 years away from the game, Bobby Fischer has returned to chess and is playing against his old rival Boris Spassky. Fischer's win in the first game was impressive, simple yet deep. However, as the following games have shown, this older, bearded chess player is not the same as he was in 1972. He is 49 years old, out of practice, and not in the best shape. Spassky is even older. Chess has changed a lot in the last 20 years. A new era of professionalism started because of Fischer's influence on the game. The rise of professional chess has made winning more important than the scientific and artistic aspects of the game. In international chess, a player's nerves and stamina are as important as their intellect and wisdom. The pressure of the game has always been high: a chess clock is used to make sure each player finishes the required number of moves in the given time - failing to do so means losing the game immediately. Now, the playing sessions are longer, and many games are played without breaks. This increased pressure benefits younger players. In the last 30 years, each new world champion has been younger than the one before. It is notable that, of the world's top ten players, eight are under 30. The way the game is played has also changed. Much of modern chess happens off the board - not just the psychological battles that Fischer is known for. Every professional must prepare seriously before a match, especially because computer databases have greatly impacted chess. A small portable computer can store one million chess games and provide instant access to hundreds of games of a potential opponent. In a recent match, each player had large teams of assistants working non-stop to find weaknesses in the other's strategy. The opening moves of a chess game are now analyzed in great detail. Being better prepared in the opening can decide the game. Today, there are more top-level players than ever before. Hundreds of grandmasters compete for modest prize money worldwide. Success requires both physical and mental effort. A single game can last up to eight hours. For the chess master, this time is a constant struggle. A moment of lost focus can lead to disaster. The players are always under nervous tension. The chess clock adds to this tension. The end of the game often involves a frantic 'time scramble'. In these moments, each player has only seconds to make several moves or lose instantly. With minds racing and hands moving quickly, the masters make their moves and press their clocks with coordination that any athlete would admire. These moments are not for calm thinkers. The game becomes a basic struggle where nerves, determination, and a strong will to win decide the winner. At the top level of chess, losing is very painful. Winning brings great satisfaction and a chance to recover from the stress and tiredness. But one win is not enough to win a tournament. The chess master must be ready to compete the next day. Most chess competitions last 9-11 days, with games every day, and there is a year-round tournament circuit. World championship matches are even more demanding. The 1984 match between Anatoli Karpov and Gary Kasparov in Moscow had to be stopped after several months because both players were exhausted. Karpov lost about two stone (10kg) in weight. Can Fischer overcome these challenges? He once said, "All I want to do, ever, is play chess." This made his departure from the chess world after 1972 seem even more puzzling. But in some ways, it was a fitting end to his story. It made Bobby Fischer a legend. If he has returned for the money, he will do well. Whatever happens in his match with Spassky, both will end up much richer. But if Fischer has come back truly believing he can prove he is still the best player in the world, the final result could be very disappointing.'

**Fame and Fortune**

Imogen Edwards-Jones talks to some of the new British talents, from poets to pop stars, who are on their way to success.

**A** Nick Grosso, in his early 30s, has written three plays that critics love. He is now turning his first play, "Peaches," into a movie script. "It's low budget, but we don't know how low," he says. "It won't be over £30 million, but it could be as low as £30." The most surprising thing about Nick is that before writing "Peaches," he had never seen or read a play. "When I wrote the play, I never thought it would be performed," he says. "It's set in a car. I probably wouldn't do that now because I know the problems it causes. I knew nothing back then." He left school at 16 but returned a year later. After finishing his A-levels, he joined the Young People's Theatre. "I realized I wanted to write for actors. I wanted my writing to be heard, not just read, because of the rhythm and rhyme," he says. "It was the first time I enjoyed being in an educational environment. It was very stimulating."

**B** Comedian Simon Pegg, 28, has progressed a lot since studying drama at Bristol University. He is currently writing a TV comedy series and has just finished a demanding tour with comedy star Steve Coogan. He has always worked hard. Even at Bristol, he was improving his skills in comedy clubs. "University was very theoretical," Simon remembers. "It made me realize I didn't want to be a serious actor and that I was more interested in comedy. People think comedy is the hardest job in the world, but it really isn't. If you have courage and good material, it's wonderful to make people laugh." He has performed with the comic group Funny Business, but his work with Steve Coogan has been the most successful. "He saw my show, and since I was a big fan of his, he probably saw me copying him," Simon admits.

**C** Ciaran McMenamin, 24, became well-known when he starred in the series "The Young Person's Guide To Becoming A Rock Star." The critics loved it, and his career has taken off quickly. "It's been a great opportunity for me," he says with a smile. "I'm now in a position where I can choose what I do, which is what I've always wanted." This is a rare situation, especially since he just graduated. Looking at Ciaran's early career, it's clear he was always going to be successful. Encouraged by his mother, he went from playing lead roles at school to the Ulster Youth Theatre, where he stayed for four years. "I was using acting as an excuse not to do homework," Ciaran laughs. "But I decided to take it seriously because I was good at it and loved it." Now he is waiting for the praise to come in, but when asked about fame, he becomes thoughtful. "When you're 18, you think you'll love the photos and interviews, but you soon realize that's not why you're acting. It's about getting respect for doing good work."

**D** Neil Taylor, 25, is the lead singer of the pop band Matrix, which has just signed a three-album deal with Domino Records. Neil and his bandmate Rick Brown are expected to be very successful when their single "Chimera" is released soon. "The record company's idea of good sales is different from mine," he says. "They're talking about a big hit, but I have no idea. For me, if two people buy it, I'll be happy." Unlike many new pop stars, Neil has worked hard for his success. He left school at 16 and has been trying to break into the music business ever since. "It's funny how things happen," he says. "I had been playing student gigs for eight years and was getting tired. I was about to give up when this happened." By "this," he means meeting Rick Brown, who had contacts at Domino, and forming Matrix. It couldn't have happened at a better time. "There were times when I was very depressed, and I've been in some terrible bands. But hopefully, it will all have been worth it."

**E** Poet and author Stephen Richards, 27, has won more prizes, awards, and academic honors than many people twice his age. He is well-known on the poetry circuit, where he has been touring and giving readings for the past six years. Now his first novel, "Hidden," will be published in March. "It's a story of obsessive love. It was a strong idea that I couldn't express as a poem." Stephen loved creative writing at school but became disillusioned with education later. "I decided not to go to university, but when I got bored with stuffing envelopes at a theater, I decided I should." After university, he published his first work, a children's book, in 1992. "I don't think my parents expected me to be a writer. They thought I'd be a reader because that's all I did as a child." With his poetry receiving such praise, moving into novels is brave. "There's a structure with my poetry and less chance to make big mistakes," he explains. "Because a novel can be any length, there are more chances for bad words. My main goal is not to fall into a pattern of producing work without caring about the quality."

Text: A. Isabel, the main character in this funny novel, thinks she looks good in jeans but rarely wears them because she doesn't want to be associated with the wrong people. She is a 31-year-old art student who loves historical romances and is looking for Mr. Right. She worries that her knobbly knees might ruin her chances. However, she remains hopeful, which helps her and others in the story. The author writes with great energy, using a fast-paced style similar to early silent films, with chapter titles like 'Our Hero Feels Inspired'. B. This story is about the beginning and near-end of a local radio station in America. It is told from the perspective of Francis With, a smart but weak child. Francis works for WLT (With Lettuce and Tomato) Radio, a station started by Roy and Ray Soderbjerg to promote their sandwich shop. The station soon broadcasts a mix of singers, preachers, soap-opera stars, and announcers. The small-town American setting allows the author to use dry humor and simple writing. He takes the reader back to the 1940s and 1950s, a time of dime stores, old cars, and the radio. C. In the author's world, it's normal for a second husband to talk with his wife's first husband. So, when professor Richard Vaisey falls for a Russian poetess, he talks to his wife's ex. The poetess writes bad poetry, which bothers Richard, and she wants his help for her brother, who is in prison unfairly. The author skillfully untangles these issues with humor and insight into relationships, making it a fun and smart read. D. Two pairs of best friends—two women and two men—meet in 1960s London and stay connected for 25 years. At the start of this long novel, one of them, James Hudson, an American businessman, is starting a newspaper, which his friend Richard Blake is editing. The newspaper launch is important, but so is the fact that the woman they both loved (and one married) was killed years ago. The story includes murder, ambition, love, and jealousy, and the writing is good. It's a book where you can really get to know the characters. E. Written by a top American fiction writer, this funny and caring story is about Ian Bedloe, who feels guilty for a past mistake and becomes a 'father' to his brother's three orphaned children. At 40, he is slowly becoming an eccentric bachelor surrounded by the mess of family life. The story explores many emotions and focuses on the touching relationship Ian develops with the youngest child, Daphne. It's a warm book with a perfect mix of sadness and laughter.

**Volunteer Tourism: Perspectives from Four Writers**

**A.** The direct impact of volunteer tourism on development is often questioned. Volunteers, especially those on gap years, may help build homes or schools, but they usually pay a large fee to participate. This money, if given directly to local communities, could hire more workers than the volunteer could replace. Many studies question whether gap year volunteering is truly altruistic or if young people do it to gain 'cultural capital' for their careers. However, these projects might help volunteers become more ethical and considerate of less fortunate people in their future lives.

**B.** Volunteering can improve international understanding, conflict resolution, and participation in global issues. It can also create international social networks. Ideally, both volunteers and host communities benefit, contributing to the global good. However, if only wealthy individuals from richer countries volunteer, they gain international experience and career advantages, while communities without access to such opportunities see little benefit. Volunteers may use these experiences for personal gain, treating host communities as steps in their career ladder.

**C.** At its worst, international volunteering can be seen as imperialistic or self-serving, benefiting mainly the volunteers from wealthy Western countries. At its best, it provides mutual benefits, allowing for the exchange of skills and cultural experiences. Importantly, volunteering can increase awareness and commitment to fighting inequality, poverty, and unsustainable development.

**D.** Volunteer tourism aligns with the trend of life strategies focused on helping others. These strategies, which aim to 'make a difference,' can seem positive in an anti-political climate. They avoid big government and business but also bypass democratic processes, reducing development to individual charity acts. While volunteering is commendable, when marketed as sustainable development, it can degrade the true meaning of development. This approach shifts away from understanding global inequalities and the poverty experienced by many in developing countries.

**Sound the Alarm: Stuart Harris Reports**

Many of us listen to the radio when we wake up and need something to help us get out of bed. That's where the clock radio comes in. But how do you choose a good one? Our panel, which included me, inventor Tom Granger, and broadcaster Paul Bridges, tested five models currently available.

The 'dual alarm function' on one model doesn't work as expected. Instead of waking you with a buzzer and then letting you snooze, it allows you to set two different wake-up times, one for weekdays and one for weekends. This model is priced similarly to the second model we tested, but it includes a cassette player, which is a good deal. You can fall asleep to your own tapes and wake up without news. We all thought the radio quality was excellent, but the size was a downside—it's as big as a rugby ball. Paul Bridges said, "Any clock radio I buy has to leave enough space on the bedside table for my keys, wallet, glasses, and phone. I'm paranoid and always book a wake-up call in case the alarm doesn't go off."

This model was voted the best-looking and overall winner. Paul Bridges said he was "in love with it," although the clock on his test model "kept getting stuck at 16.00." I liked the digital display with its grey numbers on a green background. The wide snooze bar is easy to tap with your eyes closed. However, the smooth buttons made me want to touch them like piano keys, which was a problem when I finally looked at the 50-page instruction booklet. The clock has a self-power backup, so you don't have to reset it if someone unplugs it to use a hairdryer or vacuum cleaner; this was a big plus. However, we all found it hard to set up, though learning how made us feel "cool" and sophisticated.

Tom Granger called the model with an extra built-in lamp "unbelievably tacky." "You have to pull the light out of its socket to make it work, which makes me question the quality of the rest of it." He had to read the instruction booklet twice to get it to work; the clock kept jumping from 12.00 to 02.00. The light was hard to position; you couldn't read by it—it only shines on the clock, which is already lit. Paul Bridges liked the lamp idea but agreed the radio was hard to tune. The buzzer sounded like a submarine alarm and made me want to throw it across the room. Interestingly, this model is the third most popular on the market.

Aimed at young people, with its bright colors and matching strap, this model appealed to Tom Granger and me. "I would choose this one because it stands out," he said. The traditional controls made it the only one we set up without reading the instructions. Unfortunately, the alarm has a 20-minute margin for error; the manual says, "the alarm may sound about 10 minutes earlier or later than the set time." Paul Bridges found this unacceptable, calling the model "terribly fiddly" and "completely useless."

The simplest and cheapest model scored points with Tom Granger because it "seemed very standard and took up little space," and it has old-fashioned dial tuning. "It's more intuitive to set up. With modern push-button tuning, you're never sure if you've pressed all the buttons in the right order, so you can't trust it will work." He admitted that manufacturers had to improve radio quality because of button-tuning. I thought the tuning was crude, as did Paul Bridges, but we agreed the radio quality was fine. The buzzer on this model certainly works; it got me out of bed in just two beeps!

Text: 'Hedgehogs A hedgehog is a small mammal known for the sharp spines covering its body. Hedgehogs are found in many parts of the world, but none are native to America or Australia. All hedgehog species can roll into a tight ball when threatened, making their spines point outwards. This defense mechanism's effectiveness depends on how many spines the hedgehog has. Some desert hedgehogs have evolved to be lighter, so they have fewer spines and are more likely to try to run from an attacker, using their ball-rolling ability only as a last option. Hedgehogs are mainly active at night and sleep most of the day, either under bushes or in a hole in the ground. Although all hedgehogs can hibernate, not all do; in the right conditions, some stay awake all year.'

**Great Sportswomen on a Winning Streak**

Excelling in any sport is challenging, even for men, but women often have to work twice as hard. Training and competition leave little time for a normal life, so sacrifices are necessary. Despite these challenges, women are overcoming prejudice and breaking records. Here, we talk to a few brilliant British sportswomen who are achieving their goals.

**A. Jill, 27, Skier**
"It's an amazing feeling to fly through the air and land cleanly, but it can be scary. Sometimes you don't feel well, or it's windy and you can't see, but you just keep going. It's not easy to have a career outside skiing because we train for ten months a year. You give up a lot of your social life and friends. But it was my choice. There are six men and three women in the British team. We all compete on the same courses at the same competitions and get treated the same - it's a young sport."

**B. Caroline, 22, Cyclist**
"Two years ago, I borrowed a bike to take part in a charity race. I won overall just because I cycled faster than everyone else, which was amazing because I'd never cycled before! I'm well paid as a professional, and cycling has lots of potential for endorsements. However, I know I'm not ugly, and it worries me that people may think I've succeeded because of my looks, not because I'm the best cyclist. So I focus on cycling at the moment, rather than earning money. I do at least four hours of training every day on the bike, plus some stretching exercises, swimming, and running. My boyfriend is a cyclist too, so he understands the time you have to put into it -- it would be impossible otherwise."

**C. Annabel, 26, Rower**
"Rowing is hard for girls to get into because very few girls' schools offer it. So most don't start until they're 19 or 20, which makes it harder to succeed at an international level. Also, you usually have coaches who only stay a year or so. There's no continuity, so the women's squad is basically a mess. But it's great fun, and I love being fit, plus there's a good social life."

**D. Ffyona, 24, Long Distance Walker**
"At 13, I dreamed of walking around the world -- I didn't know just how big it was then! But Britain was too claustrophobic, too safe. I was very headstrong; I hated anyone having control over me. Now I am more tactful. Each walk has been different. The walk across Australia was the worst experience I've ever had in terms of pain. I was doing 50 miles and 21 hours each day with three hours of sleep in high temperatures and walking with 15 blisters on each foot. But I got the record! I had to because my sponsorship money was going to run out after 95 days. Men think that women are more likely to fail, so sponsoring them is always seen as a higher risk."

**E. Lisa, 26, Saloon Car Racer**
"Some men have huge egos when they're driving - you see it on motorways. When I'm doing well, they don't talk to me. Being a woman has its disadvantages. When I get to a corner, the men think 'I've got to beat her', so I've had a lot of knocks! You have to be naturally competitive and aggressive. It's very difficult to earn any money, and what I do make goes back into the sport. Women have been racing since the twenties and have always been seen as eccentrics. It's great that there are now more and more women taking up racing every year. For me, the appeal of saloon car racing is aiming for perfection, always trying to get around with a perfect lap."

**F. Alison, 28, Triathlete**
"I get up at 5.30 three mornings a week to swim. I need Tuesday and Thursday mornings to catch up on my sleep. In the evening, I just cycle or run. Yes, I do fall asleep at my desk sometimes! There is a lot of nervous build-up beforehand, and when you're racing, you really push yourself - you don't feel good if you don't. Several times I've asked myself why I do it. The answer is a) I'm happier when I keep fit, b) I'm a slob at heart, and if I didn't make myself do this, I'd really be one, c) racing is very social. Men and women usually compete together, but when an event is covered in the press, 90 percent of the article will explain the men's event, and 10 percent will say, 'Oh, by the way, so-and-so won the women's event'. The prize money isn't as good either, of course. But now we've formed an International Triathlon Women's Commission, so we're working on it."

**The Day I Drew Picasso**

Richard Cork remembers the day he met one of the most famous artists of the century, Pablo Picasso. At 18 years old, Richard was traveling around Europe and Morocco before starting university. He was low on money and found a job painting boats in Cannes. One day, while carrying his sketchbook, he saw Picasso having lunch at a restaurant in the harbor. Picasso was known to be a private person, so Richard was surprised to see him there with his wife, Jacqueline, and three friends.

Encouraged by a friend, Richard nervously approached Picasso to ask for his autograph. To his surprise, Picasso agreed and signed his sketchbook. Then, Picasso added a lively drawing on the page. Richard was thrilled and started a conversation with Picasso, though they needed an American woman at the table to translate because Picasso's English was not good.

After showing his friend the autograph, Richard was encouraged to go back and draw Picasso's portrait. Without asking for permission, Richard started sketching Picasso, who playfully made funny faces to make it difficult. Despite this, Richard continued drawing, feeling challenged by Picasso's antics. Eventually, Picasso stopped moving and allowed Richard to study him closely. Richard noticed how youthful and intense Picasso's eyes were, despite his age.

When Richard finished, Picasso wanted to see the portrait. Although Richard was embarrassed, Picasso looked at it and nodded approvingly. Then, Picasso took the crayon and quickly drew a playful version of Richard's face, moving one eye onto his nose and capturing his smile with a single line. Richard was amazed by Picasso's skill and humor.

Richard asked Picasso to sign the drawing, but Picasso declined, saying Richard already had his signature. Despite this, Richard felt incredibly lucky to have met Picasso and received his attention. This encounter meant a lot to him.

**Talking Shop: How Stores Make You Spend More**

Have you ever gone into a store and bought more than you planned? We explain the tricks shops use to make you spend more money.

**A. The Image of Freshness**

Supermarkets know that customers value fresh produce. They often place fruits and vegetables at the store entrance or have displays of house plants to create a fresh image. An in-store bakery might spread the smell of fresh bread throughout the store. The store's colors, like green, can also enhance this fresh image. However, most of what supermarkets sell, like frozen foods and cleaning products, doesn't match this fresh image.

**B. Displaying to Advantage**

The placement of products in a store is crucial for sales, especially in supermarkets. With computerized stock control, supermarkets know which areas attract the most shoppers. High-profit items or fast-selling products are placed in these spots. The saying "eye-level is buy-level" means that shelves at eye height are prime spots for products. Special offers in "dump bins" attract bargain hunters. "Complementation" is also popular, like placing salad dressings near salads or desserts near ice creams.

**C. Spreading Staples Around the Store**

Supermarkets often place low-cost essentials like bread and sugar far from the entrance. This forces shoppers to pass by more tempting, higher-profit items. Similarly, chain stores might place popular products far from the entrance, relying on customer loyalty to lead shoppers past other items that might catch their interest.

**D. Less Sells More**

Chain stores have changed how they display products. The Next chain, for example, moved away from the "pile them high, sell them cheap" method. Their stores have a "boutique" feel, displaying fewer items to give an exclusive impression. However, Next's clothes are just as mass-produced as their competitors'. Their success is due to good store design and well-designed clothing.

**E. Tempting Totals**

Food shoppers often focus on the total cost of their shopping trip rather than individual item prices. Supermarkets use this by offering a mix of low and high mark-up items. Not everything in a supermarket is cheap. Some items, called "loss leaders," are sold at a loss to attract customers. More often, low prices come from buying in bulk, offering manufacturers prime display spots, or meeting sales targets, which earn discounts from manufacturers.

**F. The All-Important Price Tag**

In chain stores, shoppers buy fewer items and notice individual prices more. Pricing a blouse at £14.99 instead of £15 is still effective. This pricing also helps reduce theft, as staff must record the sale to give the penny change.

**G. Lighting to Effect**

Both supermarkets and chain stores carefully consider lighting. Chain stores aim for lighting that resembles natural light, so clothes look the same as they would in daylight. Supermarkets use special lighting and mirrors to enhance the appearance of fresh produce.

**H. Walk This Way**

Many chain stores use different carpeting to guide shoppers. One pattern marks the main routes, and another defines sales areas. These routes, known as the "Yellow Brick Road," guide shoppers through the store. However, some shoppers hesitate to leave the main path. Marks and Spencer, for example, use wood or marble for routes, encouraging shoppers to step onto the more inviting carpet in sales areas.

**I. In-Store Promotion**

As you enter a supermarket, large photos of delicious foods greet you, tempting you if you're hungry. In the U.S., some supermarkets are testing "video trolleys." These trolleys have screens that show ads as you shop. Sensors trigger ads relevant to the products nearby, like an ad for ready-made meals near the cook-chill section. These trolleys target impulse shoppers, and makers claim they boost sales by about 30%.

Text: 'Sea, Ice & Rock Mountaineer Chris Bonnington, who is 58 years old, is famous for climbing Everest in 1985. He has also created new climbing routes in Britain and the Alps and written many books, like Quest for Adventure and Everest the Hard Way. Robin Knox-Johnston, who is 53, started his sea career in the Merchant Navy. In 1968-9, he was the first person to sail around the world alone in his yacht, Sunhaili. He also set a record for crossing the Atlantic, taking 10 days to sail from New York to the Lizard. The two teamed up to sail and climb in Greenland, and they wrote about the trip in their new book: Sea, Ice and Rock. In 1979, I was working on Quest for Adventure, a study of post-war adventure. I called Robin to ask for an interview, and he invited me to join him for a sail. I could teach him some climbing techniques, and he could teach me the basics of sailing. It was my first time on a yacht. We sailed for a while and then anchored. Robin's wife and daughter stayed on the boat, and we paddled to the shore to practice climbing. The route was quite difficult, and I was impressed by how steady Robin was in tricky conditions. He moved quietly and confidently. After a bit, we reached a huge drop. I asked Robin if he had ever climbed before. He hadn't, so I showed him how. When I finished, Robin politely asked if he could go down the way he climbed down ropes on his boat. He was used to using his arms, but I wanted him to use his legs. I wasn't too happy about it, but he lowered himself down safely. During that trip to Skye, Robin and I built a strong friendship. His idea to combine our skills on a trip to Greenland was just a bigger version of our Skye trip. Robin impressed me as a leader. Usually, the skipper makes all the decisions, but Robin asked everyone for their opinions first. Most of the time, nobody dared to advise him, but it was nice to feel included in the decision-making process. To be honest, I found the sailing difficult and boring. The moments of crisis on the way back were easy to handle: the adrenaline kicks in, and you get all worked up. The hard part was spending day after day in the middle of the sea. I love the land and am not really a do-it-yourself person. Robin, on the other hand, is a natural sailor and enjoyed fixing the engine or mending the toilet. I knew Robin didn't really need me. To be honest, I felt a bit useless at times, and I found that hard. The crew was also very close together: six people on a 32ft yacht, designed to sleep four. At least on a mountain expedition, you can get away from each other. When we reached Greenland, and it was my turn to 'lead' the expedition, I found it hard to be responsible for Robin's life. There were many times when, if Robin had fallen, he could have pulled me down with him. I had to watch for that constantly. I underestimated how difficult the Cathedral -- Greenland's highest mountain - would be. Robin isn't a natural climber, which made his efforts even more impressive. The first time we tried to reach the top, we were on the move for 24 hours. On the way down, we were falling asleep on steep slopes, 1,500 feet above the ground. Robin went through a tough time, but he completely trusted me. He just followed. When it got too difficult, and I realized we had to turn back, he accepted it. I also knew that Robin was worried about the boat: whether we'd be able to get it through the ice, whether it was in one piece. Yet he was all in favor of us trying to climb the mountain again. The only time there was a near-crisis in our relationship was on the yacht on the way home. We were taking turns to be on watch. I was supposed to get up at 4 am for my shift, but Robin decided not to wake me. He felt he could do it himself. The previous night I'd almost fallen asleep. I felt that he didn't trust me - I felt insecure, and I said so. Robin immediately reassured me that I'd misunderstood. While we enjoyed the Skye trip, we didn't really know each other until the end of the Greenland expedition. I found that underneath his tough exterior, Robin was a kind-hearted, sensitive person.'

**A History of the Apple**

Apples have been with us since ancient times, in many colors, shapes, and sizes. However, the late 20th century risks losing this heritage.

**Prehistoric Wild Apples (8,000 BC)**

Humans have been eating apples since prehistoric times. In Neolithic Britain, people spat out apple seeds. Around 10,000 years ago, they left apple remains near their homes in Switzerland and Italy. In Switzerland and near the Caucasus mountains, ancient people stored dried apple halves for winter. These were wild crab apples, small and shriveled, known in Ancient Britain as 'windings'. They were quite different from the apples we know today.

**Norman Knowledge (1000 AD)**

The French learned fruit-growing skills from the Romans, which were developed in monasteries. This knowledge, including cider-making, was brought to Britain, along with the dessert apple, Decio, introduced by the Roman general, Etio. However, most Roman apple varieties did not suit the British climate, and Norman varieties became more popular. British monks continued to experiment and develop new apples, and many Western apples today come from these varieties.

**Medieval Favorites (1200)**

Several apple types became popular in Britain during the 13th century. The Old English Pearmain, recorded in 1204, was the main dessert apple until the 18th century. Its cooking partner was the Costard, sold in Oxford markets from 1296 until the 17th century, giving us the word 'costermonger' for a street fruit and vegetable seller. However, apple production declined due to droughts, the Black Death, and the Wars of the Roses. More apples were imported until the 16th century when Henry VIII sent Richard Harris to France to learn about apple cultivation. Harris returned with many grafts, including the famous Pippins, and created the first modern-style orchard in Kent.

**Settler Treasure (1750)**

By the 17th century, apples were so popular in Britain that settlers took them to Canada, Australia, the US, South Africa, and New Zealand. Captain Bligh took the first apples to Australia; Jan van Riebeeck took them to South Africa, and the Pilgrim Fathers carried them to America. In North America, the most famous apple-planter was John Chapman, or 'Johnny Appleseed'. Born in 1774, he planted apple nurseries from Pennsylvania to Indiana. The Indians saw him as a medicine man, and his love for apple trees, unusual clothing, and religious devotion inspired many folktales. He was said to be so kind to animals that he even slept with bears.

**Modern Delicious (1850)**

Around this time in Iowa, a Quaker farmer named Jesse Hiatt found a shoot growing from a dead tree's roots. It became an apple tree with a new apple, which Hiatt called 'Hawkey'. At a fruit show, a judge tasted it and exclaimed 'Delicious, delicious!'. In 1895, it was introduced to the market as 'Delicious' and became one of the most widely grown apples in the world.

**Granny Smith (1850)**

Another famous modern apple was discovered in Australia by Maria Anne Smith. The daughter of convicts, Maria was independent and worked as a midwife in Eastwood, New South Wales. Known as 'Granny Smith', she managed the family farm and orchard. In 1868, she found a small tree growing from discarded fruit. She transplanted it and soon harvested the first major crop of green apples, which became famous worldwide. When asked about the tree, she said, 'Well, it's just like God to make something useful out of what we think is rubbish', referring to both the fruit and her convict origins.

**Uniformity (1950)**

Apples are now grown worldwide, from India to Africa. Most are grown commercially and come from just a few varieties, chosen for their red skin or ability to travel well, rather than taste. This uniformity is reducing the variety and gene pool of apples. While UK gardeners have preserved many old apple varieties, the US has lost most of its apples from 100 years ago. Consumers are starting to demand more variety. We cannot rely on amateur gardeners to save apple diversity. We must value and protect natural diversity for everyone's benefit.

**Explore Worldwide - Small Groups, Big Adventures**

Explore Worldwide is a leader in adventure travel, offering trips for those who want more than just a beach holiday. We focus on new and unusual destinations with unique itineraries. Our brochure features over 100 adventures, including tours, treks, safaris, and expeditions in more than 60 countries. Most trips last 1-4 weeks.

**Small Groups**

Our groups average 16 people, allowing for a more personal experience. This setup helps you connect with local cultures and people, making your travel more enriching.

**Different Modes of Travel**

We use various types of transport, often within the same trip. This includes chartered coaches, local buses, trains, expedition vehicles, minibuses, boats, canoes, rafts, camels, light planes, and walking. Each trip adapts to the local environment.

**Who Travels with Explore?**

Our travelers are adventurous people, mainly from the UK, Europe, Australia, New Zealand, Canada, and the USA. They are usually aged 25-55, with half traveling as couples and the rest as solo adventurers. Our trips suit those in good health, reasonably fit, and adaptable.

**Activities and Interests**

Each trip is unique, so we categorize our adventures into 8 different themes, highlighting main activities and interests. These include cultural experiences, wildlife safaris, ethnic encounters, hiking, major treks, wilderness exploration, sailtreks, and river journeys.

**Cultural/Adventure**

Most trips have a cultural focus, emphasizing local cultures and historical sites. Destinations include Egypt, Jordan, Syria, Yemen, Turkey, Greece, India, Bhutan, Thailand, China, Peru, Bolivia, Guatemala, and Belize. Short walks to off-the-beaten-path sites are often included.

**Wildlife and Natural History**

Our safaris visit top game parks, offering close encounters with wildlife. In Africa, you might track gorillas in Zaire, walk with guides in Uganda, or canoe on the Zambezi River. We provide camping equipment, with some trips offering hotel stays. In Asia and South America, we use hotels and lodges for game viewing, like our tiger safari in India.

**Ethnic Encounters**

Meeting ethnic or tribal peoples is a highlight. You might meet the Tuareg in the Sahara, the Maya in Mexico, or the Huli in Papua New Guinea. We travel in small groups to minimize cultural and environmental impact.

**Easy/Moderate Hiking**

Many trips include easy walks through countryside or village-to-village hikes. Destinations include Spain, Provence, Tuscany, Crete, Corsica, Greece, Morocco, Turkey, Bulgaria, Thailand, Bhutan, Nepal, and Venezuela. Main luggage is transported separately.

**Major Treks**

For strong walkers, we offer treks in mountain ranges like the Atlas, Himalayas, and Andes. These involve high altitudes and may include camping or staying in local homes. Support vehicles or porters carry heavy gear.

**Wilderness Experience**

Explore remote wilderness areas like the Amazon Rainforest or the Sahara Desert. These adventures offer a chance to see exotic landscapes and wildlife.

**Sailtreks/Seatreks**

Relaxing holidays on local boats, like felucca sailboats in Egypt or gulets in Turkey. We explore islands in Indonesia and the Galapagos by yacht.

**Raft and River Journeys**

River trips range from a few hours to several days, using inflatables or whitewater rafts. No experience is needed, and safety skills are taught. Destinations include India, Africa, and the Amazon.

Richard Nerurkar, a top British 10,000-metre runner, visits a high-altitude training camp in Kenya. Located ten miles south of the equator, a mountain track leads from a quiet road from Nairobi to Mount Kenya, the country's highest peak. This beautiful but isolated place is Nanyuki, where I have trained for the past three winters. However, I had never trained with Kenyan runners on their home ground until my fourth trip. During this visit, I competed in my first race in Kenya's thin air and stayed at the national team training camp. I was invited by Kenya's national team coach after finishing fifth in the World Championship 10,000 meters race, behind three Kenyans and a Moroccan. It was an opportunity I couldn't miss. Training at high altitude increases red blood cells, improving oxygen capacity, which has helped many Kenyan runners succeed. My first race in Africa, held in Nairobi, was also the continent's first international cross-country race. It was a humbling experience, as 41 runners finished ahead of me, all but three were Kenyan. Despite this, I felt I had a good race. I don't think Kenyan success is only due to altitude. Kenyan runners have a simple approach to the sport. Their running style is effortless, their diet simple, and they love competing. The least discussed aspect of their success is their training. My stay at the Kenyan team training camp provided answers. The camp is at St Mark's College, 6,200 feet up Mt Kenya, surrounded by playing fields and tropical vegetation. It's basic, with few comforts. Athletes live with regular students, six to a room in dormitories. Their days include three workouts: an easy morning run, interval training mid-morning, and a steady run in the late afternoon. The daily routine starts at six.
