We got up and were briefed by the coaches for the morning run. "Run easy, you have a hard job today," the coach who invited me said. We covered about 40 kilometres each day, just short of a marathon. Sunday was an exception, with only one 20-kilometre run, a welcome break from the three daily workouts. Life outside running was simple. A splash of water and brushing teeth were enough before breakfast. Breakfast was tea, bread, and boiled eggs in a small dining area. Lunch and dinner were similar: ugali (a maize dish), stew, cabbage or spinach, and tea. After running, we drove to bathe in streams from Mt Kenya's glaciers. By the time I left the camp, I appreciated Kenyan success even more. It can't be just genetics, upbringing, or altitude. I thought about another explanation: the simple lifestyle, tough workouts, and passion for success might be the real reasons behind Kenya's rise in world distance running.

**Hit and Miss of Mass Marketing**

Almost everyone knows that advertising is struggling. It's not just because of the recession. Advertising started to decline in early 1989, even before the recession hit hard. The problems with advertising are more basic, and the decline is happening worldwide. The truth is that advertising hasn't kept up with economic changes. Advertisers think about mass markets and mass media, but as more brands and media options have appeared, target markets have become more divided. Even big brand campaigns should focus on smaller audiences, but they often don't. This is where advertising has gone wrong.

Think about your own shopping habits. When you go to a supermarket, you might buy 30, 40, or 50 items. Many of these won't be advertised brands; some will be multiple purchases of the same brand. You might buy only a few advertised brands from the 15,000 products available in the store. Over a year, you probably won't buy more than a few hundred brands. Consumer durables? Maybe a dozen a year. Cars? If you have a new car, it's likely provided by your employer. If not, you might buy one every three years. You don't buy many clothes either, and most aren't advertised brands. Even when you include sweets, medicines, hardware, and services, you probably don't buy more than 400 different brands a year.

Compare that to the 32,500 branded goods and services advertised, according to Media Register. Let's focus on the 9,500 brands that Media Register lists and analyzes. The average person buys 400 of those 9,500, and not all because of advertising. That's about 4 percent. So, you can forget the saying often linked to Lord Leverhulme: "Half of my advertising is wasted, but I don't know which half." You could say that 96 percent of all advertising is wasted, but nobody knows which 96 percent.

When you watch TV tonight, count how many commercials are for brands you buy or might buy in the future. For most people, it's about one in 16 (6 percent), so the commercials for the other 15 (94 percent) seem wasted. You might think you're not influenced by advertising, but almost everyone thinks that. The truth is, nobody buys most of the brands they see advertised. Waste is part of using media for advertising. The idea that everyone who sees an ad will buy the product is unrealistic. People notice only a few ads and ignore the rest, so waste can't be avoided.

That doesn't mean advertising isn't cost-effective. Many ads have shown it is. Advertising needs to reach many people to find the right audience because advertisers can't know in advance who will respond. Media advertising works because it's a cheap way to communicate with many people. However, all waste is unpleasant. With smart targeting, advertisers can reduce waste by increasing the percentage of people who respond, but they can never know exactly who will respond. Even the best direct mail campaign never gets a 100 percent response.

This is a key difference between media advertising and face-to-face selling. A salesperson might succeed with every client they talk to, but this can't happen with media. If advertisers knew exactly who would respond, they wouldn't need media at all. They could contact those people directly. This is true for all types of ads, from personal announcements to soft drink commercials. Any advertiser who gains one million new customers (2 percent of the adult population) is doing well. For soap powder, the top brands would be thrilled with a million extra customers. So, any advertising campaign that wins over 2 percent of the population would be very successful. As I said at the start, this is a small part of the population. The most cost-effective way to reach them might be through mass media, but for advertising to succeed again, its message needs to be more focused than ever before.

Text: 'Solar Survivor Charles Clover explores Britain's most environmentally-friendly home. Southwell in Nottinghamshire has some surprises. One is Southwell Minster, an ancient cathedral with 'green' men figures carved by medieval craftsmen. Another is the 'autonomous house', Britain's greenest home, designed by Robert and Brenda Vale. The Vales use rainwater for washing and drinking, recycle sewage into garden compost, and heat their house with waste heat from appliances and body heat from themselves, their children, and their cats, Edison and Faraday. The house looks traditional, with a clay tile roof, and blends with the town's old buildings. It was approved by planners even though it's in a conservation area. The solar-powered doorbell is silent, and the house is super-insulated with triple-glazed windows, making it very quiet inside. Once inside, you must take off your shoes. The house is very still, and on a sunny day, the conservatory warms the air before it ventilates the house. Vale opens ventilation shafts and windows to create airflow because the house is very draught-proof. Even the cats have an air-locked door. The Vales, who teach architecture at Nottingham University, have been focused on the environment since the 1970s. They wrote a book called The Autonomous House. They designed a building that emits no carbon dioxide and decided to do without mains water. They use composting toilets, rainwater tanks, and copper gutters to protect drinking water, which is filtered before use. Water from washing goes into the garden, and they don't use a dishwasher to avoid strong detergents. Most features are designed to be environmentally friendly. 'We wanted to show that you can design a house that is less harmful to the environment without living in the dark,' says Robert. The house's only medieval aspect is its aesthetic: the hall, with a hearth and staircase, is the full height of the building. The Vales pay no water bills, and last winter, the house used only nine units of electricity a day, costing about 70p. Soon, solar panels will be installed, reducing electricity use further. The house will generate more electricity than it uses, enough to charge an electric car. The only heating is a small wood-burning stove, rarely used. Is it warm in winter? One February night, Robert was reading and said it was too warm to light the fire. The room temperature was 18C, comfortable because there are no draughts or heat loss. Perceived temperature depends on these factors. An Edwardian lady was comfortable at 12.5C due to her clothing's insulation. Robert suggests people in old houses should live like they did in the past, but this idea may not catch on. The house is low-tech, with little to go wrong. Most materials were from a builder's merchant and installed by local craftsmen, making it cheap to build, costing the same per square metre as low-cost housing. Commercial builders resist this idea.'

**Blacksmiths**

Throughout history, iron has fascinated people, and those who work with it, blacksmiths, have been seen as more than just skilled workers. Before the Industrial Revolution, blacksmiths were as respected as doctors and astrologers because they made weapons, armor, and farming tools. They were also celebrated as artists. In the 18th century, blacksmiths created the intricate ironwork for St Paul's Cathedral. The flowing metal designs of French and Belgian Art Nouveau buildings were also crafted by talented blacksmiths. However, by the late 1960s in Britain, blacksmiths were almost extinct because heavy industry no longer needed them, and modern architects rarely used elegant wrought-iron designs.

In the past 10 years, there has been a revival of interest in blacksmithing, thanks to a renewed interest in decorative architecture and more creative interior design. Despite this, much of the work still looks old-fashioned, with manufacturers promoting 'classical' or 'Victorian-style' gates and balconies. Trendy design stores often feature rusty candlesticks with decorative elements. Fortunately, there are new alternatives, and a series of events in the coming weeks aims to promote the blacksmith's craft. The first event, an exhibition of forged ironwork by members of the British Artist Blacksmiths Association (BABA), opened last week at the Fire & Iron gallery in Leatherhead, Surrey.

Alan Dawson, the secretary of BABA, says, "We could be at the start of a new Iron Age because both the public and blacksmiths are seeing things differently." Power tools have made it easier for blacksmiths to work with metal, allowing them to bend, split, twist, and weld it with ease. "In short," says Dawson, "these artists now have a material that lets them express themselves." About 250 pieces are on display at the show, ranging from bookends to a spiral staircase. Prices start at £90 and go up to several thousand pounds. Most of the money will go to the individual makers, but a percentage will be kept by the Association to promote good ironwork, says Dawson. His own contributions include an eight-foot gate and a lamp with a glass shade. "My style comes from letting steel bend and flow into shape when it's hot. It's like drawing with metal in space," he says.

Many artists are fascinated by iron. Unlike most metals, which are easy to shape when cold, iron and steel are tougher and more challenging. Susan May, a jeweler by training, says, "It's magical because it's incredibly soft when hot, but as soon as it cools, it becomes rigid and immovable again." Ann Catrin Evans' steel door-knockers and handles seem inspired by the castles seen in horror films. One of her designs looks like a ball and chain, another like a Celtic cross. "I love that steel is cold and hard," she says. "And it feels like it's there forever." No other base metal has given people as much visual pleasure or a greater feeling of security. The chances of iron being used decoratively for the next thousand years are good, as long as we don't have to see any more rusty candlesticks.

**THE DAY I GAVE UP SMOKING**

I thought everyone would be happy, but one of my colleagues was very angry. "What do you mean?" she shouted. "If it was that easy, why didn't you stop years ago?" I guess my inability to explain how I went from being a pack-a-day smoker to a non-smoker in just four hours was a bit annoying. I find it strange myself. The stop-smoking session was a mix of group therapy and hypnotherapy, and it happened exactly two months and three weeks ago. I hadn't planned to stop, and I didn't even really want to. For one thing, I was annoyed by the constant pressure from anti-smoking groups—and I still am. Also, I had low blood pressure and a healthy family. I didn't cough or feel sick and seemed to recover from colds more easily than friends who had healthier lifestyles.

On that ordinary Thursday afternoon, I went to the Birmingham session of The Easy Way to Stop Smoking to write an article about other people trying to quit. "I won't be trying to stop myself, it wouldn't be fair," I said firmly. "Since my reason for being here is writing, not stopping, it wouldn't be right to expect your method to work on me." I thought I was being very reasonable. After all, I really enjoyed smoking. It gave me real pleasure. I thought the counselor looked at me knowingly. We were encouraged to smoke as much as we wanted, and most of the afternoon was spent in a room so full of smoke that we had to open the windows. I noticed with interest that when I was told to smoke, I was reluctant to do so—and so were the others.

I suppose what happened was that the stop-smoking messages made sense. Just as smoking had become a challenge against opposition, the idea of stopping started to feel appealing. The possibility of not being a smoker began to make me feel powerful. It was a secret feeling that had nothing to do with anyone except myself. Could I also conquer the world? In many ways, it was easy. The physical craving, the desire for nicotine, in the same place where you feel hunger, faded after a minute or two, and I experienced them for only four or five days. The one activity—my work—that I thought would be the hardest to do without cigarettes didn't cause a single problem. I had really believed that I wouldn't be able to work to deadlines without nicotine and that for the first time ever, I would fail to write a story on time. Surprisingly, spending time at home on weekend mornings was the hardest thing—and it still is. I am increasingly coming to the view that for me, smoking had a lot to do with avoiding boredom; having a cigarette was an activity in itself. Yes, I do miss my cigarettes, but not too much. Each "new" experience as a non-smoker has to be faced—eating out, waiting for a plane, checking into a hotel, a theater break. All are key moments when I would have previously smoked cigarettes.

**Dorothy Who?**

Dorothy Hodgkin is the only British woman scientist to win a Nobel Prize, yet she is not well-known in her own country. Georgina Ferry, who is writing Hodgkin's first biography, has noticed that many people in Britain are unaware of Hodgkin's achievements. If Hodgkin had won a Nobel Prize in literature, she would likely be a household name. Hodgkin, who passed away in 1994, was an extraordinary person. Her life mirrored significant changes in the 20th century, such as the progress of women's education and the globalization of science.

When Ferry started her research, she read scientific biographies. A friend of Hodgkin's suggested a biography of Linus Pauling, a close friend and fellow scientist who also opposed nuclear weapons. However, Ferry found no biographies of Pauling in her local bookshop, which surprised her. Pauling was a highly influential chemist and a Nobel Prize winner in both chemistry and peace, yet he was not well-known to British readers.

Even scientists have questioned the value of scientific biographies. Peter Medawar, another Nobel laureate, once said that scientists' lives are often dull to read about. This negative view might explain why publishers and booksellers are not eager to promote scientific biographies. The idea that scientists' lives are less interesting than those of artists or politicians is part of the 'two cultures' mentality, which sees a divide between the arts and sciences.

However, this view is changing. Scientists are now more visible in the media. For example, Professor Richard Dawkins presents TV quiz prizes, and geneticist Steve Jones appears in car advertisements. These activities help make scientists more relatable to the public.

The publishing world is also changing. Scientific biographies used to be scholarly and dull, often ignoring the personal lives of scientists. This changed with Richard Feynman's memoir, "Surely You're Joking, Mr. Feynman?", which showed the personal side of a great physicist. Now, even famous scientists like Isaac Newton and Albert Einstein are portrayed with their personal flaws.

Dorothy Hodgkin was dedicated to her scientific work. She solved the structures of penicillin and vitamin B12, winning the Nobel Prize for Chemistry in 1964, and later solved the structure of insulin in 1969. She also had three children and was married to a historian. Her personal life may not seem directly related to her scientific work, but it shows how she balanced different aspects of her life.

Hodgkin's passion for scientific inquiry was central to her life. Communicating this passion is a challenge for biographers because many readers lack the scientific background to understand complex ideas. However, understanding science is not harder than reading Shakespeare or learning a new language; it just requires effort. It is unfortunate that many educated people are unaware of the contributions of scientists like Dorothy Hodgkin.

Margaret and Her Water-Finding Skills

Margaret Wilkins is known for having a 'sixth sense'. She can use a forked hazel rod to find water underground. Many farmers, whose wells have dried up, ask for her help. Margaret and her husband run a well-drilling business, using equipment like drilling rigs and air-compressed hammers. However, to find water, Margaret only needs a forked hazel stick. Their success rate is over 90%.

Dowsing is the ability to find water, minerals, and lost objects underground. It is considered a 'sixth sense'. There are many ideas about how it works, from physical explanations like magnetism to spiritual ones. One believable theory is that everything on Earth vibrates, and water vibrates more than other things. Dowsers might have a special ability to sense these vibrations. Some say they can 'sense' water, while others claim they can smell it, as smell is a very strong sense.

The Wilkins have been very busy during recent droughts, with a waiting list of almost six weeks at one point. Most of Margaret's clients are farmers with dry wells. She says, 'We usually see customers only once because wells last a long time.' Other clients have remote cottages or barns, now used as holiday homes, where installing water pipes is too expensive. Some are golf-course developers needing water for clubhouse facilities.

Margaret tries to find water 50 to 70 meters deep. 'You can't drill a well where farm or other waste might contaminate the water. The water we find flows in cracks of solid rock, and if we bring it straight up, it should be clean. But in Cornwall, you have to watch out for iron because the area is rich in minerals.' Another important factor is electricity to power the pump; it's too costly to run power lines over long distances, so the well should be near existing power sources. After considering all this, Margaret starts looking for water.

On large areas like golf courses, she begins with a map and a pendulum. 'I hold the pendulum still and move it over the map. It swings when it is over an area with water.' After the map shows possible spots, Margaret walks over the fields with a hazel stick. 'Once I'm above water, I feel something strange; I sway a bit. When it stops, I use the stick to find the exact spot to drill.' She holds the two forks of the stick with both hands and pulls them slightly outward. 'When water is right below, the straight part of the stick rises. It's crucial to drill exactly where the stick indicates. If you're off by a little, you can miss the water completely. My husband also dowses the same area; usually, we agree on where to drill. If we don't agree, we keep looking until we do.'

Margaret Wilkins is not alone in practicing this unusual skill in the west of England. Anthropologists and writers have long been interested in this mysterious ability. Margaret calls it an 'intuitive perception of the environment', which is the closest explanation for her accurate water-finding. Without this 'sixth sense', how else could her family successfully run their well-drilling business year after year?

**We changed lives for a day!**

Have you ever thought about swapping lives with someone else for a day? Maybe you think it would be fun to try something different? We arranged this for four people - read about their experiences.

**Amanda's Story**

Amanda, a 23-year-old mother with two daughters, swapped lives with her friend Cindy, a 30-year-old waitress at a busy London restaurant. Amanda had never been in such a lively place before. It was dark, noisy, and full of people. She was unsure if she could handle it. Being a mother is busy, but this was different! She had only fifteen minutes to learn how to carry a tray of drinks with one hand. The other waitresses made it look easy, but Amanda struggled, and the drinks fell, making a mess. She was embarrassed, but the other waitresses laughed and said everyone makes mistakes at first.

By 11:30 am, a line had formed outside, and Amanda felt nervous. She worried about remembering orders, but everything was automated. After a few hours, her feet hurt, and she couldn't get used to the loud music. She had to keep asking customers to repeat themselves, which was embarrassing. By the end of her shift at 5 pm, she was exhausted and wanted to soak her feet. She was surprised when a waitress said it had been a 'quiet' day. Amanda realized waitressing was tiring and not for shy people. She wasn't impressed with the pay either, as she didn't get any tips. She was glad to return to her children, which seemed easier after waitressing.

**Cindy's Story**

Cindy was nervous but excited to be a 'mum' for the day. She was warned the girls were cheeky, but she thought she could handle it. She was wrong! After Amanda left for work, Cindy had to dress and feed the girls. After dropping Sophie at school and Katie at nursery, she thought she would have some peace. But Amanda left a note with chores like making beds, cleaning, and doing laundry. At 1 pm, Cindy picked up Katie, went to the supermarket, and then home for lunch. When Sophie came home, the real challenge began. The girls turned the sofa into a trampoline and screamed loudly. Cindy thought they would tire out, but they didn't. She managed to get them to bed by 8 pm, but they kept asking for water to stay up and watch TV. Cindy found it exhausting to negotiate with them all evening. She didn't realize how tiring it was to look after two small children. Despite the challenges, she enjoyed the day.

**Rosemary's Story**

Rosemary, a 42-year-old dairy farmer, swapped with Hilary, a 30-year-old primary school teacher. On the farm, Rosemary wakes up at 5:30 am, so sleeping until 7 was a treat. She worried about what to wear and hoped she blended in at the school assembly with 400 pupils. In the maths class, children worked in groups, which was different from her school days. She helped with a nature project and was exhausted by lunchtime, but teachers only have a short break. She attended a staff meeting and helped with athletics trials. After lunch, there was a silent reading lesson and a French lesson, where the children practiced on her. Finally, there was Physical Education, and Rosemary was drained, but the children were full of energy. She found speaking in front of the class daunting. Despite teachers having more holidays, she preferred farming.

**Hilary's Story**

Hilary arrived at White House Farm at 8:30 am, surprised that Rosemary had been up for three hours. The farm has 100 Jersey cows, 15 calves, and about 800 ewes. Rosemary also makes ice-cream, yoghurt, and cream. Hilary spent the morning in the ice-cream parlour, bottling milk and packaging ice-cream. It was hard not to taste the treats! At lunchtime, she checked the sheep and helped a fallen ewe. Sheep need to be checked daily, especially in winter. After feeding the calves, she started milking, which took two-and-a-half hours. Rosemary does this twice a day, every day of the year. Hilary found the day lonely and missed the children. The hardest part was not being able to take time off, as the cows need milking daily. Farming seems romantic, but it's tough, with irregular income and dependence on the weather.

Text: 'A trumpet isn't just for Christmas... It's interesting how many musicians, even famous ones, come from homes without music. Hakan Hardenberger, the only son of parents who didn't play music, grew up in a rural area of southern Sweden. At 30, he is now a unique trumpet player in the world. His recordings introduce new music, including concertos by lesser-known composers from the baroque and classical periods, as well as new works. When you meet him, he looks young and is friendly, much like the sound of the trumpet. Recently, he played the Hummel Trumpet Concerto in one of London's top concert halls, and a TV feature focused on his work and growth, filmed in both the UK and Sweden. Born near Malmo, his career began with a Christmas gift when he was eight. His father, who liked Louis Armstrong, decided to give him a real trumpet, not a toy. The gift was a success, and the boy played constantly. His mother found a teacher for him, the second trumpet player in the Malmo Symphony Orchestra, Bo Nilsson, who noticed his talent right away. Hardenberger is grateful for having such a dedicated teacher who loved the trumpet and was always looking for new ways to improve. Hardenberger explains that the trumpet is a simple instrument with imperfections, and he learned to work with them. From the start, he had a special sound, which he developed as a child. Unlike John Wallace, a great British trumpet player who started in brass bands and orchestras, Hardenberger always saw himself as a solo artist. He admired the French trumpeter Maurice Andre, who also focused on solo performances. His parents supported his dream of becoming a professional trumpet player. At 15, he needed to decide where to study. America was considered too far and dangerous, so at 16, he went to Paris to study with Pierre Thibaud. Thibaud advised against joining an orchestra, comparing it to gardening. Hardenberger knew he played better than others his age, but during his first competition at 17 in Paris, he realized he had a special ability to connect with audiences. Thibaud suggested he enter the competition for experience. Hardenberger learned the pieces for the first round and advanced to the second. He knew most of the pieces in that round too, but in the final, he faced a difficult concerto. He didn't win first prize, but he enjoyed performing and realized that even if he didn't play perfectly, people listened to him. Hardenberger's honesty about his work might seem arrogant, but that's not true. He thoughtfully avoids analyzing his gift for communication, believing that trying to explain it might ruin it. The power of music, he says, is in its ability to move people.'

**New In Paperback**

A. The story of Tristan Smith takes place in the imaginary country of Efica. It is a unique tale about human power, history, and humor. The author has skillfully created a world with its own history, traditions, and customs. The book is known for its humor and the author's special vision, combined with deep psychological insight. It is a challenging but rewarding read.

B. Harriet is a middle-class woman with an architect husband and her own business. Normally, she would not meet someone like Sheila, a working-class woman who cares for her elderly father and has raised her grandson, Leo, since he was three. Their lives change when Leo attacks Harriet's son, Joe, in the street. After the court case, both boys refuse to talk about the incident. Leo, who was a good student and had never fought before, won't explain his actions. Joe recovers physically but becomes withdrawn. Harriet is deeply affected by her son's condition, and caring for him consumes her life. Sheila feels so guilty that she asks to meet Harriet, and from this meeting, an unusual friendship begins. The author is excellent at showing how people react to major changes in their lives and captures the feeling that, no matter how hard a mother tries, it never seems enough.

C. This book was shortlisted for the Booker Prize and tells the story of one of the most remote Scottish Orkney islands and its people over a long, quiet history. The story is set against important moments in Scottish history, imagined through the daydreams of the young main character, Thorfinn Ragnarson. He disappears suddenly at one point in the book but returns after World War II, having learned to appreciate the simple lives of his ancestors.

D. After his recent successful book, the author has written a sequel with the same gentle irony and sharp observations of family life that made the first book popular. Fifteen years after her daughter's death, Aurora Greenway is nearing her seventies with her lively friend, Rosie Sunlap. Aurora's approach to life is still a mix of vanity, charm, and reluctant kindness, and Rosie helps her in her enjoyable manipulation of suitors and friends. By the end of the book, Aurora must face the reality of time passing and a new generation taking the spotlight. The author is skilled at revealing the deep sadness beneath the ordinary events of life and focuses more on the shadows than the bright moments of human activity, showing the randomness of events.

E. Six different people are brought together by millionaire Logan Urquhart to sail around the South Pacific islands on his yacht, the Ardent Spirit. The author uses her impressive descriptive language to explore the personal journeys of self-discovery that each of these sailors experiences. They return home with their spirits renewed by their time on the "desert cities of waves." The author uses striking images to express her themes of memory and awareness, which are both alienating and enlightening.

**Take Five Careers**

Rebecca Cripps talks to five women about their different jobs: the good parts, the challenges, and what a typical day looks like.

**A. THE BRAIN SURGEON**

**Name:** Anne  
**Age:** 34  

**ANNE'S DAY**  
"I wake up at 6:30 am, go to the gym at 7 am, and start work by 8 am. I begin operating at 8:30 am. I perform surgeries all day on Monday and Wednesday, and sometimes on Friday afternoons. Most surgeries take about three hours, but some can last all day. I've worked ten hours straight without eating or taking a break. Deciding when and how to operate can be stressful. I don't feel stressed while operating, but I do worry about the next day's plans. Brain surgery is usually a last option for patients, but when it succeeds, it's very rewarding. From 10 am to 1 pm, I have an out-patients' clinic where I explain the operations. I enjoy talking to patients, but time pressure can make it hard to comfort them if they get upset. I leave work between 6 pm and 8 pm. Some nights and weekends, I'm on call and always carry my pager. On holidays, I worry for the first few days about my patients, and I often dream about operating. I find it hard to switch off."

**B. THE SENIOR DESIGNER**

**Name:** Marita  
**Age:** 31  

**MARITA'S DAY**  
"I get up at 7:45 am, leave home by 8:20 am, take the train, and arrive at work by 9:15 am. On Mondays at 10:30 am, we have a meeting to discuss our projects and any issues. My team includes three senior designers, a company partner, and a junior designer. Only 10-15% of the work is design; the rest is production. I get a brief from the client, and then spend three to four weeks designing and developing the project. After presenting my ideas to the client and getting approval, we set budgets and I start hiring photographers and illustrators. I coordinate with printers to ensure everything is on track. Managing people is a big part of my job, and clear communication is essential. I assemble everything and send it to the printers. Juggling multiple projects can be very stressful, with deadlines always approaching. Lunch is at 1 pm for an hour, and we try to go out. If not, I have sandwiches and work through. It's great when a client likes your work, but disappointing if it's rejected. I get home at 7:30 pm at the earliest, often later. It's hard to relax when I'm busy."

**C. THE CHAUFFEUR**

**Name:** Linda  
**Age:** 42  

**LINDA'S DAY**  
"I usually get up at 7 am, but two or three times a week, I meet early flights and get up between 4:30 am and 5 am. Around 10:30 or 11 am, I might go for a bike ride or swim. Since driving is a sedentary job, I watch my diet and exercise. I have a big breakfast and snack during the day. People often ask for restaurant or shop recommendations, so I need to know the area well. Many jobs are pre-booked, so I can plan routes in advance. Not everyone is polite; some passengers are rude, but most are well-behaved, and I have good relationships with regular clients. Sometimes I overhear conversations and have to focus on driving. The press has tried to get me to talk about clients, but I don't. I work seven days a week, up to fifteen hours a day, and try not to get too tired. I aim to be in bed by 11 pm."

**D. THE LANDSCAPE GARDENER**

**Name:** Tracy  
**Age:** 27  

**TRACY'S DAY**  
"I get up at 7 am, leave by 7:30 am, and start my first job. My assistant and I mostly maintain gardens we designed. We do some commercial work, but mostly private gardens, spending about an hour and a half at each. By 11 am, we're hungry and go to a cafe for breakfast. I often wish time would slow down. In summer, I may work until 10 pm; in winter, until 4:30 pm. The business office is at home, so I check messages and return calls when I get back. If someone wants their garden landscaped, I arrange an evening consultation. We use old materials to make gardens look aged, but sometimes clients have specific ideas that aren't great. It's satisfying to see a garden completed and blooming. It's hard to relax in the evenings because I can hear the business phone. I sleep well because the work is so physical. I'm not very strong, but I'm fit. It's a tough job, but it allows creativity."

**E. THE CIVIL ENGINEER**

**Name:** Zena  
**Age:** 27  

**ZENA'S DAY**  
"I arrive at the site by 8:30 am. I'm the assistant resident engineer, overseeing the building of bridges and a retaining wall. I ensure contractors follow the schedule and safety standards with minimal environmental impact. I coordinate site professionals and solve problems. Contractors start at 6 am, so I first check with the clerk of works about what's happened since I left. My day depends on this information. I review paperwork and answer design questions. Lunch is usually half an hour between 2 pm and 2:30 pm, but I often eat on the go. It's easier to check the site when contractors are on break. Our relationship with contractors must be open to avoid conflicts. I see the duty resident engineer daily, but act immediately if something urgent arises. I usually leave the site around 6 pm and am always on call."

**Careers: Six People Talk About Their Typical Working Day**

**A. Credit Card Executive**

I wake up at 6 am and get to the office by 7.30 am. I handle customer development programs for our regular credit card users. My job includes launching and managing the Membership Rewards scheme in major European markets. I keep in touch with current card users, find new ones, and build relationships with partner companies. I spend the first 45 minutes organizing my day and then reply to emails. I manage all advertising for the membership program across Europe, so I meet with our marketing team and advertising agencies to plan strategies and future developments. I have meetings most of the day, but I keep my door open for questions. There are nine customer service units in Europe, and I travel to different markets once or twice a week to discuss issues. When I'm in London, I leave work between 6.30 pm and 7.00 pm.

**B. Record Company Executive**

I start work at 10.00 am and go through the mail, which includes 10 to 20 demo tapes, letters from producers, concert information, and invoices. The phone starts ringing at 10.30 am with calls from producers and publishers. I have meetings throughout the day about campaigns or projects for artists, involving the press, marketing, and the managing director. When I listen to demo tapes, I try to be constructive because it's important to the artists. I know if the sound fits our label. After signing a band, we work on the first album, choosing songs, producers, and musicians. I share my vision of the album with the company for marketing and sales. I also manage budgets and spending. I leave work at 7.00 pm at the earliest and often go to gigs, sometimes seeing up to five new groups a night. After gigs, I might visit an artist in the studio. My social life is mostly work-related, and I often get home at 1.00 am, when I listen to a record to relax.

**C. Sales Director**

I get up at 8.00 am and drive to work, arriving at 9.30 am. I open the mail, check the diary for client visits, and wait to see who comes in. I enjoy showing people around the showrooms and making sales, knowing the furniture is going to a good home. We sell antiques from £1,000 to £6,000 and buy from London salerooms, country house sales, private clients, and overseas. Many items need restoration, so I work with gilders, picture framers, and paper repairers. I read the Antiques Trade Gazette while having coffee to stay updated on the business, and I visit the Victoria and Albert Museum to compare furniture. I do the accounts monthly and tax returns every three months. I go home at 5.30 pm, and it takes about an hour to unwind.

**D. Air Traffic Controller**

I work a set shift pattern, leaving home at 6.00 am for an early shift. At 7.00 am, I take over from the night shift at one of the four control positions in the tower. We rotate stations, working for about an hour and a half, then taking a half-hour break before switching stations. The team includes air traffic controllers, a supervisor, and a watch manager, and we work together to control aircraft movements. In winter, we handle about 1,000 movements a day, and even more in summer. Night shifts are quieter, allowing me to read up on new air traffic requirements between 12 and 4.00 am. It's crucial to be alert in this job, so I don't hesitate to call in sick if I'm unwell. The work is stressful, and it takes time to relax after a shift. I hope to become a watch manager and eventually a general manager of the airport.

**E. Shop Manager**

If I'm on an early shift, I leave home by 8.00 am. I start by setting up the electronic point-of-sale system. I ensure someone is at the till and coordinate staff lunches and breaks. I spend the morning helping customers and ordering books for them. I enjoy serving customers, though it can be frustrating when they expect me to gather a pile of books based on reviews. Between 2.00 pm and 4.00 pm, publishers' reps visit the shop, and I discuss new titles for the coming months. I decide how many copies of a title the shop might sell. When featuring a new title, I ensure it's delivered on time. The early shift ends at 5.45 pm. I work late shifts twice a week, closing the computer system, locking up, and going home.

**F. Financial Analyst**

I listen to the news at 7.00 am, then get up and take a taxi to work, arriving at 8.45 am. I contact our freelance reporters to learn about events in my region. I assess financial risks for multinational companies abroad, warning clients of potential issues. I provide three services: an online executive preview, a security forecast, and a travel information security guide. From 9.15 am to 9.30 am, I meet with editors to discuss stories. My first executive preview is due online by 10.00 am, and the second by 11.00 am, so I quickly gather stories. I type them, send them to my editor for approval, then make any changes before they go online. I travel to Africa about three times a year to report on events or stay updated. I leave work around 6.00 pm. It's hard to switch off, and I'm often awake at 1.00 am.

**Career Power: Take Control at Work**

**A. What Makes a Good Leader?**

A good leader inspires others and brings about change. Leadership isn't about physical traits like height or just intelligence. Pat Dixon, author of "Making the Difference: Women and Men in the Workplace," says leadership is about "making things happen through people who are as enthusiastic and interested as you are." Enthusiasm is crucial, and a good leader should speak clearly and confidently. Dixon says it's about having the confidence to say "I believe" instead of "I think."

**B. Discovering Leadership Potential**

John van Maurik, director of a Leadership in Management course, believes most people have more leadership potential than they realize. Becoming a leader involves recognizing and developing these hidden talents. We all have the potential to be leaders; we just need the right environment. While it's easy to see leadership in famous figures like Emmeline Pankhurst or Mahatma Gandhi, it can be harder to see it in our own workplaces. Yet, leadership is essential for effective management.

**C. Reflecting on Leadership Styles**

Think about the best and worst bosses you've had. They might have been equally good at setting goals and meeting deadlines. But how did they achieve these? The best leader motivated and supported you. The worst made you feel unimportant and withheld information, blaming you when things went wrong. The first led well; the second managed poorly.

**D. Leaders vs. Managers**

Leaders and managers are different. Managers work within set boundaries, while leaders create new paths. Michael Shea, author of "Leadership Rules," writes that a good manager can keep a company running, but a good leader can transform a struggling organization, whether it's a company, a sports team, or a nation.

**E. Improving Your Leadership Skills**

Whether you're a boss or a middle manager, you can improve your leadership skills. Here are some lessons:

- Leadership is best when chosen. Find your passions and act on them when you feel inspired.
- Think of yourself as a leader. Recognize your ability to lead.
- While collaboration is good, sometimes firm leadership is needed. Try different styles and see how outcomes change.
- Set goals and exceed them. Identify areas in your job where leadership can enhance your effectiveness and career.

**F. Developing Leadership**

- Leadership develops from taking the lead, taking risks, and learning from mistakes. Learn to delegate, motivate, organize, and praise.
- Your leadership style might not immediately win over colleagues. Keep improving your communication skills. You don't need to be liked, but your ideas and achievements should be.
- Be visible and accessible to those who matter. Remember, you don't have to lead all the time. Know where your contribution is vital and help others develop as leaders.

**Films on Video: Reviews by Nick James**

**A. Abyss**  
Before Titanic, director James Cameron made this intense Cold War thriller about oil rig workers and navy experts trying to save a nuclear submarine deep underwater. The foreman Bud and his team remind us of the cool heroes in Howard Hawks' movies. The production design and special effects are very impressive, but the dialogue and characters are not as strong. Despite the skilled filmmaking, the story feels like a B-movie.

**B. The Thin Red Line**  
This video release of the James Jones novel about the battle for Guadalcanal, directed by Andrew Marton, is interesting compared to Terrence Malick's new film. While Malick's version is mystical and poetic, Marton's is a more traditional war movie, often closer to the book. It focuses on one soldier and his tough sergeant. Malick's film is richer and more complex, but Marton's has its highlights. The flashback of the soldier dreaming of his wife is more intense than Malick's softer imagery.

**C. On Guard**  
Loosely based on Paul Feval's 1875 novel, this entertaining swashbuckler is better than most musketeer adventures. Fabrice Luchini plays a great villain, a sneaky politician causing chaos. Vincent Perez is a lively hero, though his role is short, and Daniel Auteuil, while a bit too serious, shines as an acrobat-turned-swordsman. The film uses costume-drama clichés with such wit and energy that it remains enjoyable.

**D. Character**  
A visually striking but gloomy story set in early 1900s Rotterdam. The detailed production and costumes make the film look like a museum piece. Jan Decleir is very serious as the harsh bailiff Dreverhaven, who is ruthless when evicting tenants. The tense relationship with his son is central to the story, but the filmmakers focus too much on period details, missing the dark and intense nature of the tale.

**E. The Good, the Bad and the Ugly**  
This digitally re-mastered video highlights director Leone's skill. The sound editing is excellent, making every sound clear. The story is harsh, and whenever it slows down, Morricone's great music brings excitement. Morally, there's little difference between the good (Clint Eastwood), the bad (Lee van Cleef), and the ugly (Eli Wallach), as they all act ruthlessly in the post-Civil War West.

**F. The Longest Day**  
This three-hour war epic, boasting "forty-eight international stars," is directed by four directors and features 23,000 extras. The early scenes, where soldiers wait for the invasion, feel long for both them and the audience. Logistically impressive, it needs a big screen to be fully appreciated. On video, it loses some of its impact.

**BOOK A**  
Steve Martin's *Compelling Evidence* is truly engaging. The story follows a lawyer trying to start a new practice after leaving a big law firm. He ends up defending his boss's wife, who is accused of murdering her husband. The trial scenes are exciting, with the outcome uncertain until the end, and there's a surprising twist in the final pages. This is a great debut in a busy genre.

**BOOK B**  
*Curtains for the Cardinal* starts with excitement and throws Sigismondo, a problem-solver for the Italian Renaissance aristocracy, into a mix of politics, church intrigue, and murder. We are confident he will solve the mystery. The plot is complex and the book is a bit long, but it's still very enjoyable.

**BOOK C**  
*File Under: Deceased* introduces a new detective, Leah Hunter, created by first-time author Sarah Lacey. Leah is a tax inspector who starts investigating when a strange man dies at her feet. Despite facing challenges and the disapproval of a local detective sergeant, Leah is determined and successful.

**BOOK D**  
In *Double Deuce* by Robert B. Parker, private investigator Spenser helps his friend Hawk clear drug dealers from a poor area in Boston. The dialogue is quick and clever, with more philosophy than violence. As always, Parker delivers high-quality entertainment.

**BOOK E**  
*False Prophet* by Faye Kellermann features detectives Pete Decker and Marge Dunn. They investigate an attack and burglary at the home of a famous film star's daughter. The author's easy writing style and insight into human behavior make this an entertaining mystery.

**BOOK F**  
*Blood Red, Snow White* is written by Diane Henry and Nicholas Horrock. It features a lawyer and a female client, but the action happens outside the courtroom. The lawyer becomes a victim as the plot unfolds. The story mixes romance, money, and violence to create a gripping suspense novel.

**BOOK G**  
*Dead for a Ducat* by Simon Shaw features actor Philip Fletcher as a potential victim. A funny group of characters gathers to film a Robin Hood story, but Philip feels this isn't the right direction for his career. While entertaining, this book doesn't meet Shaw's usual high standards.

**BOOK H**  
*Fall Down Easy* is Lawrence Gough's best book in a while. Canadian police chase a clever bank robber who targets female bank tellers. The slow, well-paced build-up of tension and the portrayal of the smart, troubled robber make this a standout detective novel.

Text: "I might be too old for this adventure, but here goes! At 34, Tim Pozzi has left a good job to go backpacking. He thinks about why he and others his age decide to take this big step. This summer, I quit my job, decided to rent out my apartment, and travel in Southeast Asia for a year. You might think I'm lucky, but I'm 34 years old, and I'm nervous. It's not like I haven't traveled before. After university, I spent two years backpacking around North and South America, and when I returned, I was determined to do it again someday. But you know how it is... I fell in love, started a career, bought an apartment, and got used to earning a salary. But I slowly realized I was giving up my own happiness for my salary. When I handed in my resignation letter, it felt like I was taking control of my life again. I now have no ties. Many of my friends are married with children, and while they wouldn't trade places with me, they envy my lack of responsibilities. I'm no longer in a relationship, and I have no strong career ambitions. I feel almost obliged to make the most of that freedom - if only for my friends' sake! Why am I so nervous? First, it's about making the necessary arrangements. How could I let someone else live in my home? And how would I organize the rental? And besides, I had to decide where to go. I'm a terrible procrastinator and am already several weeks behind my planned schedule. 'Might as well enjoy the summer in England,' I told myself. Then, 'Why not stay for the start of the football season?' Cutting emotional ties makes it even harder. I'm delaying because, deep down, I wonder if I can still handle backpacking. Will I be able to adjust to a simpler way of life? Will I feel out of place among young backpackers fresh out of school and university? Maybe not. I've found it's becoming more common for Britons in their late twenties and thirties to want to leave the lives they've built and travel to foreign places. Jennifer Cox, from Lonely Planet guidebook publishers, says there's a growing awareness that adventure is there for the taking: 'People are realizing they can have the opportunity anytime they want. They just need to be brave, organized, and confident enough to do it.' For Danny, a 30-year-old accountant, and his girlfriend Tammy, a 28-year-old teacher, it's a chance to have one last adventure before settling down. They have bought a round-the-world ticket for a year. 'I'm ready to give up job security for the trip,' says Danny. 'There's always a thought in your mind that, "OK, I'm not moving up the career ladder, I'll be in the same position when I come back," but I think it's a risk you have to take. When I left the office, I threw my calculator into the river as a symbolic act of defiance!' For Matt, who just left the Army, the year he spent traveling was a time of change. 'In the military, there's a set way of doing things, a pattern to how you solve problems. I went away because I needed to change this and get rid of this approach in some cases, to have a reasonable life as a civilian.' While there are many reasons to go traveling at my age, there seem to be common factors. 'We have a much more flexible workforce today,' says Angela Baron of the Institute of Personnel Development. 'There are more people working on short-term contracts, so if your contract ends, you've got nothing to lose.' Larger companies are even adopting career-break policies. 'If you've spent a lot of time and money training someone, it's nice to know they're coming back at some point rather than going to work for a competitor.' For Dan Hiscocks, managing director of Travellerseye, a publishing company that specializes in the stories of 'ordinary' travelers, more people in their thirties are rethinking their lives. 'If you're not happy with what you're doing - and many people aren't - it's no longer about just sticking with it. Now people know that opportunities exist and that a job isn't "for life" anymore. Travel offers a chance to reassess, to step back and think about your life.' Is giving in to wanderlust just another example of my generation's struggle with adulthood? Jennifer Cox thinks not. 'It's a sign of a better-educated, more stable society when we're less worried about paying the bills and more about living a balanced life. We're actually taking the time to ask "Is this what I want?" Ben, a 32-year-old picture researcher heading to Central America for a year, doesn't believe he's running away. 'It's more about running towards something. It's trying to grab some things that I want for myself.' But he does feel some fear. 'It's the thought of what I'm leaving behind, that comfortable routine - just going into the office every day, saying "hi" to everyone, and sitting down with a cup of coffee.' I share Ben's worries about leaving behind an ordered life with few challenges, and I'm not sure I'd be making this journey if I hadn't found my boss so unbearable. As Jennifer Cox points out: 'This is fairly typical. There's often a catalyst, like the end of a relationship or the loss of a job. Such an event can push people to go and do it.' It may have taken a helpful push to get me moving, but I'm now looking forward to the next 12 months with growing excitement. Whatever happens, I'll be able to take satisfaction in having taken control of my life. And in that, I'm sure I speak for all of us older backpackers."

**Plugging in the Home**

Georgina McGuiness had taken a long break from her journalism career and felt disconnected from the technological changes. She shares how she turned her family home into an efficient workplace.

The Christmas before last, I turned 37 and realized I needed to restart my journalism career, which I thought was lost due to technology. My resume showed I was stuck in the 1980s, when typewriters were the latest technology. It seemed unlikely anyone would hire me to use a computer in a newsroom. Many job ads asked for desktop publishing experience, which I didn't have. I felt more likely to teach nuclear physics than to design a page on a computer. I was the family technophobe; even pocket calculators confused me, and I couldn't use the video timer. Clearly, I needed to act quickly to save my career.

I thought leaving home before the children did would be difficult until I entered a competition in a local newspaper. Like a success story that only happens to others, my family and I won a computer package. We received a laptop for my husband and a personal computer for the family. We quickly adapted to this new world, and terms like cyberspace, Internet, and surfing became part of our vocabulary. We started chatting with strangers worldwide via the Internet. The children stopped watching TV, and I set up a mini-office in the kitchen with a phone-answering machine, a fax, a CD-ROM, and a modem connecting me to the Internet. I had everything I needed to work from home and still take the children to school.

The children were confident with computers from school, but I was hesitant, worried I would lose my work by pressing the wrong button. I was wrong. Although not an expert, I learned the basic skills I needed. It was logical, easy, and foolproof. With perseverance, you learn a little more each day. I recently started freelancing for a magazine, writing about two articles a month, and I feel proud to have the best of both worlds.

How has the computer helped me? Since school, my desk was always a chaotic mess, and I often lost important notes. The computer has made me organized, especially with office tasks. Spreadsheets help track income and expenses, and pre-formatted invoices and letterheads save time and effort. For a journalist, being online means I can research stories, ask for more information in journalism forums, and discuss working from home with people worldwide.

If this sounds too good to be true, there are downsides to working from home. You can feel isolated from people. There are distractions from urgent house chores, and when the children are home, we argue over who gets to use the computer. However, more people are buying multimedia PCs, not just for education, leisure, and entertainment. In my street, a new type of home-based industry is growing because people don't have to commute to the city daily.

So, what characterizes home workers as we move into the next century? A report called "PC Usage in UK Homes" describes the typical computer user as 38 years old and well-educated; 93% own a personal computer, and 32% have a CD-ROM device; 38% have a laser printer, and 50% have a modem. Considering this, I seem to be ahead of schedule. Who knows, one day I might email a column to a newspaper in Melbourne or, better yet, publish my own magazine from home. It seems the sky, or should I say cyberspace, is the limit.

**The Tartan Museum**

The modern buildings of Scotland's national museum stand out in historic Edinburgh. But are its contents as impressive? Sally Varlow visited just before it opened.

You can't miss it. The Museum of Scotland is noticeable on Chambers Street in Edinburgh, with its large, yellow sandstone tower and unique buildings, topped by a hanging garden. Last winter, the building received mixed reactions: some praised it as a 'masterpiece', others were cautious, and some disliked it. Now, as the museum prepares to open, the exhibitions might receive similar reactions.

The museum tells Scotland's story through various historic objects, with a timeline to guide visitors. It showcases national treasures like Mary Queen of Scots' jewels without overwhelming them with national pride. The main question is whether people will find the museum interesting enough to return.

Dr. David Clarke, head of exhibitions, wants the museum to be enjoyable for everyone, not just experts. He avoids using imaginative recreations of the past, believing the public deserves the truth. The museum shows what experts know, but the challenge is to make the objects' stories engaging with explanation panels, captions, and limited multimedia.

Inside, the museum's spaces are impressive. Galleries connect in different sizes and shapes, with pale walls and deep display cases. Daylight streams through windows, creating a pleasant atmosphere to explore each item.

Thanks to a Junior board of 9- to 12-year-olds from across Scotland, the museum has a Discovery Centre for children. Although they couldn't ride through the displays, they have a hands-on center instead. The Twentieth Century gallery, on the top floor, is the only temporary exhibition. It features objects chosen by Scottish people and others that impacted life in Scotland during the twentieth century, like an electric guitar and televisions. While the idea is fun, it might seem less serious until the computerised bank of personal stories is available next week.

Overall, Dr. Clarke believes that 'objects open windows on the past more vividly than anything else'. The modern architecture works well inside, but whether it fits the location is another question.

Text: 'The end of print may take some time Peter Preston Transition. It's a nice word and a calming idea. Change can scare some people and challenge others. But transition means moving smoothly from the present to the future. Unless, that is, it is newspapers' 'transition' to the online world, which is uncertain and uncomfortable - because it might not be a process at all. But surely (you say) it will happen eventually. Everyone knows that print newspaper sales are dropping while visits to their websites are increasing. Just look at the latest print circulation numbers. The Daily Telegraph, The Guardian, and many others are down between 8% and 10% year-on-year, but their websites are growing. This might be true, depending on timing, age groups, location, and more. After all, everyone - from web experts to print analysts - says so. Yet pause for a moment and notice a few things that don't quite fit. If sales in that area have fallen so little, maybe the crisis mostly affects newspapers? Yet again, the messages are mixed. The latest survey by the World Association of Newspapers shows that global circulation rose 1.1% last year (to 512 million copies a day). Sales in the West dropped, but Asia more than made up the difference. As for news and current affairs magazines - which you'd expect to be hit hard by digital - they had a 5.4% increase. In short, on both sides of the Atlantic, although some magazine areas went down, many showed rapid growth. You can see a similar trend with books. Kindle and similar e-readers are booming, with sales up a lot this year. The first step of transition seems clear. Yet, when booksellers looked at the value of the physical books they sold over the last six months, they found it just 0.4% down. Screen or paper, then? It wasn't one or the other: it was both. Stories about young people abandoning newspaper-reading are exaggerated. Look at the latest National Readership Survey figures and you'll find nearly 5,000,000 people aged between 15 and 35 reading the main national dailies. And even within Europe, different countries have different stories. There's Britain, with a 10.8% drop in recent years (and a 19.6% fall for quality papers), but in Germany, the decline has only been 7% overall - with just 0.8% lost to quality titles. And France shows only a 3.1% fall (0.8% at the quality end of the market). These different national trends may show a situation more complicated than digital revolution experts think. America's media analysts used to say that growing online advertising revenues would pay for change and, along with lower production costs, make online newspapers a success. But now, with digital ads on newspaper sites actually dropping, such ideas seem outdated. Already 360 US papers - including most of the biggest and best - have built paywalls around their products. However, the best way to attract paying readers seems to be a deal that offers the print copy and digital access together. In other words, print is also important in selling internet subscriptions. And its advertising rates bring in nine to ten times more money than online. Of course, this big difference isn't good news for newspaper companies, as maintaining both an active website and an active print edition is difficult, complex, and expensive. But newspaper brands still have much of their high profile in print; on the web, just being noticed is much harder.'

**Photographing People**

People are the most interesting subjects to photograph. A photo with a person in it is usually more engaging than one without. However, photographing people well is challenging. Besides technical and artistic aspects, photographers must pay attention to actions, gestures, and expressions. Sometimes, the camera can make people act unnaturally.

**A. GROUPING PEOPLE**

Avoid straight lines in group photos. Ask people to stand at different angles and distances, or on different levels. You can also have some people sitting or kneeling in front so all faces are visible, or raise your viewpoint.

**B. POSING FOR PICTURES**

People often act unnaturally in front of a camera. They might become stiff. Help them relax by suggesting they find a comfortable position, like folding their hands or putting them in their pockets.

**C. THE RIGHT APPROACH**

Don't pretend you are not taking a picture when you clearly are, as this can create tension. Most people will agree to be photographed, though they might protest at first. They may become self-conscious, so you might need to guide them. A photo can be ruined if the subject looks aimlessly out of the frame.

**D. EYE CONTACT**

A photo has more impact if the subject looks at the viewer. Ask them to look into the lens, but not necessarily to smile. They might not be able to do this for long, so remind them just before you take the picture. You can also say something funny to get a genuine reaction.

**E. CANDID CONCENTRATION**

Instead of direct eye contact, the subject can focus on something within the picture. This might be easier for them, and the viewer can follow their gaze. Candid shots are fascinating, and the subject's expression is important.

**F. EXPRESSIONS AND GESTURES**

Expressions and gestures reveal a lot about the subject. A laughing child can make the viewer smile, while a sad expression can evoke sympathy. Look for familiar expressions like shrugs, winks, or thumbs-up. They are a universal visual language.

**G. SITUATION INTEREST**

While close-up shots have impact, the background can add interest and information. When using a background, exclude irrelevant details or blur them. Ensure the subject is not overshadowed by the background. A wide-angle lens can make the subject appear larger compared to the background.

**H. INTERACTION**

When people are interacting, there are opportunities for great photos. Couples, mothers and babies, or teams working together make appealing shots. Look for eye contact or physical contact, like a handshake. Capture reactions with animated expressions or gestures.

**I. PEOPLE AND PLACES**

Many photos of people are taken on holiday to show the places they visit. To improve these photos, use a standard or wide-angle lens and step back to include the whole scene. Ask your subjects to come close to the camera, forming a foreground without blocking the background. An elevated camera position can help. A good photo balances the subjects and the place, so both are equally interesting.

**J. TO POSE OR NOT TO POSE?**

Decide why you want to take the picture. If it's to remember someone you met briefly, ask them to pose against a nice background. Family photos can be boring if they are all formal poses. Candid shots of events are more lively, especially when you know the subject well. A spontaneous picture can bring back memories better than a posed one.

**Under Sarah's Spell**

Sarah Janson is a trompe-l'oeil artist. Her paintings trick the eye by creating the illusion of reality. In this interview with Joanna Watt, we learn more about her. Unlike most artists, Sarah doesn't sign her work unless asked. She believes the work is more important than the artist. Sarah is very modest and almost makes it seem like her paintings create themselves. This attitude makes her a challenging interview subject. She admits, "I just don't like to talk about myself," and is embarrassed when asked to be photographed.

Later, in her living room, which is a beautiful space in a block of artists' studios in London, the interview becomes lively and fun. Sarah has been a trompe-l'oeil artist for sixteen years. She studied drawing for two years at art school, earned a degree in graphic illustration, and worked at a publishing house. However, illustration didn't satisfy her, so she joined a specialist decorator, Jim Smart. He asked her to create a trompe-l'oeil piece, and she was hooked. She left to start her own business, feeling she was on the right path.

Sarah's skills in observation and detail, developed through illustration, are crucial for trompe-l'oeil. She says, "People often ask me where they can learn trompe-l'oeil. But no one can teach you. It's all about observation." She insists she is still learning and believes that thinking you've mastered a field means it's time to quit. She is honest about her weaknesses, like her struggle to paint bread, which she says looks like grey concrete. She also admits to difficulties with math, especially when working on a large project like the domed chapel ceiling at Lulworth Castle.

Sarah often talks about her work in the third person, saying things like, "When I finished that ceiling, I thought, 'Well, I didn't do it, she did.'" Her trompe-l'oeil work is exceptional, far above others who have tried to imitate the style. She has completed many major corporate and private commissions. Her work is often inspired by architecture, like a dining room based on a Venetian palazzo or a painting that makes a corridor look like it leads to more rooms.

Trompe-l'oeil must do two things: trick the viewer and engage their imagination. Sarah believes it should also be personal to the client. She enjoys working with clients, saying, "That's where the ideas are born." Some clients have clear ideas, while others do not, so she listens carefully to understand their imagination. Many clients become friends because she spends so much time with them during projects. Sarah appreciates her clients, especially the adventurous ones who trust her with their walls.

Despite her modesty, Sarah is always busy. She repeats, "I really don't like to talk about myself. Like my work, I am very restrained. I don't want it to shout." While she may not like to boast, her work deserves recognition.

**Emotional Intelligence - The Key to Success**

Daniel Goleman explores the 'people skills' that are crucial for success in your career.

**A** The way we are evaluated at work is changing. We are not only judged by our intelligence or skills but also by how we manage ourselves and interact with others. This new way of judging is important for deciding who gets hired or promoted. It helps identify who might excel and who might not. These skills are important for future job opportunities, regardless of the field. They are different from what we learned in school, where exams were the focus. Now, it is assumed that we have the necessary intelligence and technical skills. The focus is on social skills and personal qualities like initiative, empathy, adaptability, and persuasiveness. These are known as emotional intelligence.

**B** In today's world, job security is uncertain, and the idea of a 'job' is changing to 'portable skills'. Personal qualities are becoming more important at work. These have been called 'character', 'personality', or 'soft skills' in the past. Now, they are better understood and called 'emotional intelligence'. This means being aware of and managing our own and others' emotions to guide our actions. At work, it includes self-awareness, self-regulation, motivation, empathy, and social skills. Emotional intelligence is not just about 'being nice'. Sometimes it means being honest, even if it's uncomfortable. It also doesn't mean expressing all feelings freely. It means managing emotions so they are expressed appropriately, helping people work together towards a common goal.

**C** More businesses are recognizing that emotional intelligence is important for management. The more complex the job, the more emotional intelligence matters. A lack of these skills can limit the use of technical skills or intelligence. Some people succeed despite weaknesses in emotional intelligence, but as work becomes more complex and team-oriented, companies that foster good teamwork have an advantage. In today's workplace, with a focus on teamwork and customer service, emotional intelligence is essential for success in any job worldwide.

**D** Unlike IQ, which changes little, emotional intelligence can grow as we learn from life experiences. Studies show that people often become better at managing their emotions, motivating themselves, and improving their empathy and social skills over time. This growth in emotional intelligence is often called maturity. Emotional intelligence can be learned, and we can develop these skills to help us succeed, especially when job stability is uncertain. While emotional intelligence is not a magic solution for struggling organizations, ignoring it can prevent other efforts from being as effective as they could be.

Text: 'Should the media make money from content they don't own? Digital cameras and camera phones have made it easier to capture important events, but social media has changed citizen photography even more. News often breaks on social networks, so some journalists now use them to find images during fast-moving events. Unfortunately, some reporters have used user-generated content (UGC) without asking for permission. Even though there is official advice that images on social media can be used without permission in special cases or if there is a strong public interest, there is still a debate about whether this is right. Research shows that about one in ten people would film or photograph a news event, showing that UGC is important for the future of the media. However, to keep a good relationship with the public, the media must make sure people are properly rewarded for their work and always ask for permission.'

**Ancient Chinese Medicine in the West: Acupuncture**

Acupuncture is a practice that is 2,000 years old. It is part of traditional Chinese medicine, which also includes herbal remedies, massage, diet, and exercise. Acupuncture is used to treat many conditions, but it is most known in the West for helping with pain. Some general practitioners, midwives, and physiotherapists use it regularly for pain relief.

**A. What is Acupuncture?**

Traditional Chinese medicine believes that health is when the energy of the mind, body, and spirit are balanced. This energy, called Qi (pronounced "chee"), flows through the body along paths called meridians. There are twelve main meridians, each connected to an internal organ, and many smaller ones that carry Qi to every cell. If the flow of Qi is blocked or weak, the body is out of balance, leading to weakness or illness. A traditional acupuncturist will try to find where the Qi is imbalanced by feeling your wrist pulses, looking at your tongue, and assessing your overall appearance. They will also ask about your medical history, current health, and lifestyle. Acupuncture involves inserting fine needles into the skin, sometimes with added warmth or pressure, to stimulate the flow of Qi.

**B. Over Three Hundred Points**

The points used in acupuncture are related to meridians and may not be near the area of pain. People often feel a dull ache or tingling when the needle is moved. This can be done by hand or with an electro-acupuncture machine. Acupuncturists say this feeling shows the needle has reached the Qi. There are over 300 points on the main meridians, with many more used less often.

**C. Scientific Explanations**

Even without accepting traditional Chinese medicine principles, Western doctors recognize that acupuncture can relieve pain. Scientific explanations include:
- Stimulating certain nerves may block pain signals from reaching the brain.
- Acupuncture might release natural pain-relieving substances called endorphins.

**D. Types of Pain Treated**

Many people with chronic pain try acupuncture as a last resort. It is commonly used for back pain, sports injuries, arthritis, headaches, migraines, and post-surgery pain. Acupuncturists also claim to treat menstrual pain, facial nerve pain, and pain in terminally ill patients.

**E. Modern Use of an Ancient Treatment**

Although acupuncture has been used in China for over 2,000 years, using it instead of anesthesia during surgery began in the 1950s. This convinced some doctors outside China of its effectiveness. In China, acupuncture is used in various surgeries, including heart surgery. It can be used alone, with electrical stimulation, or with drugs. It is said to eliminate pain, but this varies by person. Acupuncture anesthesia has no side effects like nausea, and recovery is quicker.

**F. Effectiveness**

Clinical trials for acupuncture are hard to conduct, but those done show that 50 to 80 percent of people find it effective for chronic pain. Acupuncturists agree with this success rate but acknowledge it doesn't work for everyone. For chronic pain, relief usually takes six to seven visits, with some improvement after two or three visits.

**G. A Different Approach to Pain**

Western and Chinese medicine view pain differently. Acupuncturists see patients holistically, not just focusing on symptoms. They spend time diagnosing, looking for weaknesses in Qi, and considering external factors like weather. These factors help decide how to treat pain with acupuncture, unlike typical medical doctors.

**H. Traditional or Not?**

Some medical professionals have traditional acupuncture training, while others, including many GPs, prefer scientific explanations. Traditional acupuncturists believe only traditional Chinese medicine can lead to deep, lasting changes, which are hard to measure in trials. It's important to choose an acupuncturist carefully, and they should refer you to a doctor if needed.

Text: P.D. James Barbara Michaels meets the famous crime writer, whose innocent look hides a complex and brilliant imagination. Best-selling crime writer P.D. James - the initials stand for Phyllis Dorothy - has a quiet authority. You can imagine her as a headmistress of a girls' school if she hadn't become a creator of detective stories with many twists and turns. But soon, you see that her authoritative look hides her shyness. She admits that Adam Dalgliesh, the detective in her novels, 'is, I suppose, modeled on myself - or rather, the way I would have turned out if I had been a man'. Dalgliesh likes to solve crimes alone, just like his creator. 'I need time on my own, especially when I am writing. I can write almost anywhere as long as I have total privacy.' She is too modest to agree that she is Britain's best-known crime writer, even though her books - 12 major detective novels - are read by millions worldwide. She is a big fan of her close friend Ruth Rendell's works. 'I particularly enjoy her psychological works, written under the name of Barbara Vine.' Books beside her bed are usually by women writers like Iris Murdoch, Anita Brookner, and Penelope Lively, but she also reads male authors like Graham Greene and Evelyn Waugh, whom she thinks were the greatest novelists of their generation. Success came to P.D. James later in life. Now in her seventies, she was 42 when her first crime novel, Cover Her Face, was published. Born in Oxford, the eldest of three children, Phyllis grew up mainly in Cambridge, where her family moved when she was 11 years old. 'I met my husband there - he was a student at the university, and I have always loved the place. That is why I chose it as the setting for An Unsuitable Job For A Woman.' She reluctantly shares that life has been hard, even tragic at times. Her Irish doctor husband, Connor Bantry White, returned from the Second World War, during which he served with the Royal Army Medical Corps, very sick. 'I had to work long hours to support him and our two young daughters, Clare and Jane. The ideas were in my head, but I could do almost nothing about it - I simply didn't have the time. My husband's parents, however, were wonderful, and took my daughters under their wing, giving them a sense of security during those difficult years.' While working full-time in administration for the National Health Service, she used her excellent organizational skills. At one point, five psychiatric outpatient clinics were under her control. Then she spent 11 years at the Home Office, first in the Police Department, doing administration for forensic science research, and then in the Criminal Law section, in the juvenile crime division. It was while working in forensic science that she became 'quite accustomed' to the sight of corpses. But it was not fascination with death itself that inspired her. 'It was, rather, the shape and construction involved in the writing of a crime novel that appealed. I have always enjoyed reading detective stories, and I always knew that I wanted to be a writer.' 'I didn't want to use the traumatic events of my own life in a work of fiction. Writing a detective story appealed as a wonderful training for someone wanting to be a serious novelist, and it was suitably removed from my own experience. As I went on, I became increasingly aware that one could stay within the constraints and indeed within the so-called formula of the classic detective story and still write a good, serious, and revealing novel about human beings. Writing detective stories', she says, 'is a way of bringing order out of disorder. The solution of a crime confirms the sanctity of life - even if that life is unlovable.
