Nobody really likes violence.'

**The Pen is Mightier than the Psychoanalyst**

The study of handwriting to understand a person's character is becoming more popular. In some countries, if you apply for a job, you might be asked for a handwriting sample. This sample could help decide if you are right for the job. Handwriting analysis, or graphology, is seen as a real science in many places. Researchers say it can help identify certain illnesses, like heart disease and cancer, and can show psychological states and emotional issues. Handwriting analysis is being used more for career guidance and during job interviews. Many large companies hire graphologists to study the handwriting of candidates for important positions. However, most doctors and psychiatrists are skeptical about graphology's value.

Patricia Marne, a graphologist with over 20 years of experience, believes that doctors should take it more seriously. She thinks handwriting can show psychological traits and some medical conditions. She says, "Handwriting is a strong indicator of social class and intelligence. It can also assess mental ability and potential, whether a person should focus on arts or sciences, and whether they have a devious or open character."

According to Ms. Marne, graphology can be useful in identifying possible criminal tendencies: "Criminals often have disturbed handwriting, which is mostly illiterate and poorly-shaped. Many criminals come from deprived backgrounds and have arrested emotional development. This often appears in unusually childish handwriting and in going over letters several times."

Ms. Marne can analyze handwriting to determine if people are honest, manipulative, or reliable employees. "Young male offenders often have very high ascenders, showing they live in a world of fantasy and dream of success. Graphologists can tell if violence is about to happen, if the writer is under extreme pressure, and if there are psychopathic tendencies. Handwriting can also predict potential suicides."

Heart and lung problems can also be detected, she says. "You can't diagnose from one sample unless the writing is clearly shaky or disturbed. But if it changes over time or becomes disjointed, or if there's a break in the signature that wasn't there before, it could mean something serious has happened." A severe emotional upset can also show in a temporarily changed signature, she claims.

Ms. Marne says handwriting can reveal other psychological traits. People whose letters form 'threads' instead of being individually formed are, apparently, devious and clever. Those who write mainly in capitals are trying to hide their true selves. Very light pressure indicates sensitivity and lack of energy. Originality in handwriting—how much the writer has deviated from standard script—shows confidence and artistic ability. Disconnected writing is a sign of a loner. Very small signatures indicate inhibition and an inferiority complex; circles over the 'i' are a bid for attention, and crossing the 't' heavily over the whole word shows intolerance and a patronizing attitude.

Ms. Marne says it takes six years of study and experience to analyze handwriting accurately, and this must be combined with empathy and intuition. She believes more research is needed to make graphology a proper science. She thinks this will happen soon. "It's actually more accurate than psychoanalysis because you can tell the whole history of a person, including all their emotional crises, without asking them questions they might answer incorrectly."

Although this sounds interesting, there is little solid evidence to support these claims. Some psychiatrists are very critical. They say handwriting is a result of education, artistic ability, and the type of writing taught, and it has no other significance.

Text: 'Is your office working well? Fresh air and the right chairs are important for a happy, healthy workforce, according to a new survey. We visited four different offices to find out how healthy and happy they were as working environments. Our expert panel included a building health consultant, an ergonomist who studies people's working conditions, and an occupational psychologist. Here are their opinions. Office A. Advertising Agency Building Health Consultant: This office is very simple; no central heating, no mechanical ventilation, windows open directly onto the street. It is hard to see why this space works, but the people, who are part of a small, dynamic team, seem to have few complaints. They adapt to the changing seasons by opening doors and roof panels or using electric heaters, much like they do at home. This might be the key: a team of seven people have created a happy, homely working environment without any external rules. Ergonomist: The furniture here has developed over time; no two pieces match. Much of it actually causes bad working postures. Chairs are old, most aren't adjustable, and many are broken. Although this environment is poor in that way, the staff have a varied work schedule, which they control -- office work, meeting clients, making presentations, and so on. This variety reduces the risk of fatigue, boredom, and muscle problems. Occupational Psychologist: Staff are happy with the variety of work and the flexible office space. They said their office was 'just the right size' -- small enough to know what colleagues are doing, large enough to be alone and focus on personal work. I found the office attractive and fun, showing both efficiency and creativity. Office B. News Service Building Health Consultant: While the office may not be very exciting, it seems comfortable and is not disliked by the staff. The air quality and general maintenance standards seem to be good. This is helped by a No Smoking policy. Ergonomist: I was not surprised to learn that the company had already used the services of an ergonomist. Chairs are excellent, lighting and computer equipment are good. Space is good, although the layout could be improved. But the environment is impersonal and unstimulating, with grey, bare walls. Occupational Psychologist: Walls are bare except for year planners and a poster about maternity rights. Most staff have been there for at least five years, and relationships are satisfactory. The office could be improved if the desks were arranged to make sharing information easier. Success stories or information on upcoming projects could be displayed on the walls. Office C. Bank Building Health Consultant: An office that produces mixed reactions from those working in it. The feeling inside is like being in a glass case, viewed by, and viewing, many similar exhibits. Despite a mix of smokers and non-smokers in a relatively small space, the air did not seem stale. Even standing only 1.5 meters away from a smoker, it was not possible to smell his cigarette. Ergonomist: The office area is, unfortunately, very standard and uninspiring. The desks are adequate, but only just. Not all the chairs used for computer work meet requirements, but this is user choice. Computer screens are often on small desk units with lowered keyboard shelves; this is no longer considered suitable for modern equipment. Occupational Psychologist: Staff are supportive of each other and well served by technology. Many communications awards are on display. The wood-colored paneling and brown carpet give a slightly serious effect. The office is full of activity. Office D. Newspaper Building Health Consultant: It is hard to say anything good about this building. The air-conditioning control is very basic, causing large temperature changes. The space is cluttered, and most people have inadequate desk space. The office is very dusty -- there are many places for dust to settle. The shed-type roof also collects dust, which, if disturbed, falls on those sitting below. Ergonomist: The furniture would be more suitable in a carpentry workshop than in a high-tech industry. Most of the chairs are of little use to keyboard users, especially those shorter than about 1.75 m. Many chairs are old, lack proper adjustment, and have armrests that prevent the user from getting close enough to the desk. Occupational Psychologist: Old brown chairs, dirty carpets, dust, and dirt everywhere. A lot of room for improvement -- the place needs a good clean-up, individual success could be more recognized, air conditioning needs to be improved immediately -- there are many smokers. Few conversations were happening when we visited; everybody seemed stressed and driven by deadlines. The company needs to adopt a policy of team-working.'

Chewing Gum Culture

Chewing gum is popular and classless, with Americans chewing 12 million sticks daily. Learn how this ancient habit became a big business. Each stick of gum has fewer than ten calories, but it is considered a food and must meet the American Food and Drug Administration's standards. Modern gum is mostly synthetic, with added pine resins and softeners to keep the flavor and improve texture. 

In ancient times, Greeks chewed a gum-like resin from the mastic tree, found mainly in Greece and Turkey. Greek women used mastic gum to clean their teeth and freshen their breath. American colonists learned from the Amero-Indians of New England to chew resin from spruce trees. In the early 1800s, spruce gum was sold in the eastern United States, becoming the first commercial chewing gum in the country.

Modern chewing gum began in the late 1860s with the discovery of chicle, a milky substance from the sapodilla tree in Central America. This gum was smoother and more elastic, leading to a new industry. However, attempts to grow sapodilla commercially have failed, so synthetic alternatives were developed as the market grew.

Today, the few remaining chicle gatherers, called chicleros, have a tough and dangerous job. They travel long distances in nearly 100% humidity to tap sapodilla trees. They face poisonous snakes, many insects, and the chicle fly, which lays eggs in their ears and nose. Using only a rope and an axe, an experienced chiclero can climb a tree in minutes to collect the sap. They carry the liquid to a forest camp, where it is boiled into sticky bricks. Life at the camp is hard, with a simple maize-based diet and local alcohol from sugar cane.

Despite these challenges, chicleros worry about their jobs. The U.S. once imported 7,000 tonnes of chicle a year from Central America, but last year only 200 tonnes were tapped in Mexico's Yucatan peninsula. As gum sales have increased, manufacturers use synthetics to cut costs and meet demand.

Gum producers are finding creative ways to market their products. Gum is said to help you relax, boost energy, and reduce tension. Soldiers in both world wars were given gum. Its biggest claim is that it reduces tooth decay. Plaque acid from eating causes decay, but saliva neutralizes the acid and provides minerals like calcium, phosphate, and fluoride. Gum makers say chewing for 20 minutes can increase saliva flow.

Research continues on new textures and flavors. Glycerine and other vegetable oils are used to blend the gum base. Most new flavors are artificial, but some still need natural ingredients. Additionally, 137 square kilometers of America are used to grow mint for the two most popular chewing gums in the world.

**REMOTE HOTELS**

**A. INDIA - GHANERAO HOTEL, RAJASTHAN**  
Ghanerao Hotel is located at the edge of the Aravalli Hills in a small village known for its craftsmen. It combines the calm of an English country house with Indian symbolism. The Ghanerao family has lived here for 400 years, and now Sajjan Singh and his wife welcome guests. The facilities are simple, with hot water provided by bucket, but this simplicity adds to its charm.

**B. NEW ZEALAND - HERMITAGE HOTEL, MOUNT COOK**  
The Hermitage Hotel on New Zealand's South Island is one of my favorite hotels. I discovered it by accident while climbing. After reaching the peak of a glacier, we walked down and found this hotel. It is in a stunningly beautiful and wild area. Arriving tired from the climb and finding luxury, with someone playing Cole Porter on the piano, was amazing.

**C. MAURITIUS - BEACHCOMBER PARADIS HOTEL**  
Located on the south-west of Mauritius, the Paradis Hotel is on its own peninsula in a quiet part of the island. The road to the hotel winds along the coast past empty beaches. The hotel is not small, and many enjoy the free watersports, but you can easily find solitude along nine kilometers of private beach. In the evening, when everyone has left, you can sit on the beach and feel far away from everything.

**D. ST LUCIA - LADERA HOTEL, ST LUCIA**  
The Ladera Hotel in St Lucia is set in one of the Caribbean's most dramatic locations. It is quiet and remote, standing 1,000 feet high, with open rooms offering views between the Pitons to the Caribbean Sea. The style is colonial, with mahogany and greenheart wood furniture, and four-poster beds with muslin netting.

**E. TURKEY - THE SPLENDID HOTEL, ISTANBUL**  
This hotel is on Buyukada in the Princes Islands, a perfect escape from Istanbul's noise. The islands are an hour by boat and are idyllic, with no cars, only horse-drawn carriages and beautiful 1920s wooden architecture. The Splendid is a landmark, all in wood, painted white with red domes, resembling a hotel from the French Riviera. Though a bit run down, it retains its charm.

**F. FRANCE - CHATEAU D'ETOGES, EPERNAY**  
In the small village of Etoges, in the heart of Champagne, is a beautiful 17th-century chateau. Surrounded by a moat with swans, the chateau was a family home until recently. It has 20 unique rooms, some with four-poster beds, and one with a billiard table. There are special weekend rates that include breakfast, dinner, and complimentary champagne.

**G. KENYA - THE FAIRVIEW HOTEL, NAIROBI**  
The Fairview is a rare find in Africa—a comfortable hotel without excessive luxury. It is a key stop for travelers resting from one safari and planning the next. Some guests decide to stay longer after seeing the gardens, rooms, and dining menu. The hotel is on Nairobi Hill, away from the city's hustle. It's a great place to watch the African sunset with a drink and look forward to a hearty dinner.

**H. ITALY - HOTEL SPLENDIDO, PORTOFINO**  
The Duke of Windsor was the first to sign the guest book at Hotel Splendido. Since then, many famous people have visited, like Lauren Bacall and Humphrey Bogart. Today, you might meet a billionaire or heiress. This former monastery-turned-hotel is still splendid, with enough glamour to enhance any weekend. The restaurant offers simple, delicious food, and the hotel features fine Persian rugs and homemade pasta.

**The Hotel Inspector**

Sue Brown works as a hotel inspector. Christopher Middleton observed her during one of her inspections. Just one minute into her annual check at the Globe Hotel, things start to go wrong. The receptionist is busy quoting room rates over the phone and doesn't notice Sue, the real guest, waiting. Sue whispers, "Hasn't even acknowledged us. Very poor." This is a common mistake Sue has seen many times in her 11 years as an inspector. She expects better from the Globe Hotel because it has three red stars, which means it's among the top 130 hotels out of 4,000 in the guide published by her organization.

Even before the cold welcome, Sue noticed problems. The entrance from the car park was through an unmanned door with a buzzer, leading to a long, empty corridor. "Again, not what I had expected," Sue comments. Things get worse when the receptionist says, "We seem to have no record of your booking," even though most rooms are empty that night. Sue's room on the top floor is not to her liking: it's stuffy, and there's a large hole in the wall behind a wardrobe panel.

Sue recalls being known as "The Woman in Black" early in her career for her tough reputation, though she insists she was never too harsh. The next morning, after paying her bill, she reveals her identity to the Globe's general manager, Robin Greaves. He looks terrified. Before she says much, he apologizes for a bad smell in the main lounge, suspecting a blocked drain. Sue suggests fixing the plumbing and guiding guests to another lounge. Greaves, who has been at the Globe for only five months, takes notes and listens to Sue's feedback, hoping it will help the hotel improve.

Not everything is negative. Sue praises Emma, the assistant manager, and Trudy, the waitress, for their good service. Dinner was good enough to keep the hotel's two-rosette food rating. Greaves asks what they need to do to earn three rosettes. Sue suggests, "Not serve a pudding that collapses." Greaves' brief hope fades.

Sue's job is to voice complaints that other guests might not express. She recalls a time when a woman complained that Sue got her son fired because he served apple pie with his fingers. Sue often receives letters with false accusations, but she says it still hurts.

Sue must give her findings verbally and in a written report to the hotelier, who pays for this service. Being in the guide with red stars is valuable for hotels. Greaves is relieved to hear that Sue won't recommend removing the Globe's red stars. However, another inspector will return in two months to check if improvements have been made. "Good," Greaves says, trying to sound positive. "We'll look forward to that."

**Seven Up: Conquering the Seven Summits**

Mountaineer Doug Scott shares his experiences of climbing the highest peak on each continent, known as the Seven Summits. Here is his journey:

**A. Mt. Everest, Asia (8,848m)**
My journey to climb the Seven Summits began with Mt. Everest. My partner, Dougal Haston, and I were in a snow cave near the summit. Dougal started talking to someone who wasn't there, likely due to lack of oxygen. I also found myself talking to my feet, worried about frostbite. Despite the challenges, Dougal's confidence inspired me, and I managed to reach the summit.

**B. Mt. McKinley, North America (6,194m)**
Known as one of the most dangerous mountains, Dougal and I arrived at the Kahiltna Glacier in April 1976. We carried our gear and food on our backs, climbing a new route. The low air pressure made it feel like we were at a higher altitude. After a tough climb, we reached the summit, feeling victorious.

**C. Kilimanjaro, Africa (5,895m)**
In September 1976, Paul Braithwaite and I planned to climb Mt. Kenya but ended up on Kilimanjaro. We got lost in the jungle, struggling to find water. Eventually, we found a trail and reached the summit via the Umbwe route.

**D. Aconcagua, South America (6,960m)**
In January 1992, my wife Sharu and I joined a group climbing via the Polish Glacier. Due to time constraints, we took the standard route instead. We reached the summit just before dark and camped nearby. Meeting other climbers inspired me to consider climbing all Seven Summits.

**E. Vinson Massif, Antarctica (4,897m)**
Climbing Vinson Massif became possible by guiding others to cover costs. In November 1992, our team traveled to Antarctica. Despite harsh weather, we reached the summit in eight hours, though visibility was poor.

**F. Elbrus, Europe (5,633m)**
In summer 1994, our team gathered in St. Petersburg. After acclimatizing, we took a cableway up Elbrus. We thought we reached the summit, only to find another ridge to climb. We returned to the refuge as night fell.

**G. Carstensz Pyramid, Australasia (4,883m)**
On this expedition, we aimed to establish a new route and connect with the local Dani people. Despite warnings of danger, we climbed the mountain. On May 12, we reached the summit, completing my Seven Summits mission.

**Style Merchants**

Style is important in our lives today, from clothes to home decoration and accessories. Jo Foley shares the latest fashion trends for this year.

**Ned Ingham: Dress Designer**

Ned Ingham creates beautiful, romantic wedding dresses. He suggests avoiding traditional, stiff dresses and the 'frilly' look, choosing simpler styles instead. Ingham has been designing wedding dresses since he was a schoolboy. At 16, he went to fashion school to learn how to make clothes. Besides wedding dresses, he designs long evening dresses with modern colors and fabrics. For those who prefer classic styles, he offers a navy-blue suit, a staple in English women's wardrobes for much of the 20th century, but with a modern twist.

**Sally Quail: Jeweller**

Sally Quail, who once worked for an art dealer, has no formal training in jewelry. She started designing when she couldn't find an engagement ring she liked. This led her to become a designer in 1990. Her pieces are popular with many celebrities. Her style features large semi-precious stones set in gold, inspired by 18th-century jewelry. Recently, she started using diamonds. 'It must reflect my age,' says 36-year-old Quail. 'I reached that moment in every woman's life when she wants a diamond, and that's when I began working with them.'

**Lily Grimson: Handbag Designer**

Lily Grimson entered the competitive fashion world four years ago with only a basic course in art and design. Two of her handbag designs have been chosen for a major exhibition. Her bags, whether made from fine calfskin or heavy silk, are always noticed. They are handmade in the UK and combine style and quality, making them special.

**Peter Little: Hairdresser**

For over 20 years, Peter Little has styled the hair of many famous people. 'Most women want natural-looking hair and a style they can manage at home,' he says. His approach is to make sure clients don't look like they just left a salon. However, this natural look is expensive, costing £250 for the first appointment, with a three-month waiting list. Peter has also created his own line of hairdryers and styling tools, so people can style their hair at home.

**Penny Pratt: Florist**

Penny Pratt runs a small shop and is a flower consultant for a large supermarket chain. She also provides floral ideas to top restaurants. She left her teaching job 10 years ago to do something different and has no formal floristry qualifications. Her simple yet modern flower arrangements have won many design awards, helping her start her own London Flower School. She has given successful lectures in Japan and the USA. She advises keeping flower arrangements simple and strong, with not too many leaves. For wedding bouquets, she says the flowers should be of the same species.

**Five-star luxury meets modern technology**

The five-star Merrion Hotel has just opened in Dublin. It took nearly two years to convert four large 18th-century houses into this hotel. This transformation allowed the installation of the latest technology for both staff and guests. General Manager Peter MacCann wants his staff to know guests by name, but he uses the hotel's computer system to remember guests' preferences. This system, which cost £250,000, helps treat returning guests in a special way, as expected in a five-star hotel. MacCann believes it will pay for itself over time. For example, if a guest requests certain music CDs during their first stay, those CDs will be ready for them on their next visit, thanks to the guest-history feature.

Room temperature is a common complaint among hotel guests worldwide. The Merrion has a high-tech system to control this. Guests can adjust the temperature within three degrees of the normal 18°C, and the front desk can set each room between 14°C and 25°C.

Business travelers, who MacCann expects will make up 65% of his clients, will appreciate the technology in the rooms. Each room has three phones, two phone lines, a fax machine that also works as a photocopier and printer, and a video-conferencing facility. The hotel has prepared for future technology changes by installing extra cables and renting TVs, so they can be easily updated. DVD recorders can also be upgraded when needed.

Despite all this technology, MacCann ensures that guests feel comfortable and not overwhelmed. The 145 bedrooms are large, well-furnished, and welcoming. The hotel also offers a swimming pool, gym, six conference rooms, two bars, two restaurants, and a beautiful garden.

The food at the Merrion must be excellent, as expected in luxury hotels. Chef Patrick Guilbaud, whose Dublin restaurant already had two Michelin stars, moved his restaurant to the Merrion. This move benefits both him and the hotel. He designed a new, modern kitchen and enjoys better parking facilities. The hotel gains a popular and successful restaurant without financial risks.

With advanced technology and a skilled staff, the Merrion Hotel is set to succeed.

Artist Susan Shepherd is famous for her flower paintings. Her large garden, full of her favorite flowers like tulips and poppies, provides many of her painting subjects. Some plants grow wildly and spread throughout the garden. The garden has a beautiful mix of colors and shapes, especially in the two long flower borders along the path. This beauty is partly thanks to the previous owners, who were passionate gardeners and left plants that Susan liked. She also kept their gardener, Danny. Susan says, "It was really his garden." They got along well, and he understood her vision when she explained she wanted to paint certain plants.

Susan usually focuses on detailed studies of single plants rather than the whole garden. Sometimes she paints groups of plants where they grow, but often she picks them and takes them to her studio. She explains, "I don't set the whole thing up at once. I take one flower out and paint it, which might take a few days, and then I bring in another one and build up the painting that way. Sometimes it takes a couple of years to finish." Her busiest time is spring and early summer when tulips and poppies bloom. She finds the way flowers change as they decay fascinating. For example, tulips change shape and open up after being put in water, becoming more interesting over time.

Susan has always been interested in plants. She studied botany in school and collected wildflowers. She didn't like garden flowers back then, thinking they looked artificial. She admired how wildflowers could grow in difficult places like rock cracks or cliff tops. Now, her garden includes plants from distant countries, but they fit in well. She has a relaxed approach to gardening, like an aunt who lets children play freely as long as they don't cause harm.

With two upcoming exhibitions and plenty of subjects to paint, Susan finds it hard to spend time gardening. She has hired an extra gardener but believes that to stay connected to her work, "you have to get your hands dirty."

Many trees in the Brackham area were knocked down during the terrible storms in March. The town lost two big lime trees from the old market square. The loss of these trees changed the look of the town center completely, which upset some of the town's more traditional residents. Normally, Chief Inspector Douglas Pelham, the head of the local police, would have been among those upset. However, during the storm, when the wind even knocked down the mature walnut tree in his garden, Pelham was too sick to notice. A usually healthy man, he was seriously ill for the first time with bronchitis. When he first felt a headache and tightness in his chest, his wife, Molly, tried to get him to see a doctor. Believing the police force needed him, he ignored her and kept working. This only made his memory worse and his temper shorter. Finally, his colleague, Sergeant Lloyd, took him to the doctor. By then, he was too weak to argue. Soon, she took him to the pharmacy to get his antibiotics and then home to his wife, who sent him straight to bed. On Thursday morning, when Molly told him the walnut tree had fallen, Pelham couldn't understand it. On Thursday evening, he weakly asked if the house was damaged, was relieved to hear it wasn't, and went back to sleep. It wasn't until Saturday, when the antibiotics started working, his fever went down, and he got up, that he realized the walnut tree's loss had changed the living-room's look. The Pelhams' large house was in a big garden. It was expensive, but Pelham didn't regret buying it. The leafy garden made it feel private. Now, the storm had changed his view. Before, the living-room view included the beautiful walnut tree. It didn't make the room dark because there was another window on the opposite wall, but it created interesting light and shadow patterns that hid the worn furniture the family brought from their old house. With the tree gone, the room was very bright, showing the shabby furniture. The view from the window was also bad. The tall house next door, once hidden by the tree, was now visible, with its ugly purple bricks and outside pipes. It seemed to have many upstairs windows, all watching the Pelhams. 'Doesn't it look terrible?' Pelham said to his wife. But Molly, standing in the doorway, sounded more happy than upset. 'That's what I've been telling you since we moved here. We need to buy a new sofa, no matter the cost.'

**Living in the Valley**

We had been living in our valley for sixteen months when we first realized the dangers in the surrounding hills that could threaten our survival. It was the year when the storms came early, even before November ended. Until then, we felt safe in our valley, protected by the hills. Soon, snow began to fall. Within a day, it was about 15 centimeters deep. It almost blocked our lane and made the path by the stream slippery and dangerous. But on the nearby hills, the snow was much deeper and stayed longer. Up there, the wind blew fiercely. In our valley, we only felt sudden gusts of wind; trees swayed, but the branches held firm. Yet, we knew we had reason to worry. The snow and wind were inconvenient, but they did not trouble us much. It was the river, the Ryburn, which usually flowed gently, that threatened us most. It reminded us of what could have happened if the water from the hills had not been controlled by a series of dams many years ago.

In a short time, the snow started to melt. Day after day, we watched dark clouds gather over the hills to the west. Grey clouds spread over the valleys, warning of what was to come. We had seen enough of the sky; now we began to watch the river, which was becoming fuller and wilder every day. The snow was gradually washed away as more rain fell from the clouds, but high up in the hills, the reservoir was filling and was fast approaching danger level. Then it happened - for the first time in years, the reservoir overflowed. Up in the hills, it was like Niagara Falls, as water surged over the edge of the dam and poured into the stream below. The river seemed wild as the waters rushed down to its lower parts. Just a couple of meters from our cottage, the stream seemed wild beneath the bridge. It was deeper than we'd ever seen it so close to our home, fiercely hitting its banks. For three days, we hoped it would stay below its wall. Fortunately, our hopes were answered as the dam held and the waters began to go down.

In the past, before the dam was built, the river had often flooded the nearby villages in such a rage. Now, the dam controls the river's flow, and usually, all is well; the large amount of water from the hills, from snow and heavy rain, stays behind its barrier with just the occasional overflow. We can now enjoy, rather than fear, the large clouds that hang over the valley, and be amazed by the great power we know the river has. Thanks to this protection, we feel our home in the valley is still secure and safe.

Film Critic Mark Adams reflects on his last ten years working as a film critic for a newspaper called The Front Page. Writing about films for The Front Page was his first real job. Before that, he had done some reviewing—novels for other newspapers, films for a magazine, and anything he was asked to do for the radio. This is how he met Tom Seaton, the first arts editor of The Front Page, who had also written for radio and TV. Tom hired him, but Tom was not mainly a journalist, or he would have been more careful in choosing his staff. 

At first, Tom's idea was to have a team of critics handle art forms that didn't need specialized knowledge: books, TV, theatre, film, and radio. They would have a weekly lunch to choose from the artistic material Tom decided they should cover, with guests to make it sociable. It all felt like a dream then: a new newspaper, and Mark was part of the team. It seemed unlikely that a new paper could succeed in a crowded market. It seemed just as likely that a millionaire wanted to help him personally and was pretending to employ him. Such was his lack of self-confidence. The first time he saw someone reading the newspaper on the London Underground and turning to a page with one of his reviews, he didn't know where to look.

Tom's original plan for a team of critics never happened. It was a good idea, but they didn't meet as planned, so everything was done by phone. It turned out that the public preferred to link a reviewer with one subject area, so Mark chose film. Without Tom's initial push, they wouldn't have the current setup, where Mark writes a long weekly piece, usually on one film. This way of working suits him well. He wouldn't have been interested in the usual film critic's role, which involves reviewing every film that comes out. That routine would make him bored quickly. He would soon be sinking into his seat on a Monday morning with the sigh, 'What boring rubbish must I sit through now?'—a sigh often heard in screening rooms worldwide.

The space he is given allows him to expand his argument—or forces him, in a dull week, to make something out of nothing. But what is his role in the public arena? He assumes people choose films based on the stars, publicity, or director. There is also loyalty to a 'type' or its opposite. It rarely happens that someone who hates westerns buys a ticket for one after reading a review, or a love story fan avoids a romantic film because of what the papers say. So if a film review isn't really a consumer guide, what is it? He doesn't feel he has to be 'right' about a movie. Nor does he think there should be a certain number of 'great' and 'bad' films each year. All he has to do is present an argument. He's not a judge, and he doesn't want to be.

Text: Why would a schoolgirl want to swim 1500m, cycle 40km, and then run 10km? Because "it's fun." Teenager with a love for endurance sports WANTED: Sports-loving training partner for a triathlete, preferably female. Opportunity to train with a potential Olympic champion. Must be very interested in distance running (regular 15km sessions), distance swimming (enjoys winter training in cold rivers), and distance cycling (likes 100km rides). Ability to do all three without resting is essential. The triathlon is becoming one of the most popular Olympic sports. Recently, it has attracted large crowds who are both fascinated and shocked by athletes swimming 1500m, cycling 40km, and then running 10km without stopping. It might be exciting for spectators, but what makes triathletes want to push their bodies so hard? And why would a 17-year-old girl with excellent academic results give up everything for the challenging experiences it offers? Melanie Sears has not yet learned the usual phrases about personal satisfaction, mental challenge, and higher goals that most athletes use when asked similar questions. "You swim for 1500m, then run out of the water and jump on your bike, still wet. Of course, then you freeze. When the 40km cycle ride is over, you have to run 10km, which is a long way when you're feeling exhausted. But it's great fun, and all worth it in the end," she says. Melanie entered her first triathlon at 14. "I won the junior section - but then I was the only junior taking part. It seemed so easy that I was waving at my teammates as I went around." Full of confidence, she entered the National Championships, and although she had the second fastest swim and the fastest run, she didn't place. "I was following this man and suddenly we came to the sea. We realized then that we had gone wrong. I ended up cycling 20 kilometers too far. I cried all the way through the running." But she did not give up and is determined that she never will. "Sometimes I wish I could stop because then the pain would be over, but I am afraid that if I let myself stop just once, I would be tempted to do it again." Such determination draws admiration from Steve Trew, the sport's director of coaching. "I've just been testing her fitness," he says, "and she worked so hard on the running machine that it finally threw her off and into a wall. She had given it everything, but whereas most people step off when they realize they can't go any further, she just kept on." Melanie was the top junior in this year's European Triathlon Championships, finishing 13th. "I was almost as good as the top three in swimming and running, but much slower at cycling. That's why I'm working very hard at it." She is trying to convince her supportive parents, who will cover the £1,300 cost of her trip to New Zealand for this year's World Championships, to buy a £2,000 bike ("It's a special deal, with £1,000 off) so she can try national 25 km and 100 km races later this year. But there is another price to pay. Her intense training sessions have made her a bit of a recluse. "I don't have a social life," she says. "I'm not a party animal anyway. After two hours of hard swimming on Friday nights, I just want to go to sleep. But I phone and write to the other girls in the team." What does she talk about? Boys? Clothes? "No, what sort of times they are achieving." Where will all this focus end? Melanie has tried other events. She has tried the triathlon "sprint," for example, where you only have to swim 750m, cycle 20km, and run 5km. She wants to enter even tougher events than the triathlon. "The big trouble is, I have no one of my age to train with," she says. Funny, that.

**The Collectors**

Amanda Roy writes about her collections and why many people enjoy this hobby. I have always loved collecting, and one in three adults shares this interest. It is a world full of passion, envy, enthusiasm, and delight. However, if you decide to collect, remember: if you do not love an object, do not collect it.

Since ancient times, people have felt the urge to collect. Primitive humans collected pebbles and wore them as necklaces. Attracted by their shapes and colors, these pebbles were man's first attempt to gather objects for intellectual and spiritual reasons. Over the centuries, not much has changed. Children still collect stones and seashells for their beauty.

I have been collecting all my life, from flowers like tulips to pottery and paintings. My first collection was stones from my parents' garden. At six, I was sent to a school in a remote part of England, a cold and windy place surrounded by hills. When my parents visited, they took me to the local museum, full of objects collected by people in the past. I was fascinated by these objects.

Surprisingly, I am not alone in my interest in collecting. One in three adults shares this passion. The reasons why people collect have become a topic of great interest. Some believe it is the only part of their lives where they have complete control. For me, it's just something I enjoy.

One famous collector was the Duc de Berry in France. He had a 'room of wonders' with natural and artificial curiosities, like cups made from coconut shells and pieces of Oriental china. Another was Catherine the Great of Russia, who collected over 4,000 paintings. However, you do not need to be rich to start a collection. I have collected tulip bulbs and china cups, searching for each type with determination. I remember convincing a fellow tulip collector to give me one I wanted. I planted and watered it until it was stolen by another collector.

I once collected 350 American rag dolls, searching all over the USA for different designs. This collection was destroyed when my house caught fire. The next morning, I saw the remains of my furniture and collection. I am not sure which saddened me more!

I am interested in how collections change hands. A silver spoon that once belonged to a king or poet gives value to items traded in markets. As small objects become popular collector's items, their prices rise. Toys from the 1950s are now investments, provided you kept the original boxes. (I not only threw them away, but I also discarded the contents.)

**My Job: Four People Talk About Their Work**

**Lisa - Exhibition Programmes Organiser, Science Museum**

I organize temporary exhibitions. This means I plan and design the exhibition and promote it. I need to learn about the exhibition topic first and then talk to experts to decide the main themes and goals. I plan what objects and pictures to show. I make sure visitors understand the exhibition by planning interactive displays, workshops, and theatre. I also hire engineers and electricians to ensure the display is safe. Before the exhibition opens, I help create brochures and leaflets to inform people about it.

**Janet - Teacher of London Taxi Drivers**

I start my day at 7.30 a.m. by checking the accounts. Then, I see what new maps and documents are needed for learning the routes for the London taxi-driver test. By midday, about 50 students are in school, figuring out the best routes using the correct streets and turns. I help when there's a disagreement, like if a right turn is possible at a junction. When students are close to the test, I challenge them by saying their chosen route is blocked, so they must find another way. This helps them think critically.

**Sarah - Marine Conservationist**

I live by the coast and work from home. My job includes answering phone calls, creating educational materials, and setting up training courses. I sometimes visit the main office but usually work on the coast. I also work with schools and study centers, running courses for coastal managers and decision-makers about the sea. I take them out on a boat to help them understand marine life better. This often changes their views, as it's different from making decisions on a computer. I love my job because conservation is my hobby, but working for a charity means I always need more money and resources.

**Chris - Map and Atlas Publisher**

My job is varied. I ensure our publishing program meets market needs and maintain stocks of about 300 books. We have high standards for information and content. We get many letters from readers about issues like international boundaries, which need careful replies. I discuss future projects and current sales with co-publishers. I work with an enthusiastic team, which makes the job enjoyable. The downside is there is too much administration, leaving less time for interesting tasks like product development and design.

Text: 'No Title We always went to Ireland in June. Since the four of us started going on holidays together, we spent the first two weeks of the month at Glencorn Lodge in County Antrim. It's a large house by the sea, near the village of Ardbeag. The English couple who bought the house, the Malseeds, have added to the building, but everything has been done very discreetly. It was Strafe who found Glencorn for us. He saw an advertisement when the Malseeds still needed to advertise. 'How about this?' he said one evening and read out the details. We had gone away together the summer before, to a hotel recommended by friends, but it wasn't a success because the food was terrible. The four of us have been playing cards together for a long time: Dekko, Strafe, Cynthia, and myself. They call me Milly, though my real name is Dorothy Milson. Dekko got his nickname at school, as Dekko Deacon sounded good. He and Strafe were at school together, which is why we call Strafe by his surname, like the teachers did. We're all about the same age and live close to the town where the Malseeds were before they moved from England to Ireland. Quite a coincidence, we always think. 'How very nice,' Mrs. Malseed said, smiling her welcome again this year. She seems to know when guests are about to arrive, as she's rarely not waiting in the large, low-ceilinged hall that always smells of flowers. 'Arthur, take the luggage up,' she told the old porter. 'Rose, Tulip, Lily, and Geranium.' She referred to the names of the rooms reserved for us. Mrs. Malseed painted flowers on the doors of the hotel instead of using numbers. In winter, when not many people come to Glencorn Lodge, she takes care of little details like that; her husband handles redecoration and repairs. 'Well, well, well,' Mr. Malseed said, entering the hall through the door that leads to the kitchen. 'A hundred thousand welcomes,' he greeted us in the Irish way. He was smiling broadly with his dark brown eyes twinkling, making us feel like we were more than just another group of hotel guests. Everyone smiled, and I could feel the others thinking that our holiday had truly begun. Nothing had changed at Glencorn, all was well. Kitty from the dining room came out to greet us. 'You look younger every year, all four of you,' she said, making everyone in the hall laugh again. Arthur led the way to the rooms, carrying as much of our luggage as he could and returning for the rest. After dinner, we played cards for a while but didn't play as long as we might have because we were still quite tired from the journey. In the lounge, there was a man on his own and a French couple. There had been other people at dinner, of course, because in June Glencorn Lodge is always full: from where we sat in the window, we could see some of them strolling about the lawns, others taking the cliff path down to the seashore. In the morning, we'd do the same: we'd walk along the sands to Ardbeag and have coffee in the hotel there, back in time for lunch. In the afternoon, we'd drive somewhere. I knew all that because over the years this kind of pattern had developed. Since we first came here, we'd all fallen in love with every variation of its remarkable landscape.'

**Keeping the Holiday-Makers Happy**

A chalet girl's work is never done, as Sarah Sutherland-Pilch explains to Veronica Lee, in between making beds and cooking delicious meals. This is Sarah's second year working as a chalet girl. She is 24 years old and comes from West Sussex. Known by her nickname, Pilch, Sarah works for a company in Val d'Isere, France. She cooks and cleans for visitors who come to ski and stay in the wooden houses called chalets, which are typical of the area. Sarah graduated in French and History of Art from Oxford Brookes University last summer. She says being a chalet girl isn't a career, but a fun way to spend a year or two before settling down. 'It's a good way to make contacts. I meet successful people every week.'

Sarah does not live in the chalet. She wakes up at 7 a.m. and walks about a mile to the chalet, which can host up to 18 guests each week. She has her own breakfast before preparing breakfast for the guests. 'They get everything - porridge, eggs, cereals, fruit, and croissants.' When the last guest finishes breakfast, around 9:30 a.m., Sarah cleans up and either prepares afternoon tea, which is left for the guests to help themselves, or cleans the rooms - 'the worst part of the job,' she says. By about 11 a.m., she is ready to go skiing. She skis as much as possible. 'On a good day, we can be up there until 4:30 p.m.'

Sarah returns to the chalet in time to prepare dinner and takes a shower before doing so, but she does not sleep. 'It's fatal if you do,' she says. Dinner, a three-course meal, is served at 8 p.m., and coffee is usually on the table by 10 p.m. Sarah clears away the dinner things and fills the dishwasher. 'There's nothing worse than coming into a messy kitchen the next morning.' Sometimes she will stay and chat with the guests; other times, they prefer to be left alone. 'Good guests can make a week brilliant - breakfast this morning was great fun - but some weeks, for whatever reason, don't go quite so well.'

Sarah meets her friends in the chalet where she lives, and they go out at about 11 p.m. 'We usually start off in Bananas, might go to G Jay's, and perhaps Dick's T-Bar at the end of the evening,' she says. But Sarah never stays out too late on Saturday night because Sunday is her busiest day of the week. 'A frightful day,' she says, 'when you certainly don't want to be cooking breakfast with a terrible headache.' Work begins earlier than usual on Sunday, as breakfast for guests who are leaving has to be ready by 7 a.m. As soon as the guests leave, Sarah starts cleaning quickly. 'We just blitz the place - clear the breakfast, strip the beds, get everything ready.' If she hasn't done the week's shopping on Saturday, Sarah does it now. At around 3 p.m., after cleaning, Sarah prepares tea for the new guests. 'They arrive at around 4:30 p.m.' Sometimes they are confused and have many questions. 'I'm sure it's the mountain air that does something to them.'

Between tea and dinner, Sarah takes any guests needing boots or skis to the ski shop and then gets a lift back to the chalet from one of the ski shop staff. It is soon time for dinner duty again and perhaps a drink later, but not always. 'Sometimes I'm so tired I just have an early night,' she says.

Miss Rita Cohen, a small, pale-skinned girl who looked much younger than Seymour's daughter, Marie, but said she was about six years older, visited his factory one day. She wore overalls and big, unattractive shoes, and her pretty face was surrounded by a bush of wiry hair. She was so small and young-looking that Seymour found it hard to believe she was studying at the University of Pennsylvania, researching the leather industry in New Jersey for her Master's degree. A few times a year, someone would call or write to Seymour asking to see his factory, and sometimes he would help a student by answering questions over the phone or, if they seemed very serious, by giving them a short tour. Rita Cohen seemed almost as small as the children from Marie's third-year class, who had visited the factory years ago to see how Marie's father made gloves. They especially liked the laying-off table, where the men shaped and pressed each glove by pulling it over steam-heated brass hands. These hands were very hot, shiny, and stood straight up from the table, looking thin and flat. As a child, Marie was fascinated by them and called them the 'pancake hands'. Rita asked, 'How many pieces come in a shipment?' Seymour replied, 'Between twenty and twenty-five thousand.' She kept taking notes and asked, 'Do they come directly to your shipping department?' He was pleased that she was interested in every detail. 'They go to the tannery first. The tannery is a contractor. We buy the material, and they prepare it for us to work with. My grandfather and father worked in the tannery here in town. I did too, for six months, when I started in the business. Have you ever been inside a tannery?' 'Not yet.' 'Well, you need to visit a tannery if you're going to write about leather. I can arrange that for you if you want. They're old-fashioned places. Technology has improved things, but what you'll see isn't much different from hundreds of years ago. It's tough work. It's said to be the oldest industry with remains found anywhere. Six-thousand-year-old tanning relics were found in Turkey, I think. The first clothing was just skins tanned by smoking them. I told you it was interesting once you get into it. My father is the leather expert; you should talk to him. Start him on gloves, and he'll talk for two days. That's typical: glove makers love the trade and everything about it. Have you ever seen anything being made, Miss Cohen?' 'I can't say I have.' 'Never seen anything made?' 'I saw my mother make a cake when I was a child.' He laughed. She made him laugh. An eager learner with spirit. His daughter was at least 30 cm taller than Rita Cohen, fair where she was dark, but otherwise, Rita Cohen reminded him of Marie. The good-natured intelligence that filled the house when she came home from school, full of what she'd learned. How she remembered everything. Everything neatly written in her notebook and memorized overnight. 'I'll tell you what we're going to do. We're going to show you the whole process. Come on. We're going to make you a pair of gloves, and you're going to watch them being made from start to finish. What size do you wear?'

Text: 'Is it a tough job? Chris Arnot asks four people with dream jobs if they're as wonderful as they seem. A. Raquel Graham Raquel Graham calls from a taxi on her way to the airport. She can't meet me tomorrow because her boss wants her in Los Angeles instead. As a personal assistant to a pop star, she has to travel around the world at a moment's notice. Raquel loves her job and gets along well with her boss. There's just one small issue - she doesn't like flying. 'On a nine-hour flight to California, I usually take sleeping pills to help calm me down,' she admits. Her worst experience was flying on Concorde. 'It felt so closed in with those tiny windows.' When she's not traveling, she works in offices in Manchester and London. She has to do some routine paperwork - organizing the diary, attending meetings with lawyers and accountants, planning schedules, and making more travel arrangements. She didn't apply for the job. A chance meeting with a pop group's manager led to an offer to work behind the scenes, and she took a secretarial course in the evenings at the same time. Five years later, she was in the right place at the right time when her boss needed a PA. B. David Brown David Brown has been both an accountant and a golf caddy, someone who carries a golfer's bags. Overall, he preferred being a caddy. Well, who wouldn't if golf was their passion? There were some downsides, though. A small flat fee is offered, plus a percentage of the winnings. The average earnings are between £25,000 and £35,000, and much of that goes on travel and hotels. He was 31 when he first caddied for the golfer Greg Norman. 'You're not just carrying bags. You're giving advice, using your knowledge against the weather, and trying to understand the course.' His accountancy skills were recently recognized by European Tour Productions when they made him a statistical data administrator. From cards brought in by the caddies, he compiles and analyzes the statistics of each day's play. The results are wanted by TV commentators, golfing magazines, and the golfers themselves. C. Martin Fern Martin Fern is the editor of the 'Food and Drink' pages of a daily newspaper, and one of his easier tasks is to try what's on offer in the best restaurants. What does he think about restaurants that charge very high prices? 'For those who can afford it, it's up to them,' he says. 'I'd rather spend £120 on a meal I'll remember for the rest of my life than buy a microwave.' It was his talent as a cook that led to the offer of a food column from a friend who edited a Saturday Review. For Martin, who was then a creative director of an advertising agency, it was a useful extra income. He was 42 when another newspaper called to offer a full-time job. 'It meant a 50 percent cut in guaranteed income,' he says. 'But it was a chance to turn my passion into a profession.' He still does all the cooking at home and tries to keep his waistline under control by cycling a couple of miles to the nearest tube station. D. Dick Prince 'I started writing children's stories about 20 years ago,' says Dick Prince, one of Britain's most popular children's writers. 'Before that, I had always loved words and enjoyed using them, but my writing had mainly been poetry. Then I had this idea for a story. I had been a farmer and knew the problem of chickens being killed by a fox. So I wrote a kind of role reversal story called The Fox Busters, which became my first published children's story.' Where do his ideas come from? 'Well, it's not easy, I have to work at them,' he says. 'That is what I usually do in the mornings. I'm not up with the dawn, I'm afraid. After lunch, I spend another couple of hours typing out the morning's scribbling - all of which I do with one finger on an old portable typewriter rather than on one of those awful laptops. I get between 50 and a hundred letters a week, and that is the part about being a writer that I enjoy the most. I do try to answer them all, but nowadays I have some secretarial help.'

**Simplified Text:**

In the lumberyard by the lake, where trees were turned into boards for building, there was an old two-story brick building. Around it were big piles of soft sawdust. These golden piles covered the yard all the way to the blue lake. That afternoon, with nothing else to do, all the boys followed Michael up a ladder to the roof of the old building. They sat with their legs hanging over the edge, looking at the lake. Suddenly, Michael said, "I dare you to jump down," and without thinking, he jumped off the roof and landed on the sawdust, laughing. "I dare you all!" he shouted. "You're all cowards," he said, trying to get them to follow him. Laughing, he watched them from the roof, looking scared, but one by one they jumped and got up smiling with relief. In the hot afternoon sun, they lay on the sawdust pile telling jokes until one of the boys said, "Let's go back up and jump again." They weren't very excited, but they all went up to the roof and started jumping off again until only Michael was left. The others were below, looking up and calling, "Come on, Mike. What's wrong?" Michael wanted to jump and join them, but he stayed on the edge, licking his lips with a nervous smile, wondering why it seemed like a longer drop this time. At first, they thought he was joking, but then they saw him clenching his fists. He tried counting to ten and jumping, but it didn't work. He tried taking a deep breath and closing his eyes. After a while, the boys started laughing at him; they were tired of waiting, and it was almost dinnertime. "Come on, you're a coward. Do you think we'll wait all night?" they shouted. When he didn't move, they started to leave, still shouting. "Who started this? What's wrong with you?" he called. But he stayed on the roof, looking sadly at the ground. He was alone for almost an hour while the sun, like a big orange ball, slowly set beyond the lake. His clothes were wet from nervous sweating. Finally, he closed his eyes, slipped off the roof, fell heavily on the sawdust, and lay there for a long time. The yard was quiet; the workers had gone home. As he lay there, he wondered why he couldn't jump, then got up slowly and walked home, feeling very ashamed and wanting to avoid everyone. He was so late for dinner that his stepmother said coldly, "You're old enough to come home on time. If you won't come home, you should stay in tonight." She was a strong woman with fair skin, a little grey in her hair, and a patient smile. She spoke with controlled seriousness, but Michael, with his dark, sad face, hardly heard her; he was still thinking about the boys laughing at him.

**Careers Advice**

Are you unhappy in your job but unsure how to change it? Kitty Doherty offers some helpful advice. Many people who want to change their job are turning to careers advisers. You will need to write a brief history of yourself and take several tests called 'psychometrics'. Afterward, you receive a summary of the results, which suggests various careers and any retraining you might need.

I decided to try Career Analysts, a large organization that provides career advice. Taking the careers test felt like being back in my science exams. I was in a group of about ten people, answering questions quickly. I had to remember that it wasn't about passing or failing. It was hard to see how the psychometrics would accurately describe me. The tests included finding mistakes in lists of names and numbers and matching similar shapes. Afterward, I had a long chat with an adviser. Using this conversation and the test results, he created a report with his observations and recommendations. I agreed with most of his conclusions, though I was a bit upset to learn I did poorly in the scientific, technical, and practical tests. I'm sure many sick people are glad I never became a nurse. However, it was reassuring to hear that I made the right choice in journalism.

Rethinking your career doesn't have to mean a big change. Last March, after working as a marketing manager for a large insurance company for five years, 25-year-old Donna Laney lost her job. Her friends suggested she go to Career Analysts for help. "Losing my job was the perfect chance to step back and look at my career so far. I wanted to re-examine my skills and interests," says Donna. Some results were surprising. "I hadn't realized I had a talent for design. But I had to weigh the cost of retraining in design against my financial commitments," she says. Other suggestions included taking a year off to work in the Far East. "I decided to use the skills I already had and move into something more suited to me than insurance. I am now working as a Public Relations officer. I might have reached this point without Career Analysts, but they helped me see, objectively and independently, what I truly wanted to do. I've sent several friends there, and they are all happy with the service."

Some people feel they wouldn't have reached their goals without help. A visit to Career Counselling Services led 26-year-old Juliet Greene to make life-changing decisions. "After working for a major bank for six years, I found my job dull and needed a new challenge. I had no idea what I wanted to do, so I went to Career Counselling Services with an open mind. I took the tests, which showed I was interested in sciences," she says. "I had four sessions with an adviser. The third session was recorded, which was very useful because you forget many things you say. After the fourth meeting, I decided to study geology and plan to start a degree course in it later this year. I think the advice from Career Counselling Services was worth the fee. I'm much happier now and more positive."

However, careers advice doesn't work for everyone. Amanda Margetts, a 24-year-old sales representative, says: "I reached a point in my career where I didn't know what to do next. I thought a careers adviser might suggest something new. Although I got many new ideas, I rejected them because they required a big salary drop or a lot of retraining. I wasn't told anything about myself that I didn't already know," she says. "You have to give the adviser a lot of personal information, and I felt that if I had told a friend the same things, they would have given me similar advice."

**Fun at the Dentist's?**

If you visit W. Lloyd Jerome's dental office in the center of Glasgow, you'll notice bright modern paintings on the walls and a stylish blue couch where patients sit while he checks their teeth. Jerome says, "Half of the people only go to the dentist when they're in pain instead of going for regular check-ups. That's because they're scared." To change this, he has tried to create a place where people are not afraid. That's why he decided not to wear a white coat, as he believes people link it with pain. His idea is that dental treatment should happen in a relaxed, interesting, and enjoyable setting.

This is surprising for many of us who think of dental visits as painful or at least formal and clinical. Jerome says, "If people are relaxed, entertained, and treated well, they will forget their past negative experiences." One of his new relaxation methods is virtual-reality headsets. "We were the first practice in Britain to use them, and they're very popular. The headsets are used for the first check-up, where the patient sits comfortably on the blue couch and watches a film about underwater wildlife while I examine their teeth. Then the headset switches to a special camera, giving the patient a visual tour of their mouth." Surprisingly, most patients seem to enjoy this part of their dental visit.

Another important aspect is that the office smells more like a perfume shop than a dentist's. Today, it smells like orange. Jerome explains, "When people walk in, I want them to realize with all their senses that it's not like going to the dentist's. Smell is very important. The typical dental smell can make your heart race if you're scared of dentists." I found the gentle smell in the office very pleasant.

Although he is known as Glasgow's most fashionable dentist, Jerome emphasizes that he takes his work very seriously. The relaxation techniques are important, but the quality of the treatment is the most important thing. For example, Jerome uses a special tool that sprays warm water on the teeth to clean them, instead of scraping them. It feels a bit strange at first, but as long as people are relaxed, it's not painful at all.

Five years ago, Jerome went to the United States to research dental techniques. "One thing I learned there was that when you make it easier for the patient, you make it easier for yourself," he explains. He sees his patient-focused approach as the beginning of a slow change towards less formality in the traditional British dentistry profession.

At that moment, a patient arrives. Jerome quickly goes over, offers him a cup of tea (herbal or regular), asks him what video he'd like to watch, and gently leads him to the chair. The patient seems to enjoy this five-star treatment, and it's no surprise. The office feels more like an elegant beauty salon than a typical dental practice.

**Bitter Water Hits the Big Time**

Chocolate, which started in South America, is now a huge global business. At Easter, people in Britain spend over £230 million on chocolate. Eight percent of all chocolate is bought during this time. Only at Christmas do people eat more chocolate. Although large-scale chocolate production began in the last century, the cacao plant was first grown by the Aztec, Toltec, and Mayan civilizations in Central America over three thousand years ago. 

The cacao tree is an evergreen, tropical plant found in Africa, South and Central America, the West Indies, and South-East Asia. The fruit of this tree is the size of a melon and contains 20-40 seeds. When dried, they become cacao beans, which are used to make chocolate. In English-speaking countries, they are often called cocoa beans, a misspelling from the 17th century when they were also called cacoa and cocao beans.

The Aztecs used cocoa beans as money and to make a drink called xocoatl, meaning 'bitter water' in their language, Nahuatl. This chocolate drink was flavored with spices and used in ceremonies and to welcome visitors. The Spanish liked the drink better with cinnamon and sugar, but the recipe didn't spread to the rest of Europe for another century. In the late 17th century, chocolate houses were set up in Europe's capital cities, where people gathered to drink chocolate.

Until the last century, chocolate drinks were made from solid blocks of chocolate melted in hot water. But in 1826, CJ van Houten from the Netherlands invented chocolate powder by removing most of the cocoa butter from the crushed beans. The chocolate bar as we know it began in 1847 when Fry and Sons, a company in Bristol, combined cocoa butter with pure chocolate liquor and sugar to make a solid block you could eat. A Swiss company later added milk solids, creating milk chocolate.

At the turn of the century, French companies dominated the British chocolate market. In 1879, the English company Cadbury named their Birmingham factory Bournville (ville is French for town) to add some French style. But then Cadbury's famous Dairy Milk bar, which started as Dairymaid in 1905, became popular. Clever advertising linked it to the healthy qualities of milk from the English countryside, making it a rival to the more luxurious French brands.

Currently, chocolate consumption in Britain has stabilized at about four bars each week. This has led manufacturers to find new ways to attract customers. The latest trend is the 'extended line,' where a chocolate bar becomes an ice cream, soft drink, or dessert to appeal to those tired of regular snacks.

Meanwhile, cacao farmers are still affected by a drop in cocoa bean prices at the end of the 1980s. Since most cacao farmers work on a very small scale, many had to close their businesses. Perhaps you could think of them as you enjoy your next chocolate bar.

**THE SHELL ARTIST**

At 83, Peter Cooke has become an expert in his art. There are still many things Peter Cooke wants to try, like paper-making and feather-work. For now, he focuses on the skill he has perfected over the past ten years: creating delicate and unique objects from shells. "Tell me if I am boring you," he says, as he shows me around his apartment, displaying his work. There is a fine line between being boring and being enthusiastic, but Cooke is definitely the latter, thanks to his charm and the beauty of his creations.

He points to a pair of shell-covered ornaments above a fireplace. "I won't mind if people don't buy them because I've grown fond of them, and to me, they're adorable. I never intended to sell my work commercially. Some friends visited me about five years ago and said, 'You must have an exhibition - people should see these. We'll talk to a man who owns an art gallery.'"

The result was an exhibition in London, where 70 percent of the objects were sold. His second exhibition opened at the gallery yesterday. Considering the high prices the pieces fetch - around £2,000 for the ornaments - an empty space above the fireplace seems a small sacrifice for Cooke to make. There are 86 pieces in the exhibition, with prices starting at £225 for a shell-flower in a crystal vase. Cooke insists he has nothing to do with the prices and is openly cheerful about them: he claims no one else in the world creates work like his, and, as the gallery owner told him, "Well, you're going to stop one day, and everybody will want your pieces because there won't be any more."

"I do wish, though," says Cooke, "that I'd started this much earlier, because then I could have created really wonderful things - at least the potential would have been there. Although the ideas are still there and I'm doing my best now, I'm more limited physically than I was when I started." Still, the work he has produced is far from the common shell constructions found in seaside shops. "I have a miniature mind," he says, which has led to boxes covered in thousands of tiny shells, little shaded pictures made from shells, and baskets of incredibly realistic flowers.

Cooke has developed his own method and uses materials as he finds them. He uses the cardboard from laundered shirts for his flower bases, a nameless glue bought in bulk from a sail-maker ("If it runs out, I don't know what I will do!") and washing-up liquid to clean the shells. "I have an idea of what I want to do, and it just does itself," he says of his working method, yet the attention to detail, color gradations, and symmetry he achieves look far from accidental.

Cooke's search for beautiful, especially tiny, shells has taken him beyond his Norfolk shore: to France, Thailand, Mexico, South Africa, and the Philippines, among other places where he has searched for treasures to bring home. He insists he only collects dead shells and defends himself against people who accuse him of stripping the world's beaches. "When I am collecting shells, I hear people's big feet crushing them far faster than I can collect them; and the ones that are left, the sea breaks up. I would not dream of collecting shells with living creatures in them or diving for them, but once their occupants have left, why shouldn't I collect them?" If one considers the amount of luggage that can be carried home by one man, whose work's beauty often surpasses its natural parts, his argument becomes very convincing indeed.

**The Schoolgirl Model**

When 15-year-old Kira Langer is not traveling to amazing places and appearing on magazine covers, you will probably find her studying for her school exams. Jane Laidlaw finds out more.

"I'm afraid Kira will be a little late," the receptionist at the agency told me. "Oh, fine," I said, "no problem." I had been trying to convince myself that all the negative things I had read about models were not true, but words like difficult, vain, and unintelligent kept coming to mind. And now she was going to be late. How late? An hour? Three hours? Maybe she wouldn't come at all. What if she decided a visit to the hairdresser's would be more fun than talking to me? If she was late, she would be rushing. She could be in a bad mood and refuse to answer my questions.

But when the winner of the Looks magazine supermodel competition walked in, she was smiling, relaxed, and apologetic, and she was with her mother. Kira was not dressed in expensive designer clothes but in a simple black dress and trainers. There was no sign of a selfish attitude; she was just a very friendly, very tall, very pretty girl. All models under the age of 16 must take an adult with them whenever they work, she explained, and apart from looking incredibly young, her mother was a normal mum - visibly proud of her successful daughter.

Kira seems a bit surprised by her new fame, which makes sense since it was not planned. It was her older sister who decided that she should enter the model competition. "She saw the competition and said I should go in for it," Kira remembers. "I said no, but she sent some photos in anyway." When the call came to tell her that she was a finalist, she was at school. Being selected for the final gave Kira the confidence to go through with it, and she performed perfectly. She won easily, and the Select model agency in London immediately offered her work.

Kira now finds that one of the hardest things she has to do is manage her two separate lives. But her friends and teachers have become used to having a star among them. "They're really proud of me," she says. However, a few unkind people at her school are rude about her success. "They say I have too high an opinion of myself." This kind of remark must be hard for Kira to deal with, since there can't be many people as successful as her who are less self-important. But she says, "They assume that because I've suddenly become a model, I can't stay the same. But the only thing that's changed is I've become more confident - not in a horrible way, but I'm able to stand up for myself more."

As a busy model, though, her social life is obviously affected. The Select agency can call at any time and tell her that she is wanted for a job the next day. "If my friends are going out together, I can't say I'll come, because I don't know what I'm doing the next day. I can't really make plans, and if I do, they sometimes get broken, but my friends are good about it. They don't say, 'Oh, you're always going off modeling now, you never have time for us.'"

Kira has the looks, ability, and support to have a fabulous career ahead of her. And not many people can say that before they even sit their school-leaving exams. I am about to finish the interview with the girl who has it all, and I ask what she would like to do as a career if she didn't have the outstanding beauty that seems certain to take her to the top of the profession. She pauses and replies, "I'd like to do what you're doing."

Father and Son Start Gold Rush

Terence and Chris Madden have traveled from Canada's cold north to Africa's heat in search of valuable metals. Terence, an explorer, and his son Chris, a mineral expert, believe their mine on a Welsh mountain might have up to 10,000 ounces of gold. After ten years of digging in the Welsh hills, they think they are very close to a gold vein worth five million dollars. Terence, 68, from Liverpool, said, "As we dig, we are finding high levels of gold; now we just need to dig a few more meters to where it is concentrated."

The Maddens have dedicated their lives to finding gold. Their search began when Terence read about gold worth millions in the 'Dolgellau gold belt', an area near the Welsh town of Dolgellau. They studied 19th-century mining journals and newspapers at the Welsh National Library in Aberystwyth to choose the best area to explore. After clearing away plants and finding bits of gold in the rocks, they spent ten years getting permission from landowners, taking earth samples, and removing old cars and rubbish. They dug out 150 tonnes of greenstone rock to make a tunnel and a 10-meter shaft. Now, they are running out of money. They need to find someone to invest £50,000 to dig a few more meters to reach the gold. Chris Madden says, "At the moment, this looks doubtful, although we've got quite a few people we can contact."

As news spread about the dig, the magic of gold attracted the attention of locals and gold diggers. Dolgellau depends on tourists, and residents are cautiously hopeful. Peter Woolven, manager of the Royal Ship Hotel, said, "It would encourage more people to come here if they are right, but if these two find gold, I hope millions of people are not going to come and hack away at the hillside."

The Welsh gold industry has declined since its peak in the late 1880s when thousands worked in hundreds of mines. One of the last mines, Clogau-St David's, which made wedding rings for the Queen and the Princess of Wales, closed a month ago. However, individual gold-diggers are returning. George Hall, another prospector, plans to dig a tunnel on the other side of the ridge from the Maddens. Hall, 70, said, "Searching for gold is very emotional. It's adventurous and exciting, the wonder of uncovering hidden treasure. Maybe I'll be lucky this time."

**IN HOT WATER**

Rachel Mills is a scientist who spends a lot of time at the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean. She is a lecturer at the Oceanography Centre at Southampton University and studies marine geochemistry, which means she looks at the chemical processes in the sea. When she isn't teaching, she goes into a small steel vehicle, about the size of a small car, to dive three kilometers down into the Atlantic Ocean to study underwater volcanoes. Inside the vehicle, space is so tight that she can touch the two pilots. They are used to these conditions, which mean they and Rachel can't stand up or move much, and they must stay inside until someone opens the door from the outside. A dive can last for 16 hours: three hours to reach the ocean floor, ten hours collecting rock and water samples, and then three hours to return to the surface. If there is a problem and they need to get to the top quickly, they can press a panic button. This releases a small escape vessel that quickly rises to the surface, like a ping-pong ball in water. No one has tested it yet, but Rachel thinks it wouldn't be a pleasant trip.

Rachel remembers her first time in the vehicle. It was on a ship's deck, and she got in with an instructor who explained the emergency procedures, including what to do if the pilot had a heart attack. They wanted to see how she would react in such a small space. Now, Rachel has made six dives. Last year, she dived with a Russian crew. They went to a site five days' sail west of the Canary Islands in the Atlantic. On the ocean floor, there is a large area of underwater volcanoes with chimneys blowing out black smoke. The Russian team was placing scientific equipment there to study the effects of a program that would make a hole 150 meters through a volcano.

When Rachel isn't at sea, she is in her office at the Oceanography Centre, Southampton.
