Two-thirds of her salary comes from teaching, which she loves, but she does it so she can continue her research into the "black smokers." This is another name for underwater volcanoes, where water comes out of the rock and looks like black smoke. It pours out at a rate of one meter per second and at a temperature of 350 degrees Celsius.

The only time Rachel was frightened was when she first went down with an American team. They were towing equipment on a 50-meter rope when there was an explosion. The shock waves hit their vehicle, and Rachel thought she was going to die. They waited in silence, and when nothing happened, they were incredibly relieved to be alive.

Diving to the deepest part of the ocean is an adventure for Rachel. Every time she looks out of the porthole and sees the chimneys, she feels a sense of wonder. She is at the bottom of the sea, seeing something no one else has seen before. She had studied the black smokers for three years for her PhD, and seeing them in real life was an amazing experience.

I was dirty, smelly, hungry, and somewhere beneath all that, suntanned. It was the end of my Inter-Rail holiday. My body couldn't take any more punishment. My mind couldn't handle any more foreign timetables, currencies, or languages. "Never again," I said, as I stepped onto home ground. I said exactly the same thing the following year. And the next. All I had to do was buy one train ticket, and because I was under twenty-five years old, I could spend a whole month traveling anywhere I wanted in Europe. Ordinary beds are never the same once you've learned to sleep in the corridor of a train, the rhythm rocking you into a deep sleep. Carrying all your belongings on your back in a rucksack makes you have a very basic approach to travel, and encourages incredible wastefulness that can lead to burning socks that have become too unpleasant, and getting rid of books when finished. On the other hand, this way of looking at life is entirely in the spirit of Inter-Rail, for common sense and reasoning can be thrown out of the window along with the paperback book and the socks. All it takes to achieve this carefree attitude is one of those tickets in your hand. Any system that enables young people to travel through countries at a rate of more than one a day must be pretty special. On that first trip, my friends and I were at first unaware of the possibilities of this type of train ticket, thinking it was just an inexpensive way of getting to and from our chosen campsite in southern France. But the idea of non-stop travel proved too tempting, for there was always just one more country over the border, always that little bit further to go. And what did the extra miles cost us? Nothing. We were not completely uninterested in culture. But this was a first holiday without parents, as it was for most other Inter-Railers, and in organizing our own timetable we left out everything except the most immediately available sights. This was the chance to escape the guided tour, an opportunity to do something different. I took great pride in the fact that, in many places, all I could be bothered to see was the view from the station. We were just there to get by, and to have a good time doing so. In this, we were no different from most of the other Inter-Railers with whom we shared corridor floors, food and water, money, and music. The excitement of travel comes from the sudden reality of somewhere that was previously just a name. It is as if the city in which you arrive never actually existed until the train pulls in at the station and you are able to see it with your own tired eyes for the first time. Only by actually seeing Europe, by watching the changing landscapes and seeing the differences in attitudes and lifestyles, can you really have an accurate picture of the continent in your mind. Everybody knows what is there, but it is meaningless until you view it yourself. This is what makes other people's holiday photos so boring. While the train trip won't allow you to discover anything new in the world sense, it is a valuable personal experience. Europe is a big place, and Inter-Rail gives people the best opportunity to recognize this ... though in our case it didn't happen immediately.

Text: 'There is nothing more disappointing than arriving at an airport in another country and finding out that your baggage has been left behind. At best, you will have to wear the clothes you are in for hours or days until the airline returns your luggage. At worst, you might be in a different climate, far from home, and have to wear unsuitable clothes. Although airlines rarely say how many bags they lose, it is a common issue that regular travelers will eventually face. Even the best airlines make mistakes sometimes, and no airline can guarantee that a passenger's checked luggage will be on the same flight, especially when the trip involves changing planes. 

Here's how the system works. Airlines require passengers to check in early to give enough time for baggage to go through the airport and be loaded onto the plane. Minimum connecting times (MCTs) are the shortest times needed to transfer between flights, and these are also set to allow for baggage transfers. Normally, the system works well. But extra security checks and air traffic problems can delay flights, causing the baggage system to fail. There is also the chance of human error or an accident where the destination label is torn off. These issues can be serious at large transfer airports, known as 'hubs', because they handle many bags. For example, last year, London's Heathrow airport handled over 41 million passengers, with nine million changing planes. British Airways alone handled two million transfer passengers at Heathrow, with most moving between Terminal 1 (for Domestic and European flights) and Terminal 4 (for long-distance flights). Even efficient transfer airports like Amsterdam, Copenhagen, Singapore, and Zurich have bad days. The risk of losing baggage when changing planes is higher at certain airports. Even the United States has issues - Miami airport is known for luggage going missing when passengers connect to flights to Latin America.

To avoid losing your luggage, choose direct flights when possible and check in well before the official time. If you must change planes or if it makes your flight cheaper, try to fly with the same airline for the whole trip. Allow more time for connections by taking an earlier flight to the transfer airport, and label your luggage inside and out with your home and holiday addresses. Don't forget to include the flight numbers. If your luggage still goes missing, contact the airline official in the baggage hall and fill out a property irregularity report (PIR) before leaving the airport.'

Text: 'The Kingfisher Wildlife photographer Charlie James is an expert on the kingfisher, a beautiful blue-green bird that lives near streams and rivers and feeds on fish. Old trees hang over the stream, partly shading the shallow water. Soft greens, mud browns, and the different yellows of sunlight are the main colors, as gentle as the sounds of water in the breeze. The bird moves quickly through the scene, like a flash of light and motion that is so striking you almost feel it. It disappears in a split second, but the image stays in your mind, its impact much larger than its size. Charlie James fell in love with kingfishers when he was young. He cannot explain exactly what attracts him to this little bird, which shows how much he cares for it. The kingfisher is part of legends. In Greek myth, it is a moon goddess who turned into a bird. Another story says the kingfisher flew so high that its upper body became the blue of the sky, while its underside was burned by the sun. There is some scientific truth in this story. Even though their feathers show many different blues, kingfishers have no blue pigment. Instead, the structure of their feathers scatters light and reflects blue strongly. This is why a kingfisher can look bright blue or rich emerald green depending on the angle of the light. It's no surprise that some wildlife photographers are very enthusiastic about them. The colors, along with the fact that kingfishers, though shy of people, can be watched easily from a hideout, create a lifelong passion. Charlie James's first hideout was an old blanket he put over his head while he waited near a kingfisher's favorite spot. The bird returned within minutes and sat only a meter away. But it took him another four years to get his first good picture. Meanwhile, the European kingfisher became a big part of his life. He spent as much time as he could by a stream rich with kingfishers. The problem was that school took away time he could spend with the birds. So he skipped classes, becoming what he calls an 'academic failure'. But his interest in the kingfisher, the only member of its family to breed in Europe, was noticed. At 16, he was hired as an advisor for a nature magazine. He then worked as an assistant to the editor and gradually became a freelance wildlife film cameraman. Now, he wants to make the ultimate kingfisher film. 'No speech, just beautiful images that say it all,' he says. 'I'm drawn to the simple approach. I like to photograph parts of kingfisher wings...' His sentence trails off. He's thinking of the bird's colors that still excite him after so many years. His photographs show some of his feelings, but as Charlie knows, there's much more to his relationship with the kingfisher than his work can ever show.'

**Conducting an Orchestra: Insights from Five New Conductors**

**A. ANNE MANSON**

Anne Manson, 30, had an unexpected start in conducting when she asked to watch Claudio Abbado's rehearsals in Vienna. She ended up replacing an absent assistant and was later invited to help with another opera. "I had to lead the first rehearsal for Abbado. No, I wasn't nervous. I've always been comfortable in front of an orchestra," she says. Manson, originally from the US, works with a London opera company focused on modern music. She is also gaining recognition in Europe, supported by the British Arts Council, and has assisted Abbado on several occasions since.

**B. ANDREW CONSTANTINE**

Andrew Constantine, 31, believes the hardest part of conducting is convincing people to give you opportunities. He won a major competition in 1991 after failing in two others. Reflecting on this, he feels the timing was right: "If it had happened earlier, I might have disappeared." The competition opened doors for him, including a role as an assistant to a famous conductor. However, he worries about being labeled as just a "competition winner." "If in three years my name is still linked to the competition, I'll be concerned," he says. "But orchestras like the English Chamber Orchestra, who hired me after the competition, are inviting me back. If they don't, your career can fall apart."

**C. WASFI KANI**

Wasfi Kani, founder of Pimlico Opera, enjoys the long rehearsal periods in opera. "The music deserves four weeks of focus," she says. Kani began conducting seriously in her late twenties. After university, she worked in London's business sector until Pimlico Opera became fully professional two years ago. Starting lessons with Sian Edwards was crucial for her. "Seeing her conduct, I realized she was my size. I had always been taught by much bigger people, which makes a big difference." She appreciates the complexity of opera: "There are many arguments, and you have to consider the singers' personalities."

**D. ROGER VIGNOLES**

"Conducting came as a surprise, but it's fascinating," says Roger Vignoles, 48. It's not a strange move for him, though. He began as a resident musician at an opera house and worked with skilled conductors. Last year, he was asked to direct Handel's Agrippina from the piano at a festival, something new for him. "It was easier than I thought. I knew the music well and what I wanted it to sound like. I tried to achieve that performance. People respect my musical ability. I'm using all my experience in music and performing. Now, I'll do whatever people ask to find out what I enjoy."

**E. WAYNE MARSHALL**

In 1986, conductor Simon Rattle noticed Wayne Marshall, then a young assistant, and mentioned him to his agent. Marshall, now 32, soon found himself conducting a musical in London on short notice, a challenging start. He even had to deal with musicians reading newspapers during the show: "I was firm with them. I always gave a clear beat and got the best result I could. Many musicians don't seem to need much guidance from a conductor. But I'm not afraid to say what I want. If you show worry, it gets worse. I've never formally studied conducting, and no book teaches you how, but people have been supportive. I'm determined and know what I like."

**Variations on a Theme**

If you're planning to take children to a theme park, there are many options in Britain. We asked five families to try out some of the best ones.

**Fun Island - The Burns family**

Last year, we visited a large theme park in the US, so we thought Fun Island might not be as exciting. However, we were pleasantly surprised. The park is great for younger children, so our three-year-old felt included. The kids loved the Crocodile Ride and the Giant Wheel. There’s a special dodgems ride for very young kids, which was a big hit. For older children, there are more thrilling rides like Splash Out, where you end up in a pool! After five hours, Steve and I were ready to leave, but the children wanted to stay because they were having so much fun. Our only complaint is that the park lacks a bit of atmosphere, and the scenery could be better. But the staff are very helpful, and the park is clean, well-organized, and safe.

**Wonderland - The McMillan family**

None of us had been to a theme park before, so we didn’t know what to expect. We thought Oscar might be too young, but he loved it. He enjoyed the Mountain Train and Little Land, which has small models of famous buildings at his height! The older children liked the ferris wheel and driving toy cars on a real road layout. We spent six hours there and appreciated the places to rest. The landscaping is beautiful, and the staff are friendly and helpful. There’s something for everyone, including adults.

**Adventure World - The Jeffree family**

After seven hours, we felt there was still a lot to see. The children loved the Big Top Circus, especially the trapeze act, which was thrilling. We went on the Terror Line, and although the girls were scared and kept their eyes shut, they said they enjoyed it. Their favorite ride was Running River, where you think you’ll get wet, but you don’t. For younger children, Toy Land is great fun. The children looked at the new ride, Fear Factor, but we were relieved they were too small for it! The park is well-designed, so even waiting in line isn’t too boring. It’s very clean, and the staff are excellent. On one ride, I couldn’t sit with both girls, so a staff member offered to go with one of them.

**The Great Park - The Langridge family**

We arrived at one o’clock and were disappointed that the park was only open until 5 p.m. This is a great theme park for younger children because the rides aren’t too scary. I’m usually afraid, but even I had fun. We all loved Exotic Travels, a boat ride that starts calmly and then becomes very exciting. We waited for half an hour for Lightning River, and then it was over quickly! I didn’t go on the Big Leap, but it looked great for those who are brave. If the children were older, they might have found it a bit tame, but they were the right age and loved it.

**Fantasy World - The Break-all family**

The park advertises that there is 'No Limit to the Fun', and we agree. Europe’s tallest roller-coaster, the Rocket, is the main attraction, and Ben thought it was the scariest ride, although Jennie said the Hanger, where you hang upside-down 30 meters above the ground, was even scarier! There are about a dozen main rides, which the older children went on several times. Sarah was too small for a few of them, but she enjoyed the Long Slide. We found the staff attitudes varied. Some were great with younger children, but the welcome wasn’t always warm. You need a full day to enjoy Fantasy World. We wouldn’t have dared tell the kids we were leaving early.

**Running a Business in the Countryside: Five Women's Stories**

**A. Christine Hogan**  
Christine Hogan runs a computer-aided design business with a yearly turnover of over £200,000 and employs four full-time staff. She says, "My customers are friends." Christine and her husband moved from London to the countryside when their children were young. She wanted a job she could do from home. Having worked with computers before marriage, her husband suggested starting a computer-aided design business. It required a lot of money, and the beginning was tough. Christine was careful with finances, always informing the bank manager if she might overspend. Working from home saves money, and she can work in the evenings if needed. The business remains small, with local clients often collecting their work.

**B. Maggy Sasanow**  
Maggy Sasanow enjoys being independent and works from home designing greeting cards. She studied art at university and wanted to work in a museum, but after marrying and moving to the countryside, she started her own business. She creates 50 different greeting cards, selling them to museums. Maggy works in a large room upstairs. A downside of working from home is the constant distraction of household chores. Her business grows through word of mouth, without advertising. People send work from London because she is cheaper than other artists. Although she misses exchanging ideas with others, she finds more advantages than disadvantages in her work.

**C. Delia Turner**  
Delia Turner has faced challenges with her curtain-making business. She started eight years ago, and initially, the business grew from £24,000 to £80,000 in two years. She managed six full-time curtain-makers but had to let them go due to economic decline, which was difficult as jobs are scarce in the area. Now, Delia is almost back to where she started, making curtains at home with her husband's help and using women who work from their homes. She must be ready to lower prices when needed and explore new opportunities.

**D. Tessa Strickland**  
Tessa Strickland manages the editorial and production side of her children's book publishing business from her farmhouse. She moved to the countryside three years ago for financial reasons and her love of the country. Tessa enjoys the flexibility of working when she wants. Most of her income comes from deals with Australia, the Far East, and North America, requiring her to take calls at odd hours. The challenge is maintaining discipline to stop working. She publishes children's books from various cultures, collaborating with authors and artists. Initially, she felt lonely, as all her professional experience was in London.

**E. Meg Rivers**  
Meg Rivers runs a cakes-by-post business and a shop with a yearly turnover of £250,000, employing six people, some part-time. She started ten years ago at home, focusing on health by making fruit cakes with quality ingredients. As demand grew from friends and relatives, she began sending cakes nationwide. Seven years ago, she rented a small building where everything is made, employing a baker, assistant, and professional cake-icer. Meg now manages the commercial side and no longer cooks. Her biggest challenge has been the financial aspect, as they didn't have much money to start with.

**Meet the Amazing Watkins Family**

The Watkins family is unique because not only are the sons talented musicians and composers, but their father, John, also makes musical instruments. When John and Hetty Watkins from South Wales needed a cello for their ten-year-old son, Paul, they found it too expensive to buy one. John decided to learn how to make a cello himself. He attended evening classes at the Welsh School of Instrument Making for about three years. After practicing with violins and violas, he successfully made his first cello for Paul. Paul used this cello until recently, and John now makes up to twelve violins a year. Selling one to the famous American violinist Jaime Laredo was a highlight for him.

Both Paul and his younger brother, Huw, were encouraged to play music from a young age. Paul started with the piano and then moved to the cello, inspired by a cellist in his father's music group. Huw, on the other hand, chose to play the piano and is now making a name for himself as a pianist and composer.

Paul achieved great success with the cello his father made. He won the string final of the BBC Young Musician of the Year competition and became the principal cellist of the BBC Symphony Orchestra at the age of 20. He now plays a Francesco Rugeri cello, which is on loan from the Royal Academy of Music. Paul believes his father's cello will improve with age, just like his Rugeri, which is over 300 years old.

Paul will soon perform Elgar's Cello Concerto on television, but he won't be able to watch it because he will be performing at the Cheltenham Festival the same night. Huw will also be busy, as his String Quartet will premiere in London at the Wigmore Hall. John and Hetty will have to manage their time well to follow their sons' busy musical schedules.

Text: 'Caring for the Countryside THE NATIONAL TRUST The National Trust is an organization that aims to protect the British countryside. Gill Page visits the Lleyn Peninsula in North Wales and talks to Gareth Roberts, a warden employed by the Trust to care for the beautiful areas it owns. According to Gareth, a National Trust Warden needs common sense. 'You also need to be good with people because you deal with farmers, visitors, conservationists, and building companies all the time.' Gareth grew up on the Lleyn Peninsula and worked on his parents' farm until he got married. About 80 people applied for the job of National Trust Warden for the Lleyn Peninsula. In the end, Gareth's local knowledge and farming experience got him the job, even though he didn't have formal training. 'It's helpful that I still farm with my parents and can understand farmers' problems. Also, they can't fool me about anything!' he says. His farming background also helps him handle the physical work of the job - putting up fences, planting trees, building walls. Since joining the Trust, Gareth has learned more about nature conservation. 'When I was young,' he remembers, 'I used to pick and press flowers, collect butterfly larvae, and old birds' nests. I recently thought, where would I find all those flowers, birds' nests, and grasshoppers now? It's clear to me that farming has changed the countryside. It's not the farmers' fault - they were just following government advice.' Gareth says that, when he started, farmers and conservationists were against each other. Both wanted things done their way. Now they talk and understand each other's views. 'We're at a crossroads and just need a small step to bring them together,' says Gareth. Conservation is a main part of Gareth's work, along with public access to the Trust's land, tree planting and maintenance, and meeting the Trust's tenant farmers. 'My role is to make sure jobs get done, with little fuss and as cheaply as possible. What I enjoy most is seeing projects finished, although about half my time is spent on reports, signing bills, and so on.' Gareth is very enthusiastic about his job and, despite never being off duty, he enjoys every minute of it, especially talking to the public. Most of them, anyway. 'It's the attitude of some people I dislike,' he admits. 'They just come into the area, demand everything, then leave as if it's their right. Having to be nice to those people annoys me!' But as Gareth says, it's all about common sense. So if you have plenty of that, and you like the idea of an outdoor job, you might think of applying to become a warden like Gareth - but don't expect a job to be available on the Lleyn Peninsula for many years!'

**The Netball Captain**

In our series on women in sport, Suzie Ellis met England's netball captain, Kendra Slowinski. Kendra is preparing for next month's World Championships. Her days are busy: she teaches at a local school and then trains in a supermarket car park. I asked her if people give her strange looks. She said, "I'm too focused on my movements and my feet to notice. I might see cars slow down, but that's all."

Kendra's life is all about being her best for the Championships. She follows a strict schedule to get fit. This will be her fourth World Championships, and they will be the biggest ever, with 27 countries participating. "We'll have home support, which is special," she says. "It's important to improve netball's reputation in our country. Playing here means more pressure. A home crowd will expect us to start well."

Their first game is against Barbados, right after the opening ceremony. "As far as I know, we have always beaten them, but they are exciting to play. They have lots of ability." England is currently ranked fourth in the world. But the World Championships will be tough. "You have to play every day, with no rest between games. In a series, you can lose the first game and still win. But in the Championships, there's only one chance."

In her 15 years at the top level, netball has become harder and faster. Players are more aggressive. "You don't train so hard not to win," says Kendra. "But after the final whistle, we're all friendlier."

Netball now uses a more scientific approach to fitness. "We must think and train like world-class players," says Kendra. "As captain, I need a strong mental attitude and must lead by example. My role is to support and encourage the team."

Kendra's netball career has been carefully planned. She decided that this competition would be her last as a player. She might coach young players in the future, but now she is focused on her last big event. As she leads her team in the opening ceremony, she might have a tear in her eye.

**SPECIALIST MUSIC SCHOOLS**

How should you support a child with exceptional musical talent? It can be challenging to know the best way to nurture their gift. Some parents might not notice their child's needs until the child becomes frustrated and difficult to manage. While most schools can support children who excel in academic subjects, musically gifted children need special attention that regular schools might not provide, especially if music is not a priority there. These children, along with those encouraged by parents or teachers, might benefit from attending a specialist music school.

There are five specialist music schools in Britain, which are relatively new. They offer a supportive environment for gifted children aged seven to eighteen to develop their musical skills with the help of professional musicians. At these schools, children spend one-third to half of their day on musical activities, such as individual lessons (up to three hours a week on their main and secondary instruments), playing in orchestras, chamber groups, voice training, conducting, and learning music theory. They also practice for several hours daily in well-equipped private rooms, sometimes with a teacher. The rest of their time is spent on a limited academic program focusing on essential subjects like English, math, basic sciences, and languages. However, students can study more subjects if they wish.

All five British specialist schools are independent, with small classes and a high teacher-to-student ratio. Most students are boarders, meaning they live at the school full-time, which allows them to grow up with peers who have similar goals and interests.

What are the downsides? One major issue is the cost; boarding fees range from £12,000 to £17,000 a year. However, schools try to help parents of exceptionally gifted children with scholarships and financial aid. Another concern is that not all parents want to send their children to boarding school, especially at a young age. Many school directors question the wisdom of admitting children as young as seven into such a demanding environment. They emphasize that their goal is to develop 'rounded and well-balanced individuals.'

Separating musically gifted children from an early age can be stressful. Musical talent might fade during teenage years, and the pressure to succeed can lead to feelings of failure. However, specialist schools closely monitor each student's progress and provide help and advice when needed. While many former students feel they gained a lot from the high-quality music education, some are concerned about the limited academic program, which is secondary to music activities. Many musically talented young people are also very intelligent and can handle academic challenges, feeling frustrated if their intellectual needs are unmet.

For these reasons, it might be better to wait until the child is old enough to decide for themselves before considering a specialist education. Those who are also academically gifted might thrive in a less specialized environment, such as a school with an excellent music department or by combining regular schooling with musical training at a junior department of a music college. These colleges offer Saturday morning lessons with excellent teachers and opportunities for orchestral and chamber music experience. However, this option may not be feasible for families living far from London or other major cities.

Artist Susan Shepherd is famous for her flower paintings. Her large garden, full of her favorite flowers like tulips and poppies, provides many of her painting subjects. Some plants grow wildly and spread throughout the garden. The garden has a beautiful mix of colors and shapes, especially in the two long flower borders along the path. This is partly thanks to the previous owners, who were passionate gardeners and left plants that Susan liked. She also kept their gardener, Danny. Susan says, 'It was really his garden.' They got along well, and although Danny sometimes doubted her choices, he understood her vision when she explained she wanted to paint them.

Susan prefers to paint detailed studies of single plants rather than the whole garden. Sometimes she paints groups of plants where they grow, but usually, she picks them and takes them to her studio. 'I don't set everything up at once,' she explains. 'I paint one flower, which might take a few days, then add another one, building the painting over time. Sometimes it takes a couple of years to finish.' Her busiest time is spring and early summer when tulips and poppies bloom. 'They all bloom together, and you're so busy,' she says. She is also fascinated by how flowers change as they decay. For example, tulips change shape and open up when left in water, becoming more interesting over time.

Susan has always loved plants. 'I studied botany at school and collected wildflowers from the countryside,' she says. 'I wasn't interested in gardening then; I thought garden flowers looked fake, like the silk or plastic ones in some shops. I preferred wildflowers because they grew in tough places like rock cracks or cliff tops.' Now, her garden includes plants from distant countries, but they fit in well. She has a relaxed attitude towards her garden, like an aunt who lets children play freely as long as they don't cause harm. With two upcoming exhibitions and plenty of subjects to paint, she finds it hard to work in the garden. She has hired another gardener, but she knows that to stay connected to her work, 'you have to get your hands dirty.'

Title: Keeping the Holiday-Makers Happy

Sarah Sutherland-Pilch, a 24-year-old from West Sussex, shares her experience as a chalet girl in Val d'Isère, France. This is her second year working there, where she cooks and cleans for visitors staying in chalets, which are typical wooden houses in the area. Sarah graduated in French and History of Art from Oxford Brookes University last summer. She says being a chalet girl isn't a long-term career but a fun way to spend a couple of years before settling down. 'It's a good way to make contacts. I meet successful people every week,' she says.

Sarah doesn't live in the chalet. She starts her day at 7 a.m. and walks about a mile to the chalet, which can host up to 18 guests each week. She has her own breakfast before preparing a full breakfast for the guests, including porridge, eggs, cereals, fruit, and croissants. After breakfast, around 9:30 a.m., she cleans up and either prepares afternoon tea or cleans the rooms, which she finds the hardest part of the job. By 11 a.m., she is ready to ski and enjoys being on the slopes until about 4:30 p.m.

Sarah returns to the chalet to prepare dinner and takes a shower before starting. Dinner is a three-course meal served at 8 p.m., with coffee by 10 p.m. After dinner, she cleans up and loads the dishwasher. Sometimes she chats with the guests, while other times they prefer to be left alone. 'Good guests can make a week brilliant, but some weeks don't go quite so well,' she says.

Sarah meets her friends at the chalet where she lives and they go out around 11 p.m. They visit places like Bananas, G Jay's, and Dick's T-Bar. However, she never stays out too late on Saturday night because Sunday is her busiest day. 'A frightful day,' she calls it, as she starts work earlier than usual to serve breakfast by 7 a.m. After the guests leave, she cleans the chalet thoroughly, strips the beds, and prepares for the new guests. If she hasn't done the week's shopping on Saturday, she does it now. By 3 p.m., she prepares tea for the new guests, who arrive around 4:30 p.m. She helps them with any questions and takes those needing equipment to the ski shop. After that, it's time for dinner again, and sometimes she chats with friends, but not always. 'Sometimes I'm so tired I just have an early night,' she says.

Text: 'Changing lives with a Stranger Mandie Currie, a zoo-keeper, spent the day at the offices of the magazine Marie Claire. 'Choosing what to wear for my day at Marie Claire was difficult because I usually wear a uniform at work. First, I went to a still-life photo studio, then to press previews, all before lunch. The zoo is a calm, peaceful place - and here I was rushing around when I could be sitting quietly with an animal. Some of the fashion team seemed quite stressed - my job doesn't really get stressful. At a fashion shoot in the afternoon, it made me laugh to think that I'd usually be cleaning cages or handling rats. I'm interested to see how magazines work, but I really enjoy my job at the zoo, so I'll stay there.' Alice Cutler, a fashion assistant at Marie Claire, spent the day at London Zoo. 'I arrived at the zoo in my leather boots and dark blue trousers. The zoo gave me a green polo shirt to work in - which was good because I got very dirty. As I stroked one of the elephants, I thought Mandie would probably be packing up clothes in the cupboard. By five o'clock, I smelled bad, but I'd had such a great day. When I retire from fashion, I could see myself working with elephants - but maybe in Africa.' Karen Hodson, a nurse at Hammersmith Hospital, went on location with the television gardening programme Ground Force. 'I was very excited about meeting the team, and Alan Titchmarsh, the programme presenter, was really nice. One of the things I liked was the chance to be outside. Depending on my shifts, I sometimes never see daylight. Even though it was hard work, it was great fun. I thought I was pretty strong, but I felt weak compared to the rest of the team. My romantic idea of landscape gardening did not include physical hard work or careful planning. I was more enthusiastic than effective as a gardener, so I don't plan to leave my other job.' Charlie Dimmock, a landscape gardener with the TV programme Ground Force, worked a shift at Hammersmith Hospital. 'I made beds and handed out tablets. I expected to faint when I was doing some jobs, but I was surprised to find that it didn't bother me. The friendship among the nurses is great, and it felt very 'girlie' compared to my usual male environment. I feel my job is a real waste of time compared to nursing. My day at the hospital was not exactly pleasant, but it left me with a great sense of satisfaction.' Lucy Harvey, a personal trainer, spent the day with the airline Ryanair as a member of the cabin crew. 'I changed into the uniform, and the moment I put it on I felt completely different - people suddenly look up to you. Before the flight, our supervisor told us about safety, what to do if someone had a heart attack - which I knew about from my fitness training. When the passengers boarded the flight to Paris, I gave out magazines. Everyone stared at me, and I felt very self-conscious. On the return journey, we had 80 schoolchildren on board who wouldn't sit still. I wished I was back in the gym with one sensible adult to look after.' Sonia McDermott, an air hostess with the airline Ryanair, spent the day as a personal trainer in a gym. 'I was worried about doing this swap as I don't do any exercise. I was amazed at how much attention you give to one person. In my job, you meet 130 passengers four times a day. I was very surprised at lunch to see that some of the trainers didn't eat very healthily, but they all drink lots of water. I wouldn't swap my job for this. However, it has inspired me to join a gym and try to be a bit healthier.''

**On the Rails: Five Celebrities Share Their Favorite Train Journeys**

**Andrea Thompson - Newsreader**  
I fell in love with the south of France a long time ago and try to visit as often as I can. There's a local train from Cannes along the coast that crosses into Italy. It takes you past some of the most amazing sea views. No matter the weather or time of year, it is always enchanting. Out of the other window, you can see some of the best gardens and homes in France. It feels like peeking into the lives of the rich and famous. The travelers are always lively, with a mix of tourists and locals, all enjoying the breathtaking journey.

**Raj Patel - Explorer**  
I have enjoyed many rail journeys over the years, but my favorite is the Nile Valley Express, which runs across the desert in northern Sudan. Growing up in South Africa, I missed a family train trip from Cape Town to the Kruger National Park because I was considered too young and troublesome. When I moved to England as a teenager, I still hadn't traveled by train. London Waterloo was the first real station I saw, and its great glass dome amazed me.

**Betty Cooper - Novelist**  
I am grateful to one train in particular: the Blue Train, which took my husband and me on our honeymoon across France to catch a boat to Egypt. On the train, my husband gave me a pink dress, which I loved. Someone mentioned that pink is good for the brain, and I've worn the color ever since. What I remember about the journey is how lovely it was to travel through France and then by boat up the Nile to Luxor. It was the perfect way to relax after all the wedding preparations.

**Martin Brown - Journalist**  
We were working on a series of articles about a round-the-world trip and had to cross a desert in an African country. There wasn't a road, so we took the Desert Express. The timetable was unreliable - we were just given a day. We heard that the driver would often wait for days to depart if he knew people were still on their way. When it appeared, there was a rush of people climbing into and onto the carriages - people even traveled on the roof for free. During the night, the train crossed some of the most beautiful landscapes I have ever seen. It was like a dream, like traveling across the moon.

**Arisu Mezuki - Actress**  
Most people form their favorite impressions of trains when they are young, but not me. I grew up in Singapore and Cyprus, where I saw very few trains. It wasn't until I was a teenager that trains became important in my life. I made a film featuring a railway in Yorkshire. Most filming took place on an old, disused line maintained by volunteers. That's where my passion for steam trains began. When we weren't filming, we rode the train whenever we could, and when I went back last year, it was as if time had stood still. Everything was still in place, even the gas lights on the station platform!

Text: 'Trying to get published? If you're wondering where to send your story, our expert Margaret Stubbs has the advice you need. Readers often ask, 'I have written this story/book. Who should I send it to?' The first thing to know is that you should research the market and learn about publishers while improving your writing skills. Turning words into something that sells requires knowledge about the 'writing game'. Whatever you write, you need to understand the markets you are targeting. The best way to do this is by reading everything relevant you can find. Use your local library and visit bookshops and newsagents. Reading widely will guide you on what kinds of writing publishers are accepting at any time. This knowledge must be updated regularly as new publications appear, editors change jobs, and magazines change direction. New titles come and go all the time. Publishers are always looking for new talent; as writers, we must give them what they want. At first, you might not be sure what you want to write. Let's say you want to write short love stories. The first thing you must do is find out which magazines publish love stories, a limited market these days, and get as many recent copies as you can. Then, learn about the kind of stories they buy, paying attention to who the readers are. These readers expect different things from their magazine, and the editor focuses on meeting their needs. Writers often send me their stories saying, 'This has been rejected three times - am I wasting my time? Do I stand a chance?' As a former teacher, I would never discourage anyone. But it's unlikely the work is ready for publishing, so I try to give an honest opinion, but always positively. The problem is that most new writers are too eager to send their work out, usually before they are ready for the market. If you have only written one story or article, it's unlikely to be published. That almost never happens. When you hear about 'success', you usually find that the person has been in publishing or journalism for years before their success. When you finally send off your work for the first time, start working on more while you wait for a reply; write ten more stories, even twenty. Each one will be better than the last, and you will start to think of yourself as a writer, and both your fluency and confidence will grow. Don't throw any of them away—improve them instead. Also, I advise not showing your work to anyone else, especially in the early stages. Remember that every successful writer has faced many rejections before succeeding. Do everything you can to advance your writing career. See if there's a creative writing course near you. If not, try joining a local writers' group to gain ideas and confidence from other aspiring writers. Think of yourself as a writer and practice writing—every day if possible.'

On the last day of a difficult year, I was leaning against a pillar in the Baltimore railway station, waiting for the 10.10 train to Philadelphia. There were more people than I expected. The station, usually airy and clean, felt crowded. Elderly couples with matching luggage filled the benches, and groups of college students sat on the floor with their bags. A grey-haired man was walking around, talking to strangers. He looked well-off: tanned skin, nice sweater, and a soft, beige coat. He approached a woman sitting alone and asked her something. Then he came to a girl standing near me. She had long blond hair, and I thought I wouldn't mind talking to her. The man asked, "Are you traveling to Philadelphia?" "Well, northbound, yes," she replied. "But to Philadelphia?" "No, New York, but I'll be..." "Thanks, anyway," he said, moving to the next bench. Now he had my full attention. "Ma'am," I heard him ask an old lady, "are you traveling to Philadelphia?" When she said, "Wilmington," he just moved on to a couple with matching luggage. I straightened up and moved closer, pretending to look at the platform. I was going to Philadelphia. He could have asked me. I understood why he didn't; I probably seemed unreliable. He glanced at me quickly and then moved to the other end of the waiting area. He looked stressed. "Please!" he said to a woman reading a book. "Tell me you're going to Philadelphia!" She lowered her book. She was around thirty-five, older than me. A school-teacher type. "Philadelphia?" she said. "Why, yes, I am." "Then could I ask you a favor?" I stopped a few feet away and looked at my left wrist, pretending to check a watch I didn't have. Even without looking, I sensed she was cautious. The man must have sensed it too, because he said, "Nothing too difficult, I promise!" They announced my train. People started moving toward Gate E, the older couples pulling their wheeled bags like pets on leashes. I heard the man talking. "My daughter's flying out this afternoon for a study year abroad, leaving from Philadelphia. I put her on a train this morning, stopped for groceries, and came home to find my wife upset. My daughter forgot her passport and called from the station in Philadelphia, not knowing what to do." The woman clucked sympathetically. I would have stayed quiet, waiting to see where this was going. "So I told her to stay put. Stay right there in the station, I said, and I would get someone here to bring her passport." A likely story! Why didn't he go himself if it was such an emergency? "Why don't you go yourself?" the woman asked. "I can't leave my wife alone for that long. She's in a wheelchair." This seemed like a poor excuse, in my opinion. It was more bad luck than one family should have. I glanced at them. The man was holding a packet, not a plain envelope, which would have been logical, but a padded envelope the size of a paperback book. Aha! Padded! So you couldn't feel the contents! And from where I stood, it looked stapled shut. Watch yourself, lady, I thought silently.

**Gary and Me**

John Moore, a restaurant owner, writes about his relationship with his son Gary, who is a famous TV chef. John believes everyone gets a chance in life. Gary's chance was cooking, and John's was running a restaurant. When John found the opportunity to own a restaurant, he quickly went to see it. The place was in bad condition, but it was perfect for his plans. This reminded him of his childhood when his mother worked in a factory, and he felt lonely. He wanted to ensure his family had time together. His wife took care of the children and managed the accounts, while John ran the business. They lived above the restaurant and always made sure to have meals together. This approach benefited their children, Gary and Joe, making them confident. From a young age, they would talk to the regular customers, giving them a good start in life.

Gary was an energetic child. At seven, he once jumped into a corner bath like it was a swimming pool and knocked himself out. As he grew older, he worked for pocket money, starting with small jobs. By ten, he was in the kitchen every weekend, earning a lot of money at school. He was disciplined, often waking up before his father. In a family business, everyone helps, and it was nice to see Gary involved. Although Gary wasn't very academic, he excelled in the kitchen. By 15, he was as skilled as the adults working there and sometimes even took charge, preparing over a hundred meals. John knew Gary would pursue catering because he had a natural talent. When Gary needed work experience for school, John sent him to a friend's restaurant.

Recently, Gary started playing the drums and formed his own band. John wonders what will happen to Gary's cooking if his music career succeeds. John's advice to Gary is to focus on one goal, saying, "If you chase two hares, you catch neither." He also told Gary, "If you want to achieve something, do it by 30. After that, it's too late." Gary went to catering college at 17. On his first day, he and the other new students, who were usually beginners, were given a morning's work. Gary finished everything in an hour and helped others. John is proud of Gary's success with his TV cookery series. He always taught Gary that hard work is necessary because nothing is given for free. Gary saw his opportunity and took it. John reflects that if children remember even a little of what parents teach them, it's a success. Seeing Gary's actions and words, John feels Gary listened to him sometimes.

Finding a good flat in Dublin at an affordable price was very difficult, like finding gold during a gold rush. The best way was through personal connections: if you knew someone who knew someone leaving a place, that often worked. But if, like Jo, you had just arrived in Dublin, you had no personal contacts, no one to tell you about a vacant bedsit at the end of the month. So, it meant staying in a hostel and searching. For Jo, Dublin was a big unknown. She felt she was stepping into the unknown when she took the train to work there. She didn't question why she was going. Everyone she knew from school assumed she would go. Who would stay in a small, remote town? That's all she had heard for years. They all wanted to leave, see some life, and have a real existence. Some of her classmates went to towns like Ennis or Limerick, where a relative would help them settle. But from Jo's year, no one else was going to Dublin. She was going alone. Jo's mother thought it would be great if she stayed permanently in the hostel, which was run by nuns, so she would be safe. Her father hoped they kept the place warm, as hostels were known for being cold. Jo's sisters, who worked as waitresses in a hotel, thought she was crazy to stay a whole week in a hostel. But Jo didn't know they were all still thinking and talking about her as she answered an ad for a flat in Ringsend. It said, 'Own room, own television, share kitchen, bathroom.' It was very close to the post office where she worked and seemed too good to be true. Please, please let it be nice, let them like me, let it not be too expensive! There wasn't a queue for this one because it wasn't just 'Flat to Let', it was 'Third Girl Wanted'. The mention of 'own television' made Jo wonder if it might be too fancy for her, but the house didn't look intimidating. It was an ordinary red-brick terraced house with a basement. But the flat wasn't in the basement; it was upstairs. A cheerful-looking girl with a college scarf, obviously a failed applicant, was coming down the stairs. 'Desperate place,' she said to Jo. 'They're both awful. Common as dirt.' 'Oh,' said Jo and continued climbing. 'Hello,' said the girl with 'Nessa' on her T-shirt. 'Did you see that snobby girl leaving? I can't stand that type.' 'What did she do?' asked Jo. 'Do? She didn't have to do anything. She just looked around, made a face, giggled, and said, "Is this all there is? Oh dear, oh dear," in a posh accent. We wouldn't have her here, would we, Pauline?' Pauline wore a very colorful shirt, almost as bright as her hair. Pauline was a punk, Jo noted with surprise. She had seen punks on O'Connell Street but hadn't talked to one before. 'I'm Jo, I work in the post office and I called.' Nessa said they were just about to have a mug of tea. She brought out three mugs; one had 'Nessa', one had 'Pauline', and the other had 'Other' written on it. 'We'll get your name put on if you come to stay,' she said kindly.

**Behind the Dolphin's Smile**

People love dolphins. We enjoy watching them in marinas, movies, and TV shows. However, the Whale and Dolphin Conservation Society says dolphins are in trouble. Mark Simmonds reports on their decline.

Dolphins are special to us. They are very intelligent, understand human emotions, and make us dream of freedom in the wild seas. TV shows like "Flipper" and "Seaquest" with Darwin have made us love them even more. But these happy images hide the truth about dolphins living in polluted and overfished seas today. The number of North Sea harbour porpoises, a type of dolphin, has dropped by up to 89,000.

You might think such popular animals are protected by law and live in special marine reserves. Unfortunately, this is not true, and the lack of protection could become a major wildlife disaster. There are forty different kinds of dolphins worldwide. In northern Europe, the most common are the striped, common, bottlenose dolphins, and the smaller harbour porpoise. The first two live far out at sea and are seen only in small groups, so we know little about them. The large grey bottlenoses and harbour porpoises used to be common near European coasts. Bottlenoses are very social and were found on the Channel coast and in British rivers like the Thames. Now, they are only found in the Moray Firth in Scotland and Cardigan Bay in Wales, and the few that remain show signs of stress.

Dolphins' complex habits make it hard to know why their numbers are falling. Overfishing, which is reducing fish stocks and threatening local fishing industries, also threatens dolphins. Porpoises need to find food quickly, and if fish are overfished in one area, they may not survive. They can also get caught in fishing nets, which they cannot see. Modern fishing uses large nets that float or are pulled quickly through the sea. Recently, many dead dolphins have washed up on French and Cornish beaches, showing marks and cuts from these nets.

Pollution is another problem. Waste in the sea can build up in dolphins' bodies. For example, pesticides dissolve in fat, so dolphins can absorb them, and they accumulate in their bodies. Female dolphins then produce milk with high pesticide levels, passing the poison to their young. There is a case of a young dolphin dying from its mother's milk.

Perhaps the most debated threat is human disturbance. Dolphins live in groups and use sound to understand their world. In the sea, noise pollution from ships and oil wells travels four times better than in the air. This might disturb dolphins in ways we do not yet understand.

Title: 'GETTING FIT'

Exercise is important for your mind, body, and spirit. It helps you stay balanced when life feels chaotic. You might be tired of hearing about fitness, but it's truly beneficial. There are many reasons to exercise and very few reasons not to. Exercise improves muscle tone and quickly changes your body shape. It increases muscle strength and helps you maintain good posture, which is how you hold your body when sitting or standing. It prevents muscle imbalances that can cause injuries. Exercise also improves specific areas like thighs, stomach, and upper arms. It benefits your heart, lungs, and blood circulation.

You might have heard these reasons before and feel bored, but here's something to consider: exercise can reduce depression and tiredness, help you sleep better, and manage stress. It can also help with certain medical conditions. These reasons should convince you that exercise is good for you. Common sense also tells us this.

There are many types of exercise you can try, like aerobics, calisthenics, jogging, and weight training. However, be careful not to train too hard or with too much weight, as this can cause injury. Start slowly and consult your doctor if you're unsure about what's best for you.

Good posture is crucial for improving your body shape. A stiff or sagging body not only looks unattractive but also lacks energy and may have minor health issues. If you tend to slouch, imagine a helium balloon pulling the top of your head up. This will help lift your chest for better breathing and make your body look slimmer. When standing with a balanced chest, you should be able to see your ankles.

Stretching improves flexibility and movement, helps maintain correct posture, and prevents muscle injuries. Doing it four or five times a week will make your body more flexible and fit. Stretching should be a key part of your exercise routine and should be done slowly and carefully.

The best exercise routine includes a good warm-up, stretching exercises, an energetic workout, and a cool-down period.
