**The Netball Captain**

In our series on women in sport, Suzie Ellis met with England's netball captain, Kendra Slawinski. Kendra is leading England's netball team. When I met her, she was having a typical day leading up to next month's World Championships: teaching at a local school and then training in a supermarket car park. I was surprised about her training place. 'Don't people look at you strangely?' I asked. 'I'm too focused on my movements and my feet to notice,' she said. 'I might see cars slow down from the corner of my eye, but that's it.'

'My whole life now is about being at my best for the Championships,' says Kendra. She follows a strict schedule to get fit. These are her fourth World Championships, and they will be the biggest ever, with 27 countries participating. 'We'll have home support, which is special,' she says. 'It's important to improve netball's reputation in this country. Playing here means more pressure. A home crowd will have expectations and give more support. People will expect us to start with a good game.'

Their first game is against Barbados, right after the opening ceremony. 'As far as I know, we have always beaten them, but they'll be exciting to play. They have lots of ability.' The England team is currently ranked fourth in the world. But, as Kendra points out, the World Championships will be tough. 'You have to push yourself to play each day, there's no rest between games like in a series. You can still win a series if you lose the first game, but the Championships are different because there's only one chance.'

In the fifteen years since she has been playing at the top level, the sport has become harder and faster. On court, players are more aggressive. 'You don't do all that training not to come out a winner,' says Kendra. 'But once the final whistle blows, you become a different person. We're all friendlier after the game.'

Netball is also taking a more scientific approach to fitness testing. 'It is essential that we all think and train like world-class players,' says Kendra. 'As captain, I think it's important to have a strong mental attitude and lead by example. I see my role as supporting and encouraging the rest of the team.'

'From the very beginning, my netball career has always been carefully planned,' she says. 'I decided some time ago that this competition would be the end of my playing career.' She will likely coach young players in the future, but right now, she is focused on her last big event. As she leads her team in the opening candlelight ceremony, she might have a tear in her eye. Her loyal supporters will be with her every step of the way.

**In Hot Water**

Rachel Mills is a scientist who spends a lot of time at the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean. She teaches and researches marine geochemistry, which means she studies the chemical processes in the sea. Rachel is a lecturer at the Oceanography Centre at Southampton University. When she isn't teaching, she goes into a steel vehicle, about the size of a small car, to dive three kilometers down into the Atlantic Ocean to study underwater volcanoes.

Inside the vehicle, space is very limited. Rachel can reach out and touch the two pilots. They are used to these conditions, which mean they can't stand up or move much, and they must stay inside until someone opens the door from the outside. A dive can last for 16 hours: three hours to reach the ocean floor, ten hours gathering rock and water samples, and then three hours to return to the surface.

If there is a problem and they need to get to the top quickly, they can hit a panic button. This releases a small escape vessel that goes rapidly to the surface, like a ping-pong ball in water. No one has tested it yet, but Rachel thinks it wouldn't be a pleasant journey.

Rachel didn't know how she would react the first time she climbed into the vehicle. It was on the deck of a ship, and she got in with an instructor. He explained the emergency procedures, including what to do if the pilot had a heart attack. They were testing her to see how she would react in such a small space. Now, Rachel has made six dives. Last year, she dived with a Russian crew. They went to a site five days' sail west of the Canary Islands in the Atlantic. Here, on the ocean floor, is a large area of underwater volcanoes, with chimneys blowing out black smoke. The Russian team was dropping off scientific equipment to study the effect of a program that would make a hole 150 meters through a volcano.

When she isn't at sea, Rachel is in her office at the Oceanography Centre, Southampton. Two-thirds of her salary comes from teaching, which she loves, but she does it so she can continue her research into the "black smokers." This is another name for underwater volcanoes, where water comes out of the rock and looks like black smoke. It pours out at a rate of one meter per second and at a temperature of 350 degrees.

The only time Rachel was frightened was when she first went down with the Americans. They were towing equipment on a 50-meter rope when suddenly there was an explosion. There was a loud bang as the shock waves hit their vehicle, and Rachel thought, "I'm going to die." They stared at each other in silence, waiting. When nothing happened, they couldn't believe it. The relief was incredible—they were still alive!

Diving to the deepest part of the ocean is such an adventure. Every time Rachel looks out of the porthole and sees those chimneys, she feels a sense of wonder. She is at the bottom of the sea, and no one else on this planet has ever seen them before. Rachel studied the black smokers for three years for her Ph.D. When she finally saw them for real, it was an amazing feeling.

**Interview Tips**

First impressions are very important. Studies show that people form opinions about us in the first few minutes of meeting. They notice how we dress, our eye contact, body movements, how fast or slow we talk, our volume and tone of voice, and the words we use.

Mary Pearce studied to be a teacher. She says, "I worked hard to earn my degree. When I graduated, I was very confident." She applied for a job at a nearby primary school and got an interview with the Head Teacher. "I noticed a small hole in my jacket that morning," she recalls. "I would have changed, but I knew it would make me late, and I always think it's important to be on time." Mary didn't get the job. Her friend, who also teaches at the school, told her the Head Teacher said, "If someone doesn't take the time to present her best image at an interview, what kind of teacher is she going to be?"

Simon Grant, a hotel manager, says, "Interviewees who look like they care about themselves are more likely to care about their jobs. People think it's what's inside that counts, but in an interview, you should aim to come across in the best possible way." Many people ignore the importance of having a professional image. For example, Janet Goodwood worked for ten years as an administrative assistant in a large accounting firm. When the office manager retired, she applied for the position but wasn't even given an interview. "I thought it was a mistake, so I asked the Director of Personnel what had happened," she says. "He told me I didn't fit the image of an office manager. He suggested I improve my wardrobe before I applied again for promotion. I was shocked. I do a very good job, and the way I dress shouldn't make any difference."

Movement and gestures also influence an interviewer's first impression. Psychologist Albert Mehrabian found that 7% of any message about our feelings and attitudes comes from the words we use, 38% from voice, and a surprising 55% from our facial expressions. When our facial expressions and words send different messages, the listener will believe the non-verbal message more. So make sure your words match your body language. Mixed messages will only confuse the interviewer.

It is also important not to appear too desperate for the job or too eager to please. When Sheila Rice, a marketing specialist, applied for a promotion, her interview went so well she was offered the job on the spot. "I was delighted," she recalls. "But I reacted with too much enthusiasm. Once the boss sensed how excited I was, he knew I wasn't going to turn him down. Consequently, he offered me a lower salary than I'd hoped for. I'm sure I could have got more if I had managed to control my excitement."

Finally, what we say and how we say it will contribute to the success of an interview. David Artesio, the manager of an employment agency, suggests that it's a good idea to learn about the company before you go for an interview. "The annual report, for example, will tell you about areas of company involvement. Mention an area that interests you during the interview. This will give a positive note and show your interest in the company." Business consultant Marian Woodall suggests you have a few questions ready and avoid speaking in long, confused sentences. As she puts it, "Poor communicators talk in paragraphs. Successful communicators talk in short sentences and even in highlighted points."

**A New Life**

**The Farmer**

Matt Froggatt used to work as an insurance agent in London, but now he runs a sheep farm. "After 14 years in business, the City became less exciting and more of a grind. I hadn't planned to leave for another five or ten years, but then I was made redundant unexpectedly. The pay-off wasn't great, but it was enough to start the farm. My big break came when I met the head chef of a local hotel with one of the top 20 hotel restaurants in the country. By supplying them, my reputation grew, and now I also sell meat by mail order. I'm glad I'm not stuck in an office anymore, but it's surprising how little has changed: I still work 80- to 90-hour weeks and sell a product."

**The Painter**

Ron Ablewhite was a manager in advertising but now earns a living as an artist. "Painting started as a hobby, but I found it more exciting than my job. Taking redundancy to become an artist seemed logical. The career counsellor I spoke to was surprised because most people in their mid-forties need to return to work quickly for financial reasons. But we married young, and our children didn't need our support. Moving to the north of England was a leap into the unknown. We left our friends, but our friendships have survived the distance, and many visit us now."

**The Hatmaker**

After working as a company lawyer for five years, Katherine Goodison started her own business making hats in her London flat. "Being a lawyer was fun and well-paid, but the hours were terrible. I didn't want to become a senior partner and work even more hours, so I left. Some people thought I'd get bored, but that hasn't happened. The secret is having deadlines. In fashion, there are always collections and seasons, so you need a strict schedule. I'm happier and less stressed now. I do miss socializing with colleagues, though. What I love about this job is being fully responsible for the product. If I do a bad job, it's on me. You care more when your name is on the promotional material."

**The Masseur**

Paul Drinkwater worked in finance for 16 years before becoming a masseur at the Life Centre in London. "I started in financial markets at 22, setting up deals. I liked the adrenaline but didn't find the work rewarding. I almost got made redundant in 1989, but I resigned and traveled for a year instead. During that year, I explored what I wanted to do. I was interested in health, so I visited top gymnasiums and talked to the owners. I knew I needed qualifications to change careers, so I took various massage courses. Then I got part-time work at the Life Centre. I have no regrets. I used to feel out of control, but now I have peace of mind and control over my future. That's the best part."

**Dedicated to Their Sports: Four Young Sports Stars Talk About Their Lives**

**A. Darius (Runner)**  
I've always loved sports. I tried many, but I was best at football and athletics. At 14, I had a chance to join a professional football club, but I chose athletics instead. My proudest moment was competing for my country in the youth team and winning a medal. Unfortunately, it didn't get much media attention, which was disappointing because I hoped for sponsorship to help with training costs. I train at home during winter and then go to Florida for three weeks before the season starts. It's fun because of the great facilities and nightlife, but I have to be disciplined. If friends invite me out before training, I have to say no. I wish I didn't have to, but dedication is important in this sport. My main goal is to reach the next Olympics, which would be amazing.

**B. Gabriel (Surfer)**  
The surfing community is small, so you often meet the same people at competitions. Professional surfers are serious, and the best waves are often at dawn, so you have to avoid late-night parties. I don't mind that much, but I do miss sleeping in. It's worth it, though, because without dedication, I might not have won the National Championships last year. After a win, I make sure to have a big night out, and if there's prize money, I treat myself to a nice trip. The sacrifices are worth it because winning the championship led to me presenting a surfing series on TV. I guess I'm a bit of a celebrity now.

**C. Dieter (Yacht Racer)**  
With five guys on a boat, we have a lot of fun. We're traditional and always celebrate a win in style. Some say we act childishly when we're out, but we don't seek media attention. Reporters often care more about our celebrations than our race results. I'm away for eight months a year, so it's nice to come back and hang out with friends from different backgrounds. You can't focus on the sport all the time—it's not healthy. I'm known in the sailing world, but I've only been recognized in public a few times. I'd hate to be a celebrity. I get nice letters asking for signed pictures, and I reply to each one, even if it takes time.

**D. Tomas (Tennis Player)**  
It's great to feel the crowd's support when I walk on court. At the last tournament, it got a bit crazy with people crowding around. Still, I enjoy being recognized by fans when I'm out shopping. It has downsides, though. My last girlfriend didn't like it when I got too much attention from female fans. Tennis players travel a lot, and that's why we broke up, I think. It was hard, but you have to make sacrifices in any sport; you have to be serious and professional. It doesn't bother me much. I'm happy to focus on my game now and enjoy other things in life after I retire, which happens early in this sport.

Title: Shopping with Children

Shopping in supermarkets with children can be very challenging for parents. One mother describes it as "absolute murder" because her children want everything they see, like sugary cereals, Disney videos, or comics. She can't afford all these things and feels guilty if she gives in to their demands. She also feels bad for saying no all the time and gets stressed even before leaving home. She tries to avoid taking them shopping but worries they won't learn how to make their own choices.

Research shows that children ask for something every two minutes during a supermarket trip. Over £150 million is spent each year on advertising aimed directly at children, mostly on TV. This amount is expected to grow, and supermarkets are where this advertising is most effective. Children often don't understand why their parents can't buy everything they want, and arguments about health don't seem convincing compared to the appealing ads.

Susan Dibb from the National Food Alliance says most parents care about what their children eat and have ideas about healthy food, though these ideas aren't always correct. It's good for parents and children to talk about food because if children only learn from TV ads, they get a biased view. Parents feel frustrated because they have to compete with advertisers and often end up disappointing their children.

The Independent Television Commission, which oversees TV ads, doesn't allow advertisers to tell children to ask their parents to buy things. However, as Dibb notes, the goal of advertising is to persuade people to buy, so the effect is the same.

Deciding which of their children's requests to agree to or refuse can be stressful for parents. One mother says she talks a lot with her children about food and advertisements, which has helped reduce conflicts in the supermarket. Her son is now critical of ads, and they spend time looking at product labels together.

Parents admit they are sometimes inconsistent in their responses. Mike, a father of two, says he refuses to buy sweets for his son because they are unhealthy, even though he buys treats for himself. He finds it hard to be consistent and says his decisions depend on his mood.

Supermarkets could help reduce conflicts by removing sweets from checkout areas or providing play areas for children. Although parents might spend less without their children, the idea of shopping without their demands could attract more customers.

**Five-star luxury meets modern technology**

The five-star Merrion Hotel has just opened in Dublin. It took nearly two years to convert four large 18th-century houses into this hotel. This transformation allowed the installation of the latest technology for both staff and guests. General Manager Peter MacCann wants his staff to know guests by name, but he uses the hotel's computer system to remember guests' preferences. This system, which cost £250,000, helps treat returning guests in a special way, as expected in a five-star hotel. MacCann is very pleased with its efficiency. For example, if a guest requests certain music CDs during their first stay, those CDs will be ready for them on their next visit. This is possible because of the guest-history feature that records preferences.

Room temperature is a common complaint among hotel guests worldwide. The Merrion has a high-tech system to control this. Guests can adjust the temperature within three degrees of the normal 18°C, and the front desk can set it between 14°C and 25°C. However, guests are most impressed by the technology in their rooms, especially business travelers. MacCann expects 65% of his business to come from this market. To meet their needs, the hotel has put a business center in each room. Every room has three phones, two phone lines, a fax machine that also works as a photocopier and printer, and a video-conferencing facility.

Technology changes quickly, so the hotel has prepared for future upgrades. Extra cables are in place for new advancements. TVs are rented, not bought, so they can be easily updated. DVD recorders can also be upgraded when needed. Despite all this modern equipment, MacCann ensures that guests do not feel overwhelmed by technology. The 145 bedrooms are large, well-furnished, comfortable, and welcoming. The hotel also has a swimming pool, gym, six conference rooms, two bars, two restaurants, and a beautiful garden.

As with all luxury hotels, the food must be excellent. Chef Patrick Guilbaud, whose Dublin restaurant already had two Michelin stars, moved his restaurant to the Merrion. This move benefits both him and the hotel. He designed a new, modern kitchen and enjoys better parking facilities. The hotel benefits by offering a popular and successful dining option without financial risks. With the help of technology and a skilled staff, the Merrion is set to succeed.

**Where I Get My Energy**

Emma Marsden asked six women who live life to the fullest to share their secrets.

**A. Jeanette Kupfermann, Journalist and Author:**  
"I think it's excitement. I need to be doing something challenging. When I'm learning something new, I feel a lot of energy. Anything with rhythm gives me energy too—right now, I'm learning flamenco dancing. Dance is wonderful, very expressive, and energizing. I think you can feel tired if you're bored or feel life is pointless. Being effective in the world, even in a small way, gives you energy."

**B. Linda Kelsey, Magazine Editor:**  
"I have a lot of work, but I enjoy it all—I love being at work, it isn't a chore. If you enjoy something, it doesn't make you feel down, even if you're tired. I need a good amount of sleep, so when I get it, I feel great. When I only get six hours of sleep a night, I feel a bit off. I know exercise gives me energy, but it's hard to find the energy to do it! I do a yoga class once a week before work and try to do a workout tape at home. But if I've exercised, my mood improves a lot. I feel low in the office between 3 and 5 in the afternoon, so I think it's good to eat something then."

**C. Annie Nightingale, Disc Jockey:**  
"I don't eat healthily to get my energy—I think it's natural enthusiasm and being positive. I can't stand people with negative attitudes. I'm quite naive—I think we should all enjoy our lives and seize the moment. Enjoyment comes first. You have to achieve things and set goals. I enjoy what I do, and the last two years have been very exciting. In my job, there are lots of lively young people, and you can't help but be affected by that. I love rushing around for work, having a busy life. I'm very sociable. I enjoy taking photos, but I'm not sure if I'm good at it. I rush to get them developed and can't wait to see them. I've also started writing words for imaginary songs—it's just for fun and a good way to relax my mind when I'm traveling."

**D. Floella Benjamin, Author and Children's TV Presenter:**  
"My energy comes from the things I do and enjoy. I believe in what I'm doing, both at work and at home with my family, and I think being positive about life helps. That's why I love working with kids—they give so much and have a natural resilience. Energy is like a natural chemical, triggered by communicating with others—just try smiling at people and feel the thrill when they smile back. It's much better than feeling sorry for yourself. Although I try to eat healthily and don't smoke or drink, I don't have an exercise plan. The most energetic I get is running around and playing with the kids."

**E. Deborah Moggach, Author and Playwright:**  
"What I love doing more than anything is making a garden out of a wasteland. I did that once. The garden was solid concrete—I broke up all the concrete and added lots of soil. It was better than any workout or tennis. Another thing that gives me energy is knowing someone wants to read what I'm writing—I find it hard to write without an audience. I also like sneaking into a farmer's land or a wood. If I'm caught, I say, 'Oh, what a wonderful wood, I didn't know it was private property,' and so on. I like it because it's childlike."

**F. Katherine Monblot, Therapist:**  
"I believe you must have an interest in and respect for what you do in life. I like to take risks and get bored quickly, which keeps me motivated. Doing things you don't want to do wears you out. I used to be on various committees and resented the demands they made on my time. You only have a certain amount of energy, so direct it into the things that are most important to you."

**ICE SKATING**

Ice skating has been around for thousands of years. Archaeologists have found skates made from animal bones. These bone skates were used until iron was introduced in Scandinavia around 200 AD. In Scandinavia, the upper classes considered skating an important skill. In the early 1900s, skating was elegant and reserved. However, at the 1924 Winter Olympics, 11-year-old Sonja Henie brought a more athletic style, making skating more popular. Today, skating combines art and athletics, making it both graceful and physically challenging.

For beginners, balance and control are crucial, and speed comes with practice. Your body position is important for balance. Keep your legs slightly bent and knees bent to center your body weight; this means leaning slightly forward. Relaxation is very important in skating. To start, your heels should almost touch, and your feet should point outwards. Push forward with your back foot and make a small movement with the other foot. It seems simple, right? As you practice, you can slowly make your movements longer.

Learning how to fall is one of the first skills for skaters. Even the best professionals fall. To avoid injury, try to stay relaxed when you fall. This reduces the impact when you hit the ice. To get up, use your hands to kneel, then stand. Once you can move confidently on the ice, you can try different styles like figure skating, freestyle, distance, speed, and pair skating. The best way to start is by learning figure skating and then basic freestyle. Most ice rinks offer guidance to help you learn the basic moves, and soon you can try turns, jumps, and spins.

If you watch good or professional skaters, you will see how relaxed they are and how smoothly they move. To achieve this, you should regularly practice exercises. Skating with a stiff body can be dangerous, so warm-up exercises should include those for the legs, back, and shoulders, focusing on the ankles and knees. After a long or intense session, do the same exercises to prevent stiffness.

Skating improves balance, coordination, relaxation, and movement. It also benefits heart and lung health and strengthens the body. Combined with swimming or jogging, it offers a great program for overall health and fitness.

**Trills and Triumphs**

Seeing a talented child win a medal can be very emotional. Julia Gregson spoke to three young stars and their mothers about the joys and challenges in their lives.

**A. Annika Reeder, 15,** won a gold medal in gymnastics at the Commonwealth Games. She wants to become a physiotherapist and compete in the next Olympics. "The work is very hard right now. I don't have time to watch TV, hang out with friends, or do much besides gymnastics and school. I try to take each training day as it comes. When I'm extremely tired, my coach sometimes gives me a day off, but usually, I just keep going. You can't take too many days off, or you get stiff."

**B. Annika's mother** says, "Annika showed great potential from a young age. I've seen parents try to push their kids, and it doesn't work. To perform at Annika's level, you have to want it yourself. People often say we've given up a lot, but they don't see what the sport has given us. We love it and what it's done for Annika. Before gymnastics, she was a shy girl who sucked her thumb and hid behind me. Now, she's met people from all over the world and gained confidence."

**C. Sarah Stokes** started show-jumping at ten and has won the British National Championship. "It's good my parents like show-jumping because they train me and take me everywhere in the horse box. Shows last from one to five days. I never get tired of it—I love the excitement and fun. Even without my parents, I would do it because I'm determined. I'm glad they are happy when I win, but I'm not doing it for them. My goal this year is to qualify for the British young riders (under-18) team. My big dream is to win a gold medal at the Olympics."

**D. Sarah's mother** says, "Sarah's passion for horses started when she was 1. At 5, she would get up early to exercise her pony. To qualify for major shows, you have to compete all over England. To save money, we sleep in the horse box. Sarah is well-organized and 100% happy on a horse. Watching your child succeed at something they love is unbeatable."

**E. Jane McShane, 10,** is Britain's Under-14 Chess Champion. "Tournaments are really friendly. I know everyone, and it's fun. When I play, I don't concentrate much. I should, but I just look around and don't think too hard. I'm not worried about getting a big head; I don't talk about my success at school. I don't like being embarrassed."

**F. Jane's mother** says, "Jane played her first game at 5. My father suggested it, and she loved it from the start. By the end of that day, she knew all the moves, and by 6, she was beating adults. Of course, I'm pleased when she wins, but if she wanted to quit tomorrow, I wouldn't stop her. I don't want to discourage her because she's exceptional. If she has this gift, she should reach her potential."

Text: 'It's true - we're all getting taller Chris Greener was fourteen when he told his careers teacher he wanted to join the navy after school. 'What do you want to be?' asked the teacher. 'The flagpole on a ship?' The teacher had a point because Chris, even at fourteen, was almost two metres tall. Today, at 228 cm, he is Britain's tallest man. Every decade, the average height of people in Europe increases by another centimetre. Each year, more very tall people are born. Interestingly, this doesn't mean we are creating a new super race. Instead, we are returning to our original size from the time of the cavemen. We are now overcoming the effects of generations of poor diet, with significant results. 'We are only now beginning to reach our true potential,' says palaeontologist Professor Chris Stringer. 'We are becoming like the Cro-Magnons again - the people who lived on this planet 40,000 years ago.' For most of human history, our ancestors got their food from many sources: women gathered herbs, fruits, and berries, while men hunted animals occasionally. This lifestyle is still followed by the few remaining tribes of hunter-gatherers. One study found that they based their diet on 85 different wild plants. Then, about 9,000 years ago, agriculture was invented, which had serious consequences. Most of the planet's green areas have been taken over by farmers, and now just three carbohydrate-rich plants - wheat, rice, and maize - provide more than half of the calories consumed by humans today. This poor diet has negatively affected human health and physique. Over the centuries, we have lived on soups, porridges, and breads that have left us underfed and underdeveloped. In one study in Ohio, scientists found that when people started growing corn, healthy hunter-gatherers became sickly, underweight farmers. Tooth decay increased, as did diseases. Far from being a blessing of the New World, corn was a public health disaster, according to some anthropologists. However, agriculture spread because a piece of farmed land could support ten times the number of people who had previously lived off it as hunter-gatherers. The fact that most people relying on this system are poorly nourished and stunted has only recently been addressed, even by the world's wealthier nations. Only in Europe, the US, and Japan are diets now reflecting the richness of our ancestors' diets. As a result, the average man in the US is now 179 cm, in Holland 180 cm, and in Japan 177 cm. It is a positive trend, though not without its own problems. Heights may have increased, but the world has not changed much. A standard bed-length has remained at 190 cm since 1860. Even worse, leg-room in planes and trains seems to have decreased, while clothes manufacturers are constantly having to update their range of products. The question is: where will it all end? We cannot grow forever. We must have some programmed upper limit. But what is it? According to Robert Fogel, of University, it could be as much as 193 cm - and we are likely to reach it sometime this century. However, scientists add one note of caution. Individuals may be growing taller because of better nutrition, but as a species, we are actually shrinking. During the last ice age, 10,000 years ago, humans were slightly rounder and taller - an evolutionary response to the cold. (Large, round bodies are best at keeping in heat.) Since the climate warmed, we appear to have become slightly thinner and smaller, even when properly fed. And as the planet continues to heat up, we may shrink even further. In other words, the growth of human beings could be offset by global warming.'

**Studio Audiences: What’s it Like?**

Have you ever wondered what it's like to be in the audience when a TV show is being filmed? Cosmo Landesman explored this experience. Studio audiences are a regular part of TV production, but they remain a mystery to many of us. When we see them excited on game shows, we might wonder: who are these people?

Studio audiences are often seen as the least prestigious of all live entertainment audiences. Some people in the TV industry even look down on them, treating them poorly. I used to think that studio audiences were just people eager for a brief moment of fame. However, there is no typical studio audience. They come from all walks of life, including different classes, jobs, and income levels. TV shows try to attract various types of people for different programs.

For those of us who enjoy watching TV at home, it can be hard to understand why someone would want to watch a show in a studio. Why go through the trouble of getting tickets, traveling, and sitting for hours in an uncomfortable studio when you can watch the same show at home? One idea is that people hope to appear on TV, even if just for a moment. I didn’t believe this until I met Angela, who said she came for the chance to be on TV. Another reason might be curiosity about what happens behind the scenes. But the most common reason I heard was simply that a friend gave them a ticket.

Most of us have never been in a studio audience, but we think we know what it’s like. You imagine sitting tightly packed with strangers, following signs that tell you when to clap or laugh. This might be true for some shows, but not all. A studio manager said, "We always hope a show is good enough not to need these signs."

Is there a real difference between watching a show in a studio and watching it at home? For Claire, being in a studio is "more exciting," and Charlotte enjoyed feeling involved with live TV. "Last year I saw my favorite comedian. Watching him live was different from seeing him on TV at home," she said. Personally, I missed seeing the live actors because my view was blocked. The opening scenes were so far away that I ended up watching them on a studio monitor.

Going to a studio might not be the best way to watch TV, but that’s not the main point. For most of the audience, it was simply a fun and free night of entertainment.

**Favourite Places**

**Bruce**  
I don't like landscapes that are completely wild. I find the human element important. It's the same when I travel abroad. I am attracted to lovely villages with old temples, not empty deserts. When I was eight, I went to school in England. On Saturdays, I would cycle to the village of Lastingham in its beautiful valley. Cycling was a way to escape school. I loved exploring the bleak hilltops, the sheltered valleys, and old villages. Coming from Scotland, I found the landscape familiar yet different, and I still visit today. I used to write about my adventures in my private diary. In a way, that was my first attempt at travel writing, which later became my career.

**Sophia**  
There is a miniature railway that goes from Hythe to Dungeness, run by amateurs. I always travel first class as it doesn't cost much more than the regular fare. The scenery is not spectacular. The train moves across Romney Marsh with its sheep and alongside a canal. But there is one part of the journey I always look forward to - when our miniature world takes a detour through back gardens. For a few moments, we passengers see people at random points in their day, making a cup of tea, doing the washing up, unfolding a deckchair. I see myself in their eyes, a woman in a tiny train carriage, looking into other people's homes. It's the ordinariness of the landscape that attracts me. Just fields, sheep, and a distant grey sea. That makes me look more closely, to search for something that opens my eyes.

**Matthew**  
The Hartland Peninsula is a remote and beautiful coast. The beaches are hard to reach and scattered with rocks, so there are not many crowds here. They attract a few brave surfers, but most visitors prefer to reflect on the majesty of the sea. The coast, which faces the Atlantic, is known for shipwrecks. There are coast walks you can combine with trips inland up beautiful damp valleys, full of oak trees, ferns, and wildflowers. We stay in modest self-catering accommodation with a family who have some property in the village of Southole.

**Annette**  
My favourite place in England is the Trough of Bowland, a landscape of wide-open moorland perfect for hiking. There are not many residents and not many visitors either. It's an unknown corner, empty and remote, and I like the feeling of space. I discovered the area by chance when I was a student, and since then I've made an annual visit, either alone, with my boyfriend, or now with my son. It has changed little since my first visit. Having a child makes these visits more special. It makes me sad that he's growing up in an urban environment.

**James**  
I bought Glenthorne, my favourite house in Britain. It was about finding pure peace and reconnecting with my English roots and coming home. I grew up in what is now known as Sri Lanka, but at the age of twelve, I went to school in Devon, in the west of England. I used to cycle around the moors and village backstreets. We had a story about a place we would never cycle past: if you went down the driveway, you'd never return. That place was Glenthorne. It's the place of my dreams. It's a magical, secluded, romantic house. You can't hear anything except the sea, wind, and birds.

**HAPPY HUNTING GROUND**

We are a family that loves animals and enjoys being around them. One afternoon, my daughter called me at work to tell me she had found a wonderful pine snake. "Can we keep him?" she asked. I agreed, but only for one night. We had a special tank ready for such temporary guests, and one night was enough to admire them and look them up in our natural history book.

I got home late and quickly started boiling a pot of water when I heard screams from my sons' bedroom: "Oh, Mother! Help! Do something!" I rushed in to find Domino, our cat, with Bianca, a white mouse given to me as a Mother's Day gift, in his mouth. Domino was running around the room, trying to find a way to enjoy his catch, while avoiding the children’s waving arms. I jumped into the chaos and tripped, landing on the floor. As I thought about stopping Domino, I noticed the snake was escaping from its tank.

The room was a mess of cat, mouse, kids, and snake, with the dog barking loudly. I quickly turned off the boiling pot in the kitchen and returned to the chaos. I managed to grab Domino by the tail and rescued the mouse, which was unharmed. Interestingly, this mouse was caught by the cat three more times but eventually died of old age.

Feeling confident after saving the mouse, I turned my attention to the snake. It was not easy to handle. I sat on the floor like a snake-charmer, trying to calm it down. Slowly, the snake relaxed, and I carefully lifted it. I took it to the end of the garden and pointed it towards a tree, hoping it would choose to live there. But when I let go of its head, it slid over my shoulders like a shawl, seeming comfortable.

We stood there in the evening light, my four children, the snake, and I. My eldest, DJ, broke the silence with a scientific observation: "You know what it is, Mum? You're nice and warm, and the shed isn't." We gently encouraged the snake to move on, and it slowly climbed up the wall and disappeared over the roof. As the last bit of its tail vanished, my three-year-old, Clay, summed it up for all of us: "Boy, that was one big snake!"

Text: 'Drop me a line! In our fast world of phones, fax machines, and computers, the old-fashioned art of letter writing is at risk of disappearing. Yet, for me, receiving a letter is special in a way that no other form of communication can match. There is the excitement of its arrival, the pleasure of seeing who it is from, and the enjoyment of reading it. Letter writing has been part of my life for as long as I can remember. It probably started with the little notes I would write to my mother. My mother also always insisted I write my own thank-you letters for Christmas and birthday presents. It didn't matter how short or untidy they were, as long as they were letters. When I left home at 18 to study medicine in London, I would write once a week, and so would my mother. Occasionally, my father would write, and it was always a joy to receive his long, funny letters. Most of the letters from home were about everyday events concerning my parents and their friends. Of course, we also made phone calls, but it is the letters I remember most. There were also letters from my boyfriends. In my youth, I seemed to attract people who had to work or study away, and I could only stay in touch by writing. But instead of harming the relationships, letter writing seemed to improve them. I found that I could often express myself more easily in writing than by talking. I love the letters that come with birthday or Christmas cards. Notes are appreciated, but how much better to have a year's supply of news! And it's even better when it's an airmail envelope with beautiful stamps. My overseas letters arrive from Mangala in Sri Lanka, from someone I trained with over 20 years ago, and I have a penfriend in Australia and another in Vancouver. Then there's the lady who writes to me from France. If we hadn't started talking in a restaurant on the way home from holiday, if my husband hadn't taken her photo, and if I hadn't asked her for her address, I would never have been able to write to her. More importantly, if she hadn't replied, we would be the poorer for it. As it is, we now have a regular correspondence. I can improve my French (she speaks no English); we have stayed at her home twice, and she has stayed with us. My biggest letter-writing success, however, came this summer when my family and I stayed with my American penfriend in Texas. We had been corresponding for 29 years but had never met. Everyone was amazed that a correspondence could last so long. The local press even considered the correspondence worth reporting on the front page. I am pleased that my children are continuing the tradition. Like my mother before me, I insist they write their own thank-you letters. My daughter writes me little letters, just as I did to my mother. She and my son have penfriends of their own in Texas, organized by my penfriend. I strongly urge readers not to let letter writing become another 'lost art'. '

**Careless Tourists Damage Ancient Alpine Rock Art**

Tens of thousands of ancient pictures carved into rocks at one of France's most important tourist sites are being gradually destroyed. Scientists and researchers are worried that the 36,000 drawings on rocks in Mont Bego in the French Alps are being damaged so quickly that they might not survive for future generations. The mountain, once a place for prayer and worship, has 4,000-year-old drawings on bare rock. These include pictures of cows with horns, cultivated fields, and various gods and goddesses. However, as more people visit the site, the pictures are being ruined by careless graffiti.

Jean Clottes, the chairman of the International Committee on Rock Art, says, "People think that because the pictures have been there so long, they will always be there. But if the damage continues at this rate, there will be nothing left in 50 years." He has seen tourists stepping on the drawings, wearing away the rock and the details of the artwork. Some visitors even break off parts to take home as souvenirs. "When people can't take a good enough photograph, they rub the drawings to get a clearer picture," he said. "The drawings are polished by the weather, and if the sun is shining and visitors can't see them properly, they simply rub and scrape them to make them look fresher."

Other researchers describe how people arrive with long sticks with sharp ends to scratch their own drawings or even their names into the rocks. But experts disagree on the best way to protect the drawings. Henry de Lumley, director of the Museum of Natural History in Paris, believes the only way to save the site is to make the whole mountain a 'no-go' area, allowing the public to visit only on guided tours. Otherwise, he says, the site will be completely destroyed, and important research work will be reduced.

Clottes disagrees. "The measure proposed by Henry de Lumley is the most severe, and while it is the most effective, it is also certain to bring about protests from people who live there," he said. "The site was classified as a historic monument years ago by the Ministry of Culture, and we must do as much as possible to save what is there."

David Lavergne, the regional architect, also wants to avoid closing the site. "Henry de Lumley's idea isn't ideal," he said. "Our department feels that the best solution is to let people look at the site, but because the area is very big, it is difficult to prevent visitors from damaging it. I would prefer that everyone was able to look at it, but the main problem is financial. We do not have the funds to employ the necessary number of guards. We may have to consider charging a fee. There seems to be no prospect of government funding."

In Nice, Annie Echassoux, who also worked on researching the site, is worried that as the mountain becomes easier to reach—tourists can now avoid the three-and-a-half-hour walk by hiring vehicles—the damage will increase quickly. She thinks the only solution is to rope off the area and provide guides. "You can't say the plan can't go ahead because there is no money," she said. "That is not good enough. Money must be provided because the Ministry of Culture has classified this area as a historic site. If we don't take steps, we will be responsible for losing the drawings for the next generation."

Title: Shopping with Children

Shopping in supermarkets with children can be very challenging for parents. One mother describes it as "absolute murder" because her children want everything they see, like sugary cereals, Disney videos, or comics. She can't afford all these things and feels guilty if she gives in to their demands. She also feels bad for saying no all the time and gets stressed even before leaving home. She tries to avoid taking them shopping but worries they won't learn how to make their own choices.

Research shows that children ask for something every two minutes during a supermarket trip. Over £150 million is spent each year on advertising aimed directly at children, mostly on TV. This amount is expected to grow, and supermarkets are where this advertising is most effective. Children often don't understand why their parents can't buy everything they want, and arguments about health don't seem convincing compared to the appealing ads.

Susan Dibb from the National Food Alliance says most parents care about what their children eat and have ideas about healthy food, though these ideas aren't always correct. It's good for parents and children to talk about food because if children only learn from TV ads, they get a biased view. Parents feel frustrated because they have to compete with advertisers and often end up disappointing their children.

The Independent Television Commission, which oversees TV ads, doesn't allow advertisers to tell children to ask their parents to buy things. However, as Dibb notes, the goal of advertising is to persuade people to buy, so the effect is the same.

Deciding which of their children's requests to agree to or refuse is a major source of stress for parents. One mother says she discusses food with her children and has taught her son to be critical of ads. They now have fewer conflicts in the supermarket because her children don't ask for things she won't buy.

Parents admit they are sometimes inconsistent in their responses. Mike, a father of two, says they refuse to buy sweets for their son because they're unhealthy, while they buy treats for themselves. He finds it hard to be consistent and says his decisions depend on his mood.

Supermarkets could help reduce conflicts by removing sweets from checkout areas or providing play areas for children. Although parents might spend less without their children, the idea of shopping without their demands could attract more customers.

**Going up the wall**

In the past, climbers went to mountains. Now, challenging climbs can happen anywhere, indoors or outdoors. The crowd watches closely. High above them on the climbing wall, hanging upside down by just two fingers, is the French climber Francois Lombard. He is competing in the World Cup Climbing Championships at Birmingham's National Indoor Arena. This arena is more famous for the TV show Gladiators, but both the show and the climbing championships have one thing in common - The Wall. The fact that these events are possible is due to new and fast-developing technology.

Before the mid-1960s, climbers practiced on cliffs where there were many good climbing spots. In winter, they either braved the cold, went walking, or climbed on snow and ice in Scotland. As the sport grew, it became important for top climbers to stay fit. Since cliffs were unusable for much of the year, they used brick edges or stone buildings to train. This helped them keep their fingers strong and avoid boredom from not climbing.

Soon, many sports centers started building walls specifically for climbing, using bricks with special edges to hold onto. Many of these early walls followed the example of Don Robinson, a physical education teacher who, in the mid-1960s, built a climbing wall in a corridor at Leeds University. Robinson had the idea of setting natural rock in concrete blocks, which could be part of a wall. Many climbing walls like this were built in sports halls across the country during the 1970s, but they had design problems. Walls could only be vertical, while real cliffs have features like overhangs and angled rock slabs. Another issue was that once the walls were built, they couldn't be changed, and climbers would get bored with the same holds.

In 1985, a Frenchman named Francois Savigny developed a material that he shaped into forms like those found on cliffs. These could be attached to any wall and removed when climbers wanted a new challenge. French manufacturers also started experimenting with panels on a steel framework. Concrete was too heavy for overhanging walls without major construction, but steel frames could be set up anywhere as free-standing structures. A system of interchangeable fixtures gave climbers endless new holds.

Text: 'So you want to be an actor? If you tell someone that you want to be an actor, they will probably say it is 'risky' very quickly. And acting is indeed a risky career. There are more actors than there are jobs for them. When you decide to become an actor, some people you thought were your friends might say you're crazy, but others might react differently. Everyone will give you different advice. But it is a personal choice, and only you can be responsible for achieving your dream. There are no easy ways to succeed - no exams to pass, and no guarantee that after your training you will succeed in the profession. It's all about luck and talent. However, there is a need for new faces and talent, and there is always the chance of excitement, glamour, and sometimes big rewards. People often ask me to define talent, which everyone is looking for. I think it is natural skill plus imagination - imagination is the hardest to judge. It also involves courage and belief in what you are doing and how you present it. Why do people want to act? It is often hard to explain why you want to act. In theatre, the important thing is the moment of connection between the actor and the audience. This connection is central to all acting and motivates actors. If you ask actors how they succeeded, they might just shrug. They don't know. They know some things about themselves and their techniques and others' techniques. But they take nothing for granted because they know they are only as good as their current job, and their fame might not last. Disappointment is the biggest enemy of an actor. Last month you might have been out of work, selling clothes or waitressing. Suddenly you are asked to audition for a role, but even if you want the job, you might not get it. So actors often don't talk about their chances. They find ways to protect themselves from the stress of competing for a role and the possibility of rejection. Nobody likes being rejected. And remember, the possibility of rejection is there from the moment you start auditioning professionally. You are saying you are available, willing, and hopefully talented enough for the job. And, in many ways, it's up to you, because if you don't care enough, no one else will care for you.'

**Food for Everyone**

We are excited to share our special selection of top cookbook titles now available.

**A. Delia Smith**

When people think of a famous TV cook and writer, Delia Smith often comes to mind. Her recipes come from around the world and show her love for exciting food. She understands what the average cook can do in a regular kitchen. Her book, *Delia Smith's Complete Cookery Course*, is a must-have for modern cooks. It offers simple yet expert advice on both basic and advanced cooking, along with hundreds of excellent recipes. Recently updated, it remains the go-to book for anyone asking, "If I could only have one cookbook, which would it be?"

**B. Raymond Blanc**

Raymond Blanc went from being an amateur, untrained chef to owning the most famous French restaurant in Britain in just 15 years. His first TV series, *Blanc Mange*, now has a companion book. Raymond aims to make us better cooks by showing how and why ingredients behave as they do. He believes good cooking is easy when you understand what's happening in the pan. The book includes over 80 impressive recipes and explains why some dishes might fail, introducing basic food chemistry to help. Raymond loves cooking to entertain, and this book shows he's excellent at it.

**C. Le Cordon Bleu**

Le Cordon Bleu is synonymous with the best in classical French cooking. For over 100 years, this famous cooking school has trained students to achieve perfection. To celebrate its centenary, the *Le Cordon Bleu Classic French Cookbook* presents 100 of the school's most respected recipes. While the recipes are classics, they remain fresh and have adapted to reduce calories. The book starts with kitchen basics and continues with sections on Appetisers, Main dishes, and Desserts. Each recipe is illustrated with step-by-step images and beautiful photos of the finished dishes. Expert chefs from Cordon Bleu schools worldwide have shared their famous recipes and secrets.

**D. Nigel Slater**

Fast food? Not necessarily bad! Nigel Slater, food editor of *The Observer*, challenges the idea that good food requires long cooking times. His book, *The 30-Minute Cook*, shows that fast food can be delicious. Nigel believes you can make something tasty in the time it takes to deliver a pizza. This new book offers over 200 recipes from around the world, all ready in 30 minutes. Written in his enjoyable style, Nigel proves that fast food can also be great food. If you're skeptical, try his recipes—they're simply delicious.

**A New Life**

**The Farmer**

Matt Froggatt used to work as an insurance agent in London, but now he runs a sheep farm. "After 14 years in business, the City became less exciting and more of a grind. I hadn't planned to leave for another five or ten years, but I was suddenly made redundant. The pay-off wasn't great, but it was enough to start the farm. My big break came when I met the head chef of a local hotel with one of the top 20 hotel restaurants in the country. By supplying them, my reputation grew, and now I also sell meat by mail order. I'm glad I'm not stuck in an office anymore, but it's surprising how little has changed: I still work 80- to 90-hour weeks and sell a product."

**The Painter**

Ron Ablewhite was a manager in advertising but now earns a living as an artist. "Painting started as a hobby, but I found it more exciting than my job. Taking redundancy to become an artist seemed logical. The career counsellor I spoke to was surprised because most people in their mid-forties need to get back to work quickly for financial reasons. But we married young, and our children didn't need our support. Moving to the north of England was a leap into the unknown. We left our friends, but our friendships have survived the distance, and many visit us now."

**The Hatmaker**

Katherine Goodison worked as a company lawyer for five years before starting her own business making hats in her London flat. "Being a lawyer was fun and well-paid, but the hours were terrible. I didn't want to become a senior partner and work even more hours, so I left. Some people thought I'd get bored, but that hasn't happened. The key is having deadlines. In fashion, there's always something to do, so I keep a strict schedule. I'm happier and less stressed now. I do miss socializing with colleagues, though. What I love about this job is being fully responsible for the product. If I do a bad job, it's on me. You care more when your name is on the promotional material."

**The Masseur**

Paul Drinkwater worked in finance for 16 years before becoming a masseur at the Life Centre in London. "I started in financial markets at 22, setting up deals. I liked the adrenaline but didn't find the work rewarding. I almost got made redundant in 1989, but I resigned and traveled for a year to figure out what I wanted to do. I was interested in health, so I visited top gymnasiums and talked to the owners. I knew I needed qualifications to change careers, so I took massage courses. Then I got part-time work at the Life Centre. I have no regrets. I used to feel out of control, but now I have peace of mind and control over my future. That's the best part."

**Onto a Winner**

Two brothers are discovering that a childhood game is great for business. Dave and Norm Lagasse, two brothers in their forties with bushy beards, are in their simple home in Santa Fe, New Mexico, USA, remembering their childhood. In front of them is a wooden board with round plastic pieces. They are playing the old game of pichenotte, which they say is unique. Their grandfather, Lucien Rajotte, a grocer from Quebec, Canada, brought the game to the USA and taught it to his family. Soon, the family played the game almost every weekend and holiday, and as Dave says, they were 'having the best time ever'. Eventually, the family moved to New Mexico. But they didn't forget Grandpa's pichenotte board, made from old wooden food crates, and continued to play often. Visitors were often curious because the game was unknown in southern USA. 

Three years ago, Dave noticed the old pichenotte board was cracked and worn, so he decided to make a new one. It turned out beautifully. A relative saw it and wanted one, then a friend wanted another. To see how much interest there was, the brothers took one of Dave's new boards to a sports bar in Santa Fe. 'People started to watch,' says Dave, 'and said, "No way I'm playing that silly game." But then they'd sit down, and soon you couldn't get them up from the table!' When people asked about the game's origins, Dave researched and found its roots were likely in India, with a similar game called 'carroms'. This was adapted into a game called 'squails' played in British pubs, and a century ago, British emigrants brought it to Canada. Pichenotte is the French-Canadian version that developed in Quebec.

Pichenotte, played by two to four people, is a game of skill. Each player gets 12 pieces or 'pucks'. These are 'flicked' across a wheel-like board using one hand's middle or index finger. Flicking a puck into a small hole scores 20 points. Three rings around the hole score 15, 10, and 5 points. Eight tiny posts are obstacles. The game usually lasts just two minutes.

Seeing the game's popularity at the Santa Fe bar, the Lagasses made more boards and took them to markets and craft fairs. Crowds gathered, money was exchanged, and the game's popularity grew. Championships started, and a trophy called the 'Lord Pichenotte Cup' was created. As word spread, the boards sold quickly. The brothers decided to make pichenotte their full-time business. They set up a workshop in their garage and started making boards. Over 450 have been made so far. Made of birchwood and mahogany, each board weighs 12kg and is 1cm thick. Norm explains, 'They're very durable, as they have to stand up to lots of use.' They sell for $595 each on the brothers' website. There are no professional pichenotte players or TV coverage yet, but the brothers hope their garage will one day house a luxury car instead of tools and wood. Until then, they enjoy playing the game they hope will make them successful.

**WELCOME TO THE MODEL VILLAGE**

When you first enter the Model Village, it's hard to believe that a few years ago, this was just a piece of unused land, flat and covered with wild plants. For a long time, people thought it was worthless. However, one man's careful planning and hard work, with constant support from his wife, transformed this land into the beautiful place you see today. Many thousands of tons of soil and clay were moved to change the flat land into the shaped landscape you see now. Although machines like bulldozers helped, a lot of hard work was also needed. After shaping the land, about 1,000 tonnes of topsoil were added to create the lawns, flower beds, and rock gardens.

Hundreds of trees and shrubs were planted in the Model Village. These plants had to be chosen carefully because they needed to survive the salty air near the sea and the strong winter winds. Most plants came from local garden centers, but some were brought from as far as Canada and New Zealand.

The whole village was the idea of Colin Sims, who made over 100 models by himself over nine years, starting from when the village opened in 1972. The models are made from different materials like stone, concrete, specially treated wood, and plastics to withstand all weather conditions. At first, Colin needed help from experts to understand how different materials would last in changing weather, but he soon became an expert himself.

You will notice that all models are made to a constant scale, with great attention to detail. This was achieved through patience and unique construction techniques. The Model Village is a popular attraction, known for its high-quality workmanship and maintenance. The techniques used here have been applied in other model villages in England and are even taught in some college courses on modeling.

All the model buildings in the village show traditional British architectural styles and are not based on any specific place or structure. One of the most impressive buildings is the Manor House, a typical 13th-century stone structure with a brick tower and stone walls, inspired by manor houses in the West Country. As you walk around, you will also see the Castle, St Mary's Church, a zoo, and a mini golf course, which is the newest addition.

Please stay on the paths during your visit and do not touch the models; a small mistake can mean hours of repair work for us. You can take photos from the paths, and dogs are welcome if they are on a short lead. To enhance your experience, you will find buttons in front of some working models. Press these to see the models in action.

At the end of your visit, we would love to hear your comments. We are always planning new models, and your ideas can help us create a more varied and interesting display. We also want to know if any models did not meet the high standards of the rest of the village. We are constantly updating and replacing models, so your feedback is important.

We hope you enjoy your visit and look forward to seeing you again. Don't forget to tell your friends about us.

Week after week, British tabloid newspapers publish pictures that invade people's privacy and break the newspaper editors' code of practice. Although pop stars sometimes pose for paparazzi, this is not common. Usually, people in the public eye are harmed when their private moments appear on the front page. However, very few use the Press Complaints Commission (PCC), an organization set up to handle such issues. These pictures are rarely in the public interest. Do intimate photos of pop stars help solve a crime? How did a picture of a famous actress on a hotel balcony protect public health and safety? The actress has complained about long-lens photos before, and since she was in a hotel, where there is a 'reasonable expectation of privacy', she had a good reason to complain, but she didn't take any action. It is shocking that the PCC did not investigate on its own. It should also look into the recent story about a pop star's love life. The pop star, like the actress, has not made a formal complaint. Shouldn't the PCC take action on these and other shameful attacks? At first, this seems like a good idea. It would lead to many decisions against newspapers, which would be reported by their competitors and on TV and radio. The public would not support the newspapers, and editors would have to stop publishing such material. Even photographers would be affected, as it would no longer be profitable to hide and take pictures of unsuspecting celebrities. If the PCC decided to act as a 'police officer', which it technically could, there would be several problems. How would it decide whether to start an inquiry? Should it encourage the victim to make a complaint? And if the person still refused, should it continue anyway? Also, celebrities and royalty might expect every story about them to be investigated and be upset if it wasn't. Above all, the role is too big. How could the PCC realistically monitor all of the British press: national, regional, and magazines? Then there is the embarrassment factor. No matter how seriously someone's privacy has been invaded, would they want the further embarrassment of an investigation? Most people probably just want to move on with their lives. Of course, some may have other reasons for staying quiet. A worse story may exist that they have kept from the press, and they realize it might come out if they complain. In other words, even the PCC might become the enemy. One British comedian also suffered when he and his wife were secretly photographed on their honeymoon in the Caribbean. He didn't complain then, nor more recently, when he and his family were photographed during a holiday. He feared that the newspaper, News of the World, would publish the pictures again with a new story about his 'anger', saying it was just a bit of fun and that, as a comedian, he should have a sense of humor. This fear is understandable. People believe they will become targets again if they challenge the tabloids. It is hard to find an easy solution to this serious problem.

Text: 'There is a lot of advice for college graduates starting their first job. In this article, we will talk about moving to a second job. We are not talking about those looking for a temporary job while searching for a permanent one, or those leaving a bad job in the first few weeks. Instead, we focus on those taking a real step in their career, choosing a job that matches their goals now that they have some experience, skills, and an idea of their career path. What kind of job should you look for? It depends on your long-term goals. You need to ask yourself if you want to specialize in a certain area, move up to higher responsibility, or switch to a different field. Whatever you decide, choose your second job carefully. Plan to stay in it for two to three years. This job will be important when you apply for your next job. It should show that you are serious about your career. Most importantly, it should help you grow and give you more responsibility. If you want to travel, now is the time to do it. You can do temporary work when you return and then find your second job. Future employers will be glad to see that you have traveled and are not likely to leave again. Juliette Davidson spent her first year after leaving St. Aldate's College working for three lawyers. It was a great first job because 'OK ... they were very supportive. I learned about office work and improved my word processing skills. However, there was no room for growth. One day I quit, bought a plane ticket, and traveled for a year.' Juliette now works as a Personal Assistant to Brenda Cleverdon, the Chief Executive of Business in the Community. 'In two and a half years, I have become more capable and my job has really grown,' she says. 'From the start, my boss wanted to develop me. My job title is the same, but my duties have changed. From mostly typing and phone work, I now handle most of the correspondence and budgets. I also deal with various questions, from chairmen of large companies to people wanting to start their own business. Brenda involves me in all her work and gives me specific projects and events to organize.'

Text: 'Confident people: what's their secret? Confident people might seem like they were born that way, but most will say it's a skill they learned because they needed to. Nina Hathway asks five people how they became confident. A Jenny When I left school, I was very shy and thought I would always be that way. When I was about twenty-five, I was asked to help at my daughter's school. I was sure I couldn't handle it, but I surprised myself by doing well. Someone there suggested I take a university course. I was very nervous on my first day, but my confidence grew, and I became more outgoing. Looking back, working at the school was a turning point in my life. B Michaela It started four years ago when my father got sick, and I had to take over the family business. I was scared and became too aggressive and impatient. I thought confident people acted like that, but I learned differently. To be confident, you have to believe in yourself. If work gets too hard, I don't feel guilty about leaving some tasks for the next day. When faced with something difficult, I tell myself I have nothing to lose. Fear makes you lack confidence, so I often talk to myself to overcome those fears. C Lisa People think I'm very confident, but the calmer I look, the more scared I am. I had to learn to look confident because it's important in TV. Interviewing people helped me see that most of us get nervous in important situations, and we feel calmer when we talk to someone friendly. The best advice I got was from my mother when I worried about wearing the right clothes. She said, 'Who's looking at you? Everyone's too busy worrying about themselves.' That's worth remembering. You gain confidence by facing things that scare you. When I took my driving test, I was very nervous, but I passed. After that, I felt I would never be that scared again. D Barbara My confidence comes from enjoying my work, but it's something I've built over the years. If you keep going and learn from mistakes, you're more confident next time. I work hard and am popular in the restaurant, but maybe one out of ten people doesn't like me. I don't let that bother me. You have to like yourself for who you are, not try to be what others expect. My company offers training courses, which have built my self-esteem. They also encourage setting manageable goals. It helps to achieve something real, rather than aiming too high and getting nothing. E Kim After college, I worked as a secretary and would sit in meetings, not always agreeing, but too scared to speak up. Eventually, I found the confidence to start speaking my mind. When I first worked in politics, I had never spoken in public and would shake with nerves. I told myself, 'Don't be silly. People do this every day, so you can too.' I found it helpful to write down a few notes, like a comfort blanket. I don't think anyone isn't a little nervous about public speaking. The real secret of confidence is telling yourself, 'Nothing is impossible.''

**Visit to Malaysia**

Paul Forster attends a kite-flying festival and spends a night in the forest. Adnan Ali smiled as I gave him his torn kite. "You should keep it," he said. "It's a tradition—if the line breaks, finders are keepers. Besides, I have many more." He pointed to a pile of beautifully decorated kites at his feet. Each kite was exactly 120 cm wide and long, made of tissue paper and split bamboo. We sat next to them under the shade of the trees behind the Beach of the Seven Lagoons in Kelantan, looking at Malaysia's biggest kite festival.

In the center of the beach, there were 10 platforms where helpers held up the kites. A row of competitors, holding their kite lines, waited for the countdown. When the whistle blew, the crowd cheered, and the kites soared into the sky like rockets. Over 500 men and boys had signed up for the competition, which lasts five days every year. Each participant entered four different kite designs, judged on decoration, stability, and flying efficiency.

"Flying kites isn't hard," said Adnan, "but making them takes real skill. Visit me at home, and I'll show you how it's done." I accepted his invitation, one of five I received that day. At his house, I drank cold milky tea and ate fish crackers in a large room. As it got dark, he invited me to come back the next day to help rebuild his kite, but I couldn't. Instead, I explored the southern part of the state, driving towards Kuala Lumpur into mountains covered with lush rainforest.

I took a wrong turn, and the smooth road ended at a river. A boat was there to ferry people across. Nearby, a small sign caught my eye. It pointed up a path into the forest and read: "Jelawang Jungle 3 km." It would have been helpful to know that most of this distance was uphill, steep, and slippery. When I reached the track, I found a man with a flask of tea. This was Baba, who managed a tented kitchen and several bamboo huts. I decided to stay, trying not to think about insects under my thin mattress. The night was completely dark, filled with sounds. A waterfall roared nearby, and many creatures moved and squeaked. In the morning, there was a stunning view over five ranges of green mountains.

In the afternoon, it rained. First, the wind blew, then lightning struck the treetops. Seconds later, I was soaked. Sliding downhill, I wondered how the giant butterflies avoided the huge raindrops. I also worried about my car being swept away (it sometimes happens) and the chance of drowning if I opened my mouth. Luckily, the car was still there, covered in mud, at the bottom of the track.

In Kota Bahru, Kelantan's capital, people asked me questions: "Where are you from?" "How old are you?" But they were very friendly. Kelantan might be famous for its kites, but I remember it more for its kindness.

**What kind of shopper are you?**

Everyone goes shopping, whether they like it or not. But there are different types of shoppers. Do you know which type you are? Abby Edwards asked some people ...

**A. Melanie, 22, dancer**

I'm a shopping addict - I can't spend enough money! When I have cash, I'm out shopping, and it keeps me happy. I find it hard to walk past sale signs. My boyfriend is the same, so we often shop together. We're an addicted couple!

**B. Brenda, 40, office manager**

I'm a reluctant shopper. My husband does most of the food shopping because he cooks and knows what he likes. I don't spend much time shopping for clothes. I take my 6-year-old son and 14-year-old daughter to buy clothes, but I don't enjoy it because we all have different tastes. I don't spend money on myself often, so when I do, I feel guilty and rarely tell my husband the real price - I always say it cost less! The real price always sounds too high.

**C. Juliet, 28, personnel manager**

I only shop for essentials. I hate shopping and only go when I really have to. When I do, I know what I want and won't settle for anything else. I find shopping tiring and there's always something I'd rather be doing.

**D. Anita, 35, TV producer**

I like to look around sometimes, but I usually know what I want and where to find it. I don't waste time and get in and out quickly. I do have some mistakes hidden in my wardrobe, so maybe I'm a careful shopper who sometimes gets it wrong!

**E. Lizzie, 41, secretary**

I don't enjoy shopping at all. I really dislike shopping for clothes because I can never find what I want or anyone to help me. The shops are too noisy and disorganized, and I find it a nightmare. Luckily, I rarely have to shop for clothes because most of my clothes are given to me. For food shopping, I go to the local supermarket once a week and finish it quickly!

**F. Lisa, 22, actress**

I'm probably a happy shopper. Sometimes I go out to look around the shops with my friends, and we often end up buying things. I don't usually have a specific item in mind, but if something catches my eye, I'll buy it.

**G. Suki, 26, art gallery assistant**

I'm a careful shopper - I like going, but I don't buy much. I usually know what I want and rarely go overboard. Sometimes I shop to cheer myself up, but I often feel worse because I've spent too much!

**H. Ann-Marie, 29, nursery worker**

I love shopping, but only on certain days and never on a Saturday because it's too busy. I'd say I'm a careful shopper. I always have a good idea of what I want, and I never buy things immediately. I have to check other shops in case I find a better deal - it takes me ages!

**I. Linda, 32, restaurant manager**

I'm an unwilling shopper. Maybe because I work in the city center, the shops have lost their appeal for me. When I have to shop, I drag myself out, but I don't try things on because it's too much trouble. Clothes I buy don't always fit, but I don't mind too much. I'd rather make a few mistakes than put in a lot of effort shopping!

Text: 'NEW OPPORTUNITIES WITH AN OPEN UNIVERSITY DEGREE Like any other university, the Open University can give you a degree. However, you don't have to quit your job to study. It can also introduce you to many new interests. If you have never studied before, you will enjoy the new experience of learning more. You will meet many different people. You may also find that your degree offers new career opportunities. You don't actually go to the Open University for lectures, but study at home, using television, radio, and computer software. You can attend one class a month if you want at an Open University center. Of course, there are exams to take, just like at any university. If you would like to know more, all you have to do is fill out the form below. It could be the start of a wonderful new chapter in your life.'

**Gallery News**

**Easter Quiz for Children**

During the Easter holidays, young visitors can join a quiz about "Surprises." The quiz sheets are free and can be picked up at the Orange Street entrance. Children will be guided to 14 surprising paintings and asked questions about them. The quiz is available during normal gallery hours from 25 March to 9 April.

**New Picture**

The Gallery now has a beautiful still life by the Dutch 18th-century painter Jan van Os. This large painting (89.1 cm x 71 cm) of flowers and fruit is painted in light, bright colors on wood. It is one of the first of its kind in the Gallery. The painting is signed and dated 1777 and 1778. It is common for such paintings to have two dates because the artist waited for different flowers to bloom in their seasons to paint them. This picture was generously donated to the Gallery by Miss Violet Churchman in memory of her sister Ida Nancy. It is now on display in Room 25.

**Special Exhibition**
