The exhibition "Painting in Spain during the late 18th century" opened in the Sunley Room on 15 March. The Gallery recently bought works by three Spanish painters from this period: Paret, Melendez, and Francisco Bayeu, who are the main focus of the exhibition. These artists are joined by Francisco's brother Ramon, Antonio Gonzalez, and two Italians who worked in Spain during these years - Corrado Giaquinto and Giovanni Battista Tiepolo. The exhibition runs until 31 May.

**Lecture News**

The series of lectures related to the special exhibition continues every Wednesday. On 5 April, Lizzie Barker will discuss the work of Melendez. On 12 April, Sarah Symmons will lecture on Luis Paret. On 19 and 26 April, Juliet Wilson will talk about Francisco Bayeu. On Tuesdays in April, Erika Langmuir will explain how artists often "tell a story" through their pictures.

**Gallery Restaurant Improvements**

The Gallery is pleased to announce that the restaurant now offers an improved and expanded service. With new kitchens, the restaurant provides a wide choice of hot and cold dishes at reasonable prices.

**Information for Visitors**

Free guided tours of the Gallery take place every day at 11.00 am and 3.00 pm (except Sundays). These tours introduce some of the Gallery's greatest pictures and show the full range of the Gallery's collection of important European paintings from the 13th to the early 20th centuries.

Text: 'Little Chefs For a group of children aged between ten and fifteen, Saturdays are spent learning how to cook seriously. Their weekly lessons in small classes are so popular that there is a waiting list of 30 children who want to join the course. Parents pay £280 for the course where their children can have fun and learn to make good food. Class member Bill, aged ten, says, 'I love my mum's cooking and now I can do it better than her. The teachers make us laugh, especially when we sit down with them to share the food we've made.' Flora is twelve, and she's having trouble preparing onions. 'I love cooking. I made a meal for ten friends which they really enjoyed. Then my mum suggested I take up a hobby, instead of doing nothing at weekends. I was happy staying at home, so I wasn't too interested at first. I'm really glad I decided to come, though.' Their teacher, Philippe, says, 'It's great fun. Children pay attention and remember things better than adults, although the kitchen isn't always as tidy when they're cooking! As adults, we're always learning more about food. If parents interest their children in cooking while they are young, they'll have enough skill to make food for themselves when they leave home.''

The Outdoor Centre charges a fee for a car with four people. Each extra person costs 50p. Fees should be paid at the main office. The centre is not a private club; it is an organisation that provides outdoor sports and recreation for everyone. Groups should inform the centre before their visit.

Windsurfing - One-day course Beginner windsurfing courses are available on Saturdays and Sundays if the weather is good. Learning to windsurf is very enjoyable. The thrill of sailing across the water for the first time is unforgettable. Beginners can use boards with small sails. Course fee: £32.50 (includes all equipment).

One-day adventure course This is a great opportunity. Try sailing, climbing, surfing, and archery. This course introduces outdoor activities to adults in a fun and relaxed way. You don’t need to be very fit or have experience. Just be interested. Course fee: £22.50.

Play Park The Play Park is for children aged two to ten. It is one of the best in the country. It has sand and water play, slides, a large ball pool, a play castle, and more. Next year, the centre will open a new Play Palace and Play Ship.

Group day and residential courses We offer day and long weekend courses for groups. Schools, colleges, and youth groups visit us regularly. There are three large rooms with twelve beds each, which can be booked in advance for groups of up to 36 people (minimum 12).

Summer adventure holidays (for ages 8-14) Activities include sailing, climbing, windsurfing, and fun games. Safety is very important at the Outdoor Centre. All staff are trained in First Aid and qualified to teach the activities. We ensure that all children only do activities suitable for their age and abilities. Children must be able to swim 25 metres and be in good health for this programme.

**STAMP COLLECTING - A HOBBY THAT CAN KEEP GROWING**

Millions of people of all ages enjoy a hobby that is both interesting and fun. Every year, more people start their own stamp collection and find an interest that can last a lifetime. Starting your collection is easy because stamps are everywhere. Holiday postcards from friends, birthday cards from aunts, and letters from pen pals can all give you stamps from around the world.

Once you start collecting seriously, you might want to join the Stamp Collectors' Club. This club helps collectors get new British stamps. As a member, you can order special sets of new stamps for your collection. You can receive these in three ways. We can send you a complete set of stamps on an envelope addressed to you, or send the same stamps in a colorful information pack with interesting facts. Or, if you prefer, we can send you the individual stamps for you to arrange in your own special book.

The Stamp Collectors' Club has about 70,000 members, and you could become a member too. A two-year membership costs just £5. You can even get a discount if a group of you join at the same time. We think you'll agree that this is great value for money. When you join, the Club sends you a Starter Pack at no extra cost. This includes 100 stamps to start your collection and an attractive box to keep them in. You also receive our helpful 4-page guide to collecting, which has more suggestions on how to add to your collection and includes useful addresses of shops and businesses that sell stamps.

Every two months, you'll get a copy of the club magazine, which is full of competitions and quizzes, and gives you the chance to exchange stamps with members around the world. Why not start an adventure that will give you years of pleasure? You'll spend many happy hours looking at the amazing variety of stamps in your collection or searching for unusual ones that are out there waiting to be found. So join the Stamp Collectors' Club today and discover the fun and excitement of stamp collecting. To join the Club, simply complete the application form and send your membership fee. Your Starter Pack will be sent within 28 days of receiving your application.

Text: 'MONEY What is money? The pound, the dollar, or the euro are like units of measurement, such as a gram or a kilometre. The difference is that you can use money to buy things. For example, a five-pound note can buy a book, a big bag of sweets, or a couple of cinema tickets. But the note itself is just a piece of paper that costs very little to produce. Thousands of years ago, people didn't have money like we do today. There were no banks or shops. Back then, Mr. Green the farmer would trade the corn he grew for Mr. Hive's honey. This was a trade between two people, each having something the other wanted. Over time, most societies created their own 'currencies' to make trading easier. These different currencies started to connect, which is why today everyone uses a national currency.'

Text: 'Write a winning story! You could win £1,000 in this year's Fiction Prize and have your story published in Keep Writing magazine. Ten other lucky people will win a cheque for £100. We are looking for people who can write good stories. The judges, including Mary Littlejohn, the novelist, Michael Brown, the TV reporter, and Susan Hitchins, Keep Writing's editor, want interesting and original stories. Last year, detective fiction was very popular, but the winner wrote a love story. You can write about anything you like, but here is some advice to help you: Write about what you know This is important advice for every writer. Last year, most people who wrote for us did this. Love, family, and problems with friends were the main topics. However, you need to make ordinary situations interesting so people want to read them. Make the reader want to keep reading by writing about ordinary things in a new and surprising way. Get your facts right Don't describe a town or explain how something works if you are not sure about it. Avoid writing about things unless you are certain. Hold the reader's attention Make the beginning interesting and the ending a surprise. A poor ending is disappointing. Develop the story carefully and try to think of something unusual for the end. Think about the characters Make the people in your story come alive for the reader by using well-chosen words to make them seem real. Your story must be your own work, between 2,000 and 2,500 words, and typed, double-spaced, on one side of each sheet of paper. Even if you are close to the deadline, we cannot accept stories by fax or email. You must include the application form with your story. Unfortunately, your story cannot be returned, and we cannot discuss our decisions. You should not have had any fiction published in any magazine or book in this country, and the story must not have appeared in print or recorded form, like on radio or TV, anywhere in the world. Your £5 fee will go to the Writers' Association. Make your cheque payable to Keep Writing and send it with the application form and your story to us. The closing date is 30 July, and we will inform the winner within one month. Please note that if you win, you must agree to have your story published in our magazine.'

Text: 'THE FIRST WOMAN SCIENTIST Hypatia was born in Alexandria, Egypt, in 370 A.D. For many centuries, she was the only woman scientist mentioned in history books. Hypatia's father was the director of Alexandria University, and he ensured his daughter received the best education possible. This was unusual because most women at that time had few chances to study. After studying in Athens and Rome, Hypatia returned to Alexandria and began teaching mathematics. She quickly became famous for her knowledge of new ideas. We do not have copies of her books, but we know she wrote several important mathematical works. Hypatia was also interested in technology and invented several scientific tools to help with her work. At that time, many rulers were afraid of science, and anyone connected with it was in danger. One day in March 415, Hypatia was attacked in the street and killed.'

**NENE VALLEY RAILWAY**

**About the Railway**  
The Nene Valley Railway is 12 kilometres long and goes through the beautiful Nene Park. It starts in the east at Peterborough and ends at Wansford, which is next to the main road. There is a 2-kilometre extension that takes passengers through Wansford Tunnel to Yarwell, the current western end of the line.

**Fares:**  
- Adult: £10.00  
- Child: £5.00  
- Family (up to 2 adults and 3 children): £25.00  
- Special prices may apply on public holidays.

**Nene Park**  
Nene Park offers golf courses and a large Caravan Club site. It's a great place for a family day out with its public parkland, boating lakes, picnic areas, nature reserve, and a miniature railway.

**Wansford**  
Wansford Station has a unique collection of historic trains from Europe. This includes the elegant De Glen Compound locomotive from France, the German Class 52 Kriegslok (the largest working steam engine in Britain), and British engines like '92 Squadron' and 'Mayflower'. You can see these engines all year round, even if the Nene Valley Railway is not running. The buffet, bar, and souvenir shop are open only when the train is running. There is a site entrance fee of £2.00 for adults and £1.00 for children at Wansford.

**A Famous Railway**  
Nene Valley Railway is popular with filmmakers because it can look like a railway from any part of Europe. For example, it was used in the James Bond movie "Octopussy". Come and see where it was filmed.

**Services for Schools**  
From May to July, the Railway offers special services for school groups. Teachers can set projects for students to do while visiting or in the classroom. An educational pack is available for £1.50 plus postage. At other times, schools can hire the train ('Teddy Bear') with up to 3 carriages on non-service days. Bookings should be made one month in advance. Special low fares are available for groups of 60 or more pupils. Call 01780 784444 for more information.

**Private Hire of Trains**  
The Railway is a popular place for family events or company visits. It can provide an interesting afternoon or evening out. Special programmes can include a buffet, bar, entertainment, discos, etc. For more information, contact the General Manager at Wansford Station.

Grass

Grass is one of the most successful plants in the world. There are over 9,000 different types of grasses, and they are found everywhere on Earth. They are the only flowering plants that can live in the cold environments of the Arctic and Antarctic. Grasslands support many kinds of animals, from small insects and birds to large animals like cows and lions. All these animals depend on grass in some way. Grass grows back quickly after it is cut or damaged. Unlike other plants, new leaves grow from below the soil, not from the top. This is why large groups of animals can live in one area. Once they have eaten all the grass, new grass starts to grow, providing a fresh meal.

Kal Kaur Rai, the Young Achiever of the Year, has always loved fashion. She recently won the Young Achiever of the Year award at the Asian Business Awards. Since she was a child, she has been drawing clothes and creating designs. However, she never told her parents, who own a supermarket, that she wanted to make fashion her career. She thought they wanted her to choose a more traditional job, so she studied management at university. After graduating, she moved to London and worked at an advertising agency. She had to attend industry events but couldn't afford the designer clothes she liked, so she started making her own skirts and tops. Her friends loved her clothes and asked her to make some for them too. A small shop in London agreed to sell her designs on a sale-or-return basis, and they sold very well. This success encouraged her to leave her advertising job, take a £20,000 loan, and start her own womenswear label. Kal's parents were supportive of her career change, which made her happy. Now, her clothes are sold in over 70 stores, and her business earns over £500,000. Her designs are featured in fashion magazines, she creates clothes for pop stars, and she has gained public recognition by winning this award. Kal's business has grown significantly, and she feels very fortunate. "What I do is my hobby - and I get paid for it! But remember, I've worked hard for this."

Text: 'SUNNINGDALE HOTEL The Sunningdale Hotel was built in 1913 and opened by Princess Louise. It has offered excellent service to people from all over the world. Over the past 80 years, more than 50,000 guests from 174 different countries have stayed at Sunningdale. The hotel is located on a main road leading to the town centre. It is about 20 minutes by bus from the town centre, and buses to many other parts of the town stop outside the hotel. Guests should avoid buses with the blue sign Express on the front because they do not stop near the hotel. An underground station is less than 100 metres away. The main building has 200 well-furnished, centrally-heated single rooms, each with hot and cold water basins. Showers, baths, and toilets are at the end of all corridors. The hotel has a shop, sitting rooms, four television rooms, a table tennis room, a library, and a laundry. There are also eight pianos available for guests to use. There is parking available in the hotel drive. Daily newspapers are free, and stamps can be bought at the office. Guests staying for long periods must pay for their accommodation weekly in advance, and one week's notice is required for departures. Both short-term and long-term guests are welcome, but long-term guests are given priority for rooms. Meal times are: breakfast 7 am - 9.30 am; lunch 1 pm - 2 pm; dinner 5.30 pm - 7 pm. During the week, those studying or working late can request dinner until 11 pm by writing their name on the late list or by calling before 7 pm. A selection of 10 menu choices is available for breakfast and dinner. No animals or fires (for heating food or rooms) are allowed, and guests are asked to respect the comfort of others. If you have tapes or CDs, please keep the noise level down, especially between 11 pm and 8 am. Guests are advised to use taxis to reach the hotel if they arrive by train, as it is some distance from the main railway station.'

Text: 'Tom Cruise Tom Cruise is one of the most successful actors in movie history. However, his life hasn't always been easy. As a young boy, Tom was shy and had trouble making friends, even though he loved being in school plays. After finishing high school, Tom moved to New York to find work. He got a job as a porter and also took drama classes. In 1980, film director Franco Zeffirelli gave Tom his first role in a movie. Ten years later, he became so successful that he was one of the highest-paid actors in Hollywood, earning millions of dollars for each movie. Today, Tom still acts in movies and remains very popular with his thousands of fans from all over the world.'

Text: 'LITTLE CAT, LITTLE CAT, WHERE HAVE YOU BEEN? When Bo the cat decided to explore a furniture van, she had a bigger adventure than she expected. The driver found her after he had driven over 500 kilometres. It was the end of a long day, and both the driver and the cat were hungry! He gave her some milk and started asking questions. He called his last customers, but none of them had lost a cat. It was getting late, so he took Bo home for the night. The next morning, he brought her to an animal hospital. Meanwhile, the cat's owner was also trying to find her. After searching everywhere, he remembered the furniture van that had delivered to a neighbor. Luckily, he remembered the company's name. He called their office, and soon Bo was safely returned.'

**The Ghan Train**

Mark Ottaway traveled by train from Darwin, in the north of Australia, to Adelaide, in the south. The Ghan train crosses Australia from the warm northern coast through endless desert to the colder Southern Ocean. It is often called the 'famous Ghan', but it is known for being late. The idea of a rail link between Darwin and Adelaide started in the 1920s with a line from Adelaide to Alice Springs, but flooding often made it hard for trains to pass. A new line was finished a few months before my journey. The railway was built for speeds up to 115 kph, but the Ghan is not a high-speed train. There are few stops, and most passengers are on holiday. The Ghan does not offer luxury like the Orient Express, although the food on board is excellent. The railway was originally built to carry goods, not passengers. It was thought that sending goods from Europe to Australia's south via Darwin and the train, instead of by ship around the continent, would save time and money. A transcontinental railway is rare, and the Ghan claims to be the world's first north-south one. As I waited to board the Ghan, I saw that everyone was excited about the journey. Most of my fellow travelers were Australian pensioners, eager to board. Our first stop was at Katherine, where the Ghan waited four hours. Some passengers took a boat trip up the gorge. I left the train at Alice Springs for a two-day trip to Uluru (Ayers Rock) with a small group and a guide. Climbing the rock is not encouraged now, and few people do. Our group walked around the rock and watched the beautiful sunset. From Alice Springs, there are two trains a week going south, so many passengers stop here. The view from the train after Alice Springs is not very interesting. There is a lot of flat land with only cattle to see. But at dawn on the third day, we reached the foothills near the Southern Ocean. My journey was over, and although the train might not have delivered everything the advertisements promised, it took me to some of the most amazing sights in Australia.

Climbing to the Top of Britain

Every year, thousands of people climb Ben Nevis in Scotland. Because it is so far north, the weather can be very cold. Climber Keith Hewitt talks about his first time on Ben Nevis. It was February, and it was my first big winter climb. We planned to climb the north face of the mountain to Tower Ridge. This climb is 600 meters high and is probably the longest climb in Britain. We planned to camp for three days in the 'Carries', which are like big bowls in the mountain walls halfway up. We carried tents, sleeping bags, and metal spikes for our boots. You need these spikes because the snow can be so hard that it feels like walking on ice. Even though some people in our group were very experienced, we packed all kinds of safety equipment, like lights to attract attention, hard hats, and extra clothing. The weather forecast was perfect, with no strong winds, but we still felt nervous when we started. Climbing Ben Nevis in winter is always a challenge. The path soon became steep, and my legs felt tired. I was the weakest in the group, so I had to rest more often. The others sometimes stopped to let me catch up, but as soon as I reached them, they started again. I promised myself that I would always train properly before a climb in the future. After 200 meters, we reached the start of Tower Ridge, the path that would take us to the top of Ben Nevis. It is only one and a half meters wide, and the mountain drops hundreds of meters on each side. We knew we had to stay calm and focus on every step as we moved slowly along it. After seven hours of climbing, we reached the top. On a clear day, you can see the sea and all the way to the island of Skye, 48 kilometers away. However, we weren't so lucky because a mist had come down. On Ben Nevis, getting back down to camp can be as challenging as going up. You need to read a map properly because a wrong turn could lead to slopes that are too dangerous to go down in winter. I was glad we decided to take turns doing that job. That first time, I only really enjoyed the experience when I was safe in the tent. But at least I made it to the top.

Anna's New School

This week has been very exciting because we just moved into our new school building! It's an amazing place. The builders used wood for the whole building, just like in our old school. However, this new school is one of the first in my country to be very environmentally friendly. It took months to build, so we watched the whole process. It was exciting to see the builders clear the space for it, although it meant losing some nice open land. The noise from the building machines was very loud, and the builders often had to stop because of heavy rain. We started to think the building would never be finished.

Now, we have five classrooms, which are huge - much bigger than in our old school next door, which was very old. We share one room with people in the town when they need it for meetings. There's also a nursery, a lovely dining room, and big changing rooms that we can't wait to use once our new sports field is ready.

When you enter the school, one of the first things you notice is that there are no heaters! Instead, the heat comes from all of us inside - the children, the teachers, and the computers. The building is designed so well that it keeps all the heat inside - and all the sound too. If we sing in our classrooms, it feels like we're in a concert hall!

Another interesting thing is that the school roof has a tree on top! The builders put it there after finishing the roof because it's a custom in Austria, where the roof was made. The electricity for lights and computers comes from a wind turbine on a hill behind the school. We visited it with our teacher yesterday, and it spins very fast. It's so big that you can see it from miles away! We took some pictures to put on the website.

Even though we're already using the school building, there are still some parts to be added. For example, we are putting on a play for parents, but we still have to go back to our old school hall to do it. The new hall will be ready by next year. We're so happy with our new school, and our teachers say we'll learn much faster now that we're in it!

**International Book Club**

Have you ever thought about joining a book club and buying new books by mail? At the International Book Club, many members already buy books from us this way.

**To join:**

Simply send us your first order from our book list.

**Immediate benefits:**

As a special offer, you can choose any reduced-price books from our new members' book list, up to a total value of £6 (plus postage and packing). This way, you will save money on the publishers' prices. Tick the box on your form to order a free watch. If you reply within seven days, we will send you another free gift, carefully chosen from our book list by our staff. You can also order a DVD from our list at half the recommended retail price.

**When you've joined:**

As a member, you'll save between 30% and 50% off the publisher's price on every book you buy, and they will be delivered straight to your door. You will receive a free club magazine once a month, keeping you updated with the latest best-sellers. Each year, we offer over 1,000 books to choose from. On the Internet, you can find all our titles for the year on our exclusive members' website.

**Being a member:**

All we ask is that you choose four books during your first year. After that, you can decide how many books you want. In each monthly club magazine, our experienced staff select a Club Choice book—a fiction or reference title they think is worth buying, offered at a special price. If you do not want this book, just indicate this on the form. We will send the book if we do not receive your response.

So, return your application form today, but hurry—offers like this are rare. To apply, simply fill in the enclosed form and return it in the postage-paid envelope provided. Soon, your books will be with you. Please don't send any money now; we will send you the bill with the books. Remember, you have up to two weeks to decide if you want to keep the books you ordered. You can then either return the books or send your payment.

Text: 'No Title A month ago, I never imagined that on a Saturday afternoon in November, I would be hanging 30 meters above the ground and enjoying it. Now, as I looked down at the river far below, I understood why people love rock climbing. My friend Matt and I arrived at the Activity Centre on Friday evening. The accommodation wasn't great, but we had everything we needed: beds, blankets, and food. We were happy to be out of the city and in the fresh air. On Saturday morning, we met the other ten members of our group. Cameron came with two friends, Kevin and Simon, while sisters Carole and Lynn came with Amanda. We all came from different places, and none of us knew the area. We knew we would spend the weekend outdoors, but we weren't sure exactly what we would do. Half of us spent the morning caving, while the others went rock climbing, and then we switched at lunchtime. Matt and I went to the caves first. Climbing out was harder than going in, but after a lot of effort, we were finally out—covered in mud but happy and excited about what we had done.'

Text: 'Letter to the Newport Evening News On Saturday afternoon, I left my handbag on the bus. Inside it were my cheque book, address book, and my purse, which had about £50 in cash and some credit cards. When I realized what I had done, it was too late. I didn't know what to do: I'm 72 years old, I was far from home, and I was very worried. I stood by the side of the road and cried. A young man asked me what was wrong, and I explained what had happened. He gave me some money for my bus fare home. When I told the bus driver what had happened, he said I should keep the fare. I got home safely, and the telephone rang soon after. It was the manager of CityBus, the company that owned the bus where I left my handbag. He said they had my handbag and offered to drive over to return it. I got my handbag back, amazingly with all its contents untouched. I would just like to say how wonderful everyone was who helped me that day, and how much I appreciate their kindness and honesty. Mrs. B. James, Newport'

Text: 'Sharks Sharks are some of the most frightening creatures in our oceans. They are well equipped for hunting underwater because they have excellent vision and can sense movement through special lines on the sides of their bodies. This makes sharks very dangerous for smaller sea creatures that become their prey. Although sharks are similar to other fish in some ways, their bodies are different. For example, unlike other fish, most sharks need to swim all the time to breathe and stay alive, so they hardly sleep at all. Also, if sharks are turned over on their backs, they can stop moving completely. This is a very useful technique for researchers who often need to handle sharks. It allows them to learn more about these fascinating creatures.'

Text: 'AUSTRALIA for only £1985 OUR PRICE INCLUDES Scheduled flights with Australia's national airline, Qantas, from London or Manchester to Perth, returning from Melbourne. After arriving in Perth, Air Australia flights between Perth, Alice Springs, Cairns, and Sydney. Coach from Sydney to Melbourne via Canberra and Albury. All airport transfers in Australia. Nineteen nights' accommodation in quality hotels with full continental breakfast. Day trip to Ayers Rock, a full day Barrier Reef boat trip, a visit to an Australian sheep station, and city sightseeing tours in Perth, Alice Springs, Sydney, Canberra, and Melbourne. All state and local taxes. Hotel baggage handling. Experienced Globewise Tour Manager throughout the trip. PERTH Beautiful long, golden beaches, excellent restaurants with great food in lovely settings, lush green parks, and the stunning Swan River. City sightseeing tour included. ALICE SPRINGS Fly over the outback to famous Alice Springs in the heart of Aboriginal country. Full sightseeing tour. See the Flying Doctor base and 'School of the Air'. AYERS ROCK Drive to Yulara National Park. Visit the mysterious Olgas and Ayers Rock with its caves and Aboriginal rock paintings. Fly on to the lively seaside town of Cairns and relax in the sun. GREAT BARRIER REEF We've included a full day's boat trip on the famous reef with the chance to see amazing, brightly colored fish and other sea creatures. SYDNEY You'll love the excitement and beauty of Australia's biggest city - we've included a sightseeing tour and a visit to the famous Opera House. You can also book a day trip to the Blue Mountains. MELBOURNE We've included a city sightseeing tour - or you can visit the Penguin Parade. We promise that by the end of the trip you'll want to return!'

Text: 'Joining the Kirov Ballet I'm Nathalie. Last year, I became one of the youngest foreign students to join the Kirov's ballet school in St Petersburg, Russia. At my first ballet class, I was nervous because I didn't know anyone. Everyone gathered around and asked me questions in Russian. I tried to speak Russian, and then they started talking in English, so we could communicate. Now, six months later, everyone is really nice to me, my Russian has improved a lot, and I understand my teachers. For the first two weeks after I arrived, my mum stayed with me, and when she left, I felt a bit sad. I even called home late at night once to talk to her because I felt a little lonely. Compared to my ballet school in England, the classes in Russia are really hard, and I eat a lot to keep up my energy levels. That makes me confident I can perform to the school's high standards. In the evenings, I watch my favourite films on my computer, but sometimes I fall asleep before the DVD finishes. Now that I've settled down, I feel really at home here. I like walking around the city and going to different shops - even in December when I couldn't believe how cold it was. I decided to buy a fur hat because it was minus 10°C, but the Russians said it was mild for that time of year! At least it was warm and cosy in my room. At the moment, we are preparing for a new production, and there's also a competition for young dancers that I'm going to enter. I feel so lucky to be here.'

Text: 'THE ICEHOTEL For many years, the Arctic was a popular place to visit in the summer to see the land of the midnight sun. However, in winter, only a few people lived there, enjoying the snow and ice alone. By the late 1980s, people decided that the dark and cold winter could be a good thing. In the winter of 1990, a French artist named Jannot Derit was invited to open an exhibition in a special igloo (a building made of snow) in the small town of Jukkasjarvi on the frozen Torne River. This building, called Arctic Hall, attracted many visitors. One night, a group of foreign guests thought it would be interesting to sleep in the Arctic Hall. The next morning, they were very happy with their experience, and the idea of an ice hotel was born. Today, it is famous worldwide. When winter starts, a team of snow builders, architects, and artists from around the world come to Jukkasjarvi to build the hotel for that year. As soon as one part is finished, it opens to visitors and overnight guests, while other parts are still being built. The first part is ready in December, and each week a new part opens until January 7th, when the hotel is complete. Since the ICEHOTEL is built outside using natural winter materials, the finishing date depends on nature, so plans can change. In spring, when it gets warmer, the hotel melts. Inside the hotel, the temperature is always between -5°C and -8°C, no matter how cold it is outside. Warm winter clothes like overalls, hats, and gloves are included in the cost of staying at the hotel. Guests should also bring sweaters, a scarf, and plenty of wool socks, and choose shoes that are larger than normal to fit thick socks. If you plan to visit the hotel, you can buy warm sweaters, wool socks, and more on the ICEHOTEL website. You can order these items and the equipment you need when you book your visit. They will be delivered to your room when you check in. The hotel is in the village of Jukkasjarvi, 200 km above the Arctic Circle, but only 15 km from Kiruna airport and 17 km from Kiruna train station. Bus transport can be arranged from the airport or train station to the ICEHOTEL.'

Text: 'Shopping for furniture A report by Dave Worthington Homestyle, a new furniture store, had to close soon after it opened at midnight last Thursday. Up to 6,000 people rushed to the store. There were many special offers, like a leather sofa for £45 (only until 3 am) and a bed for £30 (only between 3 am and 8 am). The store's regular hours will be 9 am to 9 pm every day, but Homestyle had announced it would stay open for the first 24 hours. However, it had to close within half an hour of opening. A police officer who was called to the store said: 'The police knew a large crowd was expected, but people were not patient. The store quickly filled up, and the managers wisely decided to close the doors. The people outside got angry because they thought everything would be sold before they could enter, and they refused to wait quietly until there was space inside. Another problem was the long line of cars trying to reach the parking lot. What surprised me was that many people left their cars in the middle of the road and walked the last few meters to the store. This caused the road to be completely blocked.' One customer, Jenny Smith, who got into the store, said: 'I waited for three hours and didn't have time to buy what I wanted. But the staff were very calm and explained what was happening. They had no choice, as it wasn't safe. So I'll come back when they reopen, but I won't wait in line again.'

The Short Story Society helps writers in Britain today. It started in 1899 and is now one of Britain's most active arts organizations.

**Society Magazines**  
We produce several magazines, including the popular Short Story Review. This magazine features short stories by top British writers and gives new writers a chance to have their work published. Another magazine, Short Story News, includes interviews with writers and information about events, competitions, festivals, and the writing scene. You can read articles from recent issues by following the links on this website.

**National Short Story Competition**  
We organize the National Short Story Competition, the largest of its kind. It is open to anyone aged 18 and over, and stories on any topic are accepted. Stories should be between 1,000 and 1,500 words long. Society members enter for free, while non-members pay a £5 entry fee. The competition runs from April to the end of October each year. The ten best stories will be published in the Society's annual book of short stories. The winner will receive a publishing contract to create their own collection of short stories.

**Education**  
For nearly thirty years, the Society has brought writers into classrooms, giving children and teachers new ideas and building their confidence in writing. Current projects include the Young Writer of the Year, started in 1998, for writers aged 11-18. Winners receive book prizes and are invited to a five-day course taught by professional writers.

**The Writers' Cafe**  
The Writers' Cafe is the social center of the Society. It is relaxed and stylish, offering freshly cooked vegetarian food, excellent coffees, and cold drinks. It is a great place to read the Society's magazines. The Cafe also hosts monthly exhibitions, short courses, and readings. Located in the heart of London, it is open from 11:00 am to 10:00 pm Monday to Friday and 11:00 am to 8:00 pm on Saturday. Society members get discounts on selected products and events.

**Becoming a Member**  
We have members worldwide, and anyone aged eighteen or over can join. If you want to join The Short Story Society, click here and fill out a registration form.

Free-diving in the Caribbean

Tanya Streeter holds four world records in free-diving, a sport where people dive deep into the ocean on just one breath. In 2003, Tanya made history by diving 120 meters deep and returning to the surface without help. She had gone deeper the year before but used a balloon to come back up. This time, she held her breath for over three and a half minutes, becoming the only woman to break a man's world record in any sport. Fourteen safety divers watched her dive at different depths. Some people think free-diving is too dangerous because of serious accidents, but Tanya disagrees. She believes safety and training are most important.

Most free-divers focus on one or two types of events, but Tanya's training routine stays the same. She spends two-thirds of her time training on land at the gym, and the rest in the pool and ocean. She uses an exercise bike to improve her heart fitness but avoids running to protect her knees. Instead, she fast-walks to build fitness. When she starts practice dives, she usually travels away from home. She aims to do fourteen dives over four weeks, resting every other day to avoid getting tired, which could ruin her preparation.

When not preparing for an event, Tanya often appears in public to promote sports products and supports environmental causes by doing research or making films. Growing up on Grand Cayman in the Caribbean, she loved swimming and exploring rock pools. Tanya says her life now is like living her childhood dreams. She is well-known in some countries, so people listen to her about environmental issues. In the future, Tanya, now in her thirties, plans to keep breaking her own records. She started free-diving at twenty-five and doesn't plan to retire anytime soon.

Text: 'CARTOON FILMS Cartoon films have very few limits. If you can draw something, you can make it move on the cinema screen. New ideas and advanced computer programs mean that cartoons are becoming exciting again for people of all ages. By the end of the 1970s, the cinema world thought cartoons were only for children. But soon after, a few directors had some original new ideas. They showed that it was possible to make films that both adults and children could enjoy. However, not every cartoon film was successful. The Black Cauldron, for example, failed because it was too scary for children and too childish for adults. Directors learned from this mistake, and film companies began to make a lot of money again.'

Text: 'New TV Star Caroline Benson talks about her first TV role 'I never expected to spend some of my first year at university filming The Finnegans. I had only acted at school before, but I loved the book since I was eleven. My grandmother used to say I was just like Polly Finnegan, and I always imagined playing her. I took a year off to travel before university. While I was in Chile, my mother emailed me about plans to turn the book into a TV drama. I knew I had to try for the part. She was surprised at first but sent my photo to the director and convinced him to meet me. I flew back and got the part. The outdoor filming started a week into the term, so I got permission from the university to be away for three weeks. Once back at university, I got up at 6.00 am to write the essays I missed. I didn't tell my university friends, but they found out and thought it was great. It was an amazing experience, and I'm so lucky. After university, I definitely want to make acting my career. I'm not from an acting family, though my grandfather was an opera singer. I've tried for other TV parts but haven't received any offers yet. I don't know how I managed it all because I had a full social life too. When filming finished, I hardly knew what to do. I've since appeared in two college plays. Unfortunately, I haven't been home much, and now my first year at university is over, I'm off to Greece for the summer with friends.''

Text: 'No Title When I opened the first 'Body Shop' in 1976, my only goal was to earn enough to support my children. Today, 'The Body Shop' is an international company growing quickly around the world. Over the years, I have learned a lot. Much of what I have learned is in this book because I believe that we, as a company, have something important to say about running a successful business without losing our core values. This is not a typical business book, nor is it just about my life. The main idea is that to succeed in business, you need to be different. Business can be enjoyable, it can be run with care, and it can have a positive impact. In business, as in life, I need to have fun, feel a sense of family, and be excited by surprises. I have always wanted the people who work for 'The Body Shop' to feel the same way. Now, this book shares my ideas with the world and makes them public. I like to think there are no limits to our 'family' and no limits to what we can achieve. I find that an exciting thought. I hope you do, too.'

Text: 'A JOURNEY ALONG THE BEAUTIFUL DOURO RIVER VOYAGES JULES VERNE offers a 'hotel ship' experience on the Douro River in Portugal. The MV Lady Ivy May can host 160 guests in double cabins, all with outside views, private showers, and toilets. The ship is air-conditioned and includes a sun-deck, lounge, bar, dining room, shop, and library. Itinerary Day 1 Depart from London Heathrow to Oporto in the early evening. Upon arrival, your guide will take you to the Lady Ivy May, where you will stay overnight. Day 2 Enjoy a morning tour of Oporto, then return to the ship and travel to Entre-os-Rios, a four-hour journey up the river. Day 3 Continue up the river, stopping in the early evening at Peso da Regua, known for port wine. Dinner will feature local food and drinks. Day 4 After breakfast, take a bus to the ancient town of Lamego to visit the cathedral, several churches, and a museum, which was once a palace and now has a great collection of art. Return to the ship and sail to Tua. Day 5 The Douro River becomes narrow here. Depending on the river's depth, you might continue by a smaller boat to the Spanish border at Barca d'Alva. The return to Tua is by coach, with many sights to see. Day 6 In the morning, drive to Sao Joao da Pesqueira for a stunning view of the Douro Valley. Return to the ship for lunch, then take a scenic train ride through the Douro Valley to Regua, where the Lady Ivy May will be waiting. Day 7 Visit Vila Real before returning to the ship for lunch, then travel down the river to Oporto. Spend the night on the Lady Ivy May. Day 8 Arrive in Oporto with time for sightseeing and shopping before flying back to London Heathrow.'

Text: 'HONEY Honey is a sweet liquid made by bees. It is made of water and sugars. Bees can travel up to seventy-five thousand kilometers and visit over two million flowers to make just half a kilo of honey. The color and taste of honey depend on the type of flower the bees visit. There are more than three hundred types of honey. Lighter-colored honey usually has a milder taste than darker honey. In ancient times, honey was the main sweet food because sugar was very rare. Honey was very valuable to the ancient Egyptians, who used it as payment. Today, honey is made and eaten all over the world. Research suggests that it can prevent tiredness and improve athletic performance. However, honey is not just food - it can be used for sore throats and is in many skin and hair-care products.'

Norwich, the capital of East Anglia in Britain, has been a place to live for over two thousand years. It started as a small village by the River Wensum. By the time of the Norman invasion in 1066, it had grown into one of the largest towns in England. Norwich is known for its religious diversity, with two cathedrals and a mosque. The first cathedral was built in 1095 and recently celebrated its 900th anniversary. In 1994, Norwich celebrated the 800th anniversary of receiving a Royal Charter, which allowed it to be called a city and govern itself independently.

Today, Norwich is quite small compared to cities like London or Manchester, with a population of about 150,000. However, in the 16th century, it was the second-largest city in England. It continued to grow and became wealthy, known for having as many churches as there are weeks in the year and as many pubs as there are days in the year. Now, there are fewer churches and pubs, but in 1964, the University of East Anglia was established in Norwich. With a growing student population and success as a commercial center, Norwich offers a wide range of entertainment: theatres, cinemas, nightclubs, busy cafes, excellent restaurants, and arts and leisure centers. The city also has a football team, known as 'The Canaries', with green and yellow colors, though the reason for the name is unclear.

One of the city's attractions is a modern shopping center called 'The Castle Mall'. For over two years, the people of Norwich lived with a large hole in the city center as builders worked on the main car park. Nearly a million tons of earth were moved so that the roof of the Mall could become a city center park, with water pools and trees. The local people are happy that the old open market remains next to the new development. Both areas continue to do well, showing that Norwich has successfully combined the old and the new.

The Albuquerque Balloon Festival Every autumn, the sky above Albuquerque, a city in the southwestern United States, fills with bright colors. This is the Albuquerque Balloon Festival, a nine-day event held every year. The first festival was in 1972 to celebrate the 50th birthday of a local radio station. It started with about a dozen hot-air balloons taking off from a car park in the city. Since then, the festival has grown a lot. This year, at least a thousand balloons from over a third of the countries in the world are expected at its current location outside the city. What to see The pilots stay in radio contact and light up their balloons' burners at the same time. These are called 'balloon glows' and are great for taking photos. To see these 'glows,' you need to arrive just after nightfall or before 5:30 am as the balloons rise into the dark sky. During the day, you can walk among the balloons and talk to the pilots as they get ready for take-off. The balloons come in all sizes and colors, some shaped like animals, cartoon characters, or famous products like soft drinks and fast food. Kids will love it. In the afternoon, you can take a balloon flight over the desert with one of the many companies offering rides. Another option is to take the cable car from the desert floor to the top of the nearby mountains, the longest ride of its kind, and enjoy a view of the festival from above. There are many other attractions for visitors of all ages, including balloon races and fireworks on the opening night and the last three nights of the festival. The Albuquerque Box This is a local wind pattern that is perfect for balloonists. The Sandia Mountains protect the balloons from strong winds and create gentle wind currents at different heights. This allows skilled pilots to control the direction of their balloons by rising or descending. Practical advice Buy your tickets in advance online to avoid long waits at the festival site. Wear several layers of thin clothing. It can be cool at night and in the early morning, but during the day, sunglasses and sunscreen are essential. Bring a flashlight for night events and, of course, your camera. If you use film, you'll need high-speed film for evening and night pictures.

The Eden Project Since it opened, the Eden Project in the south-west of England has become one of the UK's most popular tourist spots. At first glance, the large 'biospheres' on this former industrial site look like something from a science-fiction movie. Each biosphere has a different climate zone, showing visitors how important the relationship between people and plants is. It is amazing to see how many products we use every day come from plants: wood, rubber, fruit, rice, sugar, coffee, and chocolate, for example. Over 135,000 different types of plants are grown here. No matter how cold the weather is outside, computer-controlled electric heaters keep the plants at the right temperature. In the Rainforest Zone, the air is always damp because of a large waterfall. Another zone copies the environment of the Mediterranean, California, and South Africa, and there are plans to build a desert zone soon.

Text: 'No Title Some people have complained about this year's collection, New Writing 3, but I don't understand why. Isn't 500 pages of original writing of this quality, for £6.99, quite impressive? Most of the book is fiction, including parts of novels and complete short stories. There are enjoyable pieces by famous writers like Candia McWilliam and Rose Tremain. Interestingly, the less well-known writers seem to focus mainly on food. Be careful with Jane Harris's Those Nails - it's best not to read it right after eating, as it has some very unpleasant scenes that might upset your stomach! The book also features excellent work from nineteen poets, including R. S. Thomas and John Burnside. There are excerpts from novels-in-progress by Jim Crace and Jane Rogers. Lastly, there is a bit of non-fiction, including a very funny article by Alan Rusbridger about certain newspapers, and an extraordinary piece about herself by Ursula Owen. This is an exceptional collection, and I am eager to see what next year's selection will include.'

Text: 'No Title "The best age to start learning the violin is between three and six," says Margaret Porter, a violinist and music teacher. "It's the time when you are learning about the world." Margaret, who lives in London, likes to start teaching children at three or four years old, but she sometimes makes exceptions for eager five-year-olds. When she began teaching the violin in 1972, her first class was made up of her children's five-year-old school friends. Margaret's students have group lessons. Each group has about twelve students, and each lesson lasts an hour, once every two weeks. Additionally, each student has one individual lesson a week with her. Parents must also attend the classes. It is important that parents show interest in the lessons. From the first lessons, students learn to play by ear. They do not try to read music until they have been playing for several years, and for a long time, there is a big difference between their playing and reading of music. Margaret says her method is not meant to create great violinists, and she often suggests that students who do very well should leave and study the violin using more traditional methods.'

Text: 'Moonshine The band Moonshine released their third CD last week. 'Here Again' is a follow-up to 'The Waves'. There have been some changes since the last CD. Tom Wilcott is now playing bass guitar, replacing Simon McVee who left the band last year, and Tom Simpson has joined as the drummer. From the first song, which is a dance tune, it is clear that the band is not focusing on slow songs anymore. The second song is also a dance tune and is even louder and heavier. Most of the later tracks are in the band's usual slow style. These two tracks will surprise many fans. Either of them could easily become a hit single because they are excellent. Singer Rob Letchford shows his talent by hitting each note perfectly. Fans should be thankful he recorded the songs before he had throat problems. This has caused the band to cancel their next tour. (Anyone who has bought tickets should not worry as all the concerts will be rescheduled once Rob has recovered.) On this CD, Moonshine shows they can create perfect music in different styles, from the slow ones we know to the ones that make you want to dance. I felt that the best songs were at the beginning, and the last few tracks were not as good. Despite this, 'Here Again' is sure to be a big hit and bring more success to the band.'

San Francisco San Francisco is located on the coast of northern California. The first Europeans to find the area were led by a Spanish explorer named Gaspar de Portola. He saw it for the first time in 1769. Interestingly, even though San Francisco Bay is a great natural harbor, it was discovered from the land instead of the sea. In 1849, thousands of people came to San Francisco hoping to find gold. However, it was not the gold seekers who became rich. The wealthiest people made their money by owning banks and law firms, and they built large houses on a hill called Nob Hill. Today, tourists visit San Francisco to see famous places like Chinatown and the Golden Gate Bridge. Many also take a short boat trip to Alcatraz Island to see the former prison.

Text: 'SAMUEL PEPYS The most famous diary in English was written by Samuel Pepys. It gives a detailed and interesting description of everyday life in England between 1660 and 1669. Pepys writes about important news stories of the time, like disease, an enemy navy sailing up the River Thames, and the Great Fire of London. He also writes about himself, even about his faults - he often slept during church or looked at the pretty girls. He describes his home life - a quarrel with his wife and how they became friends again, and his worry about her illness. Besides books, he liked music, the theatre, card games, and parties with good food and plenty of fun. Pepys was a busy man who had many important jobs - he was a Member of Parliament and President of the Royal Society. He is also remembered for his work for the British Navy.'

Text: 'The History of Shoes In the past, shoes were not made to be comfortable or stylish. Early shoes were likely made from animal skins, which people wrapped around their ankles in cold weather. We still use leather today, but other materials like silk, plastic, or cotton are also popular, depending on fashion trends. It was only 150 years ago that people started wearing different shoes on each foot. Before that, both shoes were straight and could be worn on either foot. All shoes used to be handmade, but now, although some shoemakers still use traditional skills, most shoes are made by machines in large factories. The invention of sewing machines allowed the shoe industry to make many cheaper shoes for more people.'

Text: 'No Title When I hurt my back, I had to stop my running career for a while. I decided to help more women try running, to show them how enjoyable it can be and to give them the confidence to start. I started a running club for women in my area because I was frustrated with many race organizers. They complain about the lack of women in the sport but use this as an excuse not to provide separate changing rooms. I put up posters, and 40 women, both young and old, fit and unfit, joined. They were interested in losing weight, but I don't think they had really thought about running before. When they did think about it, they imagined difficult training. They didn't think about chatting and smiling while running in beautiful places, like by a river. At first, they ran for only a minute - now they can run for thirty minutes. They've also learned from other runners about diet and staying fit in general. I wanted to do something for women's running, and I've enjoyed watching their progress - almost as much as they have.'

**THE HISTORY OF THE IDITAROD - THE LAST GREAT RACE ON EARTH**

In the 1880s, gold was found in Alaska, the northernmost state of the USA. Many people moved there, hoping to become rich. New towns were quickly built and expanded. One of these towns was named Iditarod, meaning 'far, distant place'. In 1909, Iditarod grew so fast that it briefly became the largest city in Alaska. During the summer, essential supplies could be delivered by boat, but in winter, the rivers and ocean froze, making travel impossible. So, in 1910, a winter trail was created for teams of dogs pulling sleds. They carried mail, food, and clothes to the gold miners. This trail was called the Iditarod Trail. It took about three weeks for a dog team to cross Alaska. They stopped at 'roadhouses' where the drivers could rest and eat, and feed their dogs. The trail was used every winter until the 1920s when airplanes replaced steam boats and dog teams as the main transport. However, the dogs had one last important role in 1925, when a disease called diphtheria struck the city of Nome. The disease could be treated, but the nearest medicine was in Anchorage, on the other side of Alaska. Airplanes were still new, and it was uncertain if they could fly in such cold weather. Also, Carl Eielson, the only pilot skilled enough for the flight, was away. So, it was decided to use dog teams to transport the medicine. The journey covered over 1,000 kilometers, mostly along the Iditarod Trail. It took twenty teams just six days to complete the trip. Leonhard Seppala, a Norwegian who came to Alaska for gold, traveled the first 400 kilometers. He relied on his dog Togo to navigate through the blinding snow, and Togo proved to be a reliable guide. The last part of the journey was completed by Gunnar Kaasen, who had driven dog teams in Alaska for 21 years. His lead dog was Balto. At one point, Balto refused to go further, saving the team from falling into icy water. The diphtheria outbreak was stopped, and Balto became a hero. Today, a dog sled race is held every year from Anchorage to Nome, following the route of the 1925 journey. It is called the Iditarod and is known as 'The Last Great Race on Earth'.

Text: 'Sweden's Ice Hotel The village of Jukkasjärvi is in Swedish Lapland, where winter temperatures can drop to -40°C. Despite the cold, 6,000 tourists visit each year to see one of Europe's most unique hotels. In this hotel, you can eat, drink, and sleep in rooms made of ice. You can even get married there if you wish. The bar is also made of ice, so putting hot drinks on it is not a good idea! The bedrooms are about -4°C, but guests receive special sleeping bags to stay warm. If needed, suitable outdoor clothing is also available. The hotel is never older than six months because it melts in the summer and is rebuilt each winter. Building the hotel requires 10,000 tonnes of ice and 30,000 tonnes of snow.'

Text: 'Maria Mutola In 1988, Maria Mutola was the only girl playing football in an all-boys team in a local competition in Mozambique. 'We won,' she said. 'At first, no one thought it was a problem that I was a girl. But then the team we beat complained.' The story appeared in a local newspaper, and Jose Craveirinha, who had supported other African athletes, learned about Maria. He went to meet her and saw her playing football outside the club. He immediately noticed she was fast. 'He talked to me about athletics. I didn't know what he meant. The only sport I knew was football. Then he bought me running shoes and took me to train. It was very hard work, and my legs really hurt.' But Jose visited her parents and convinced them she could be successful and this would help end their poverty. They agreed to let him take her to train. In 1991, she finally accepted an invitation to train in the United States. She had refused before because she knew she would miss her family. Her background was different from the girls she met in the US. She explains, 'They were good athletes, but while I worried about my parents having enough to eat, they worried about dresses and make-up. They knew very little about me and even less about my problems. But I knew I was lucky to be there. The trainers were excellent, and I learned a lot.' Today, Maria still runs, and for most of the year, she lives happily in South Africa with her mother.'

The Skywalk The Grand Canyon in the United States was formed by the Colorado River. People visit the Grand Canyon Park to walk, run, and especially to enjoy the view. The view is amazing, and the Skywalk makes it even better. The Skywalk is 1219 meters above the bottom of the Grand Canyon. It is a platform with glass walls and floor, allowing you to see the beautiful canyon rocks below. Up to 120 people can stand on it at the same time. It opened in 2007, and since then, thousands of people have visited it. You must wear special shoe covers to prevent scratching the glass. Walking on the Skywalk feels like you are a bird flying high in the sky.

Text: 'THE ROCKIES The Rocky Mountains stretch almost the entire length of North America. They begin in the northwest but are only a few hundred miles from the center in more southern regions. Although the Rockies are smaller than the Alps, they are just as amazing. There are many roads through the Rockies, but the best way to see them is by train. You start from Vancouver, one of Canada's most beautiful big cities. This city is located between the water and the mountains, allowing its residents to ski on slopes just 15 minutes by car from the city center. In the past, thirty passenger trains a day would leave Vancouver on the cross-continent railway. Now, there are only three a week, but the journey is still a great adventure. You sleep on the train, which is enjoyable, but you travel through some of the best scenery at night.'

Text: 'ZOOS People started keeping animals in zoos over 3,000 years ago, when the rulers of China opened a large zoo called the Gardens of Intelligence. In many early zoos, animals were trained to perform for visitors. This no longer happens, and now zoos aim to show animals behaving naturally. Today, most cities have a zoo or wildlife park. However, not everyone agrees with the idea of zoos. People who support zoos say they give us a chance to learn about nature and be close to wild animals, which would not be possible without zoos. On the other hand, some people are against zoos because they think it is wrong to keep animals in cages. They also argue that in poorly managed zoos, animals live in dirty conditions and eat unsuitable food.'

Text: 'JAZZ By Katie Atkins, aged 14 I play the trumpet in my school jazz band. Last month, we had a jazz competition with bands from local high schools, and our band won! Each band wore different costumes, from black school uniforms like ours to brightly-colored T-shirts. We didn't look like adult professional bands, but we were all used to performing in competitions, so the quality of playing was amazing, especially since everyone was so young. Players from each band even created new tunes right there on stage. It was exciting to watch, but even better when my band played on stage! We have a great jazz band at my school, but not everyone who wants to play in it gets accepted—only about half, in fact. But anyone who is eager to play goes to jazz practice before school, and we often spend time together after school, listening to jazz and learning its language. There are also trips to jazz summer camps across the country—I’ve been to a couple and learned a lot. Adults are often surprised that young people are getting interested in jazz. My music teacher thinks it's because pop music isn't challenging enough for people like me who are serious about music. But I find it exciting because it's both new and old at the same time—you can create your own music, but you also feel you're part of its history, as you're playing on stage in the same way as great jazz performers before you. My school is really lucky because we have great teachers and parents who have supported us all the way. Without them, we'd never get anywhere with our music!'

Text: 'Watering the Desert It can rain anytime between November and March in Marrakesh, Morocco. It doesn't happen often, and when it does, the city's water pipes can't handle the sudden floods, turning the streets into rivers. However, since many winters have been dry recently, the rain is welcomed by the local people. Marrakesh's parks and gardens exist not because of the rain, but thanks to a network of underground channels, dug in the 11th century, which bring water from the mountains all year round. Basically dry places that receive their water this way are known as oases. Further south from Marrakesh, travelers reach Skoura. Here, every piece of land is divided into small squares by the water channels and used to grow food. The Atlas Mountains, covered in snow during winter, provide a beautiful background.'

Gareth Ellis, who is 13 years old, is the youngest child of Alan, an engineer, and Kath, a nursery teacher. His older brothers work in banking and computers, but Gareth has always wanted to be a clown. Three years ago, Alan, Kath, and Gareth joined the circus. "People laugh when we tell them," says Kath. "But it's true. Gareth has wanted to be a clown since we took him to the circus when he was three." When Alan lost his job, he and Kath decided to try to find full-time jobs with a circus. They both got jobs with a famous circus, and Gareth started training to become a clown. He calls himself Bippo. They travel with the circus during the summer and go back home for the winter. Gareth's brothers are old enough to take care of the house while they are away. "I can't say it was easy," says Kath. "There was a lot to think about and organize. We only had a car and a very small caravan to sleep in, and we were leaving behind our lovely house. The only thing Gareth missed was his long, hot baths." "People ask about my education," says Gareth, "but from the beginning, wherever we go, someone has always come to teach me. I use the same books as everyone back at school, and I have a computer. I've never fallen behind my classmates." And the future? "It was a difficult decision," says Kath, "but there was no other way to teach Gareth about being a clown. I'm happy to say it's working, and we're enjoying it." And Gareth? "I'm going to be the main clown in a circus one day," he says, "maybe Bippo's circus."

Eight-eighteen News Eight-eighteen News is a news agency for young people aged 8-18. We gather news and write reports, stories, and articles. We send these to major national and local newspapers, magazines, TV, radio, and websites for publication. The news stories and articles by our members that are accepted can be read or listened to on the Eight-eighteen website. We have three centers around the country where young people can meet other members and join projects, and we plan to open more centers nationwide. Since our agency started in 1994, when we were called 'Young News', over 2,500 young people have been members. Sophie was one of them. She says: 'I first heard of Eight-eighteen when they interviewed me for an article about young people's opinions on hip hop music. I was amazed by the opportunities they had. Age wasn't important; they were trusted to do the stories on their own. I started going to the Eight-eighteen center in my city, got some training, and was a member until I was 18. Eight-eighteen helped me achieve more than I thought possible. With the skills I learned, I got a job at 19 and am now the youngest employee at a major news website, checking articles before they go online.' Get involved at every level When you join Eight-eighteen, you'll receive training and take part in monthly meetings to decide who will write each news story. Eight-eighteen encourages members to share skills. 'Peer trainers' are experienced members aged 12 and over. They train new members and teach them basic journalism skills. As they gain experience, some members present sessions to young people and adults outside Eight-eighteen, often in youth clubs and summer camps. These young trainers are supported by older staff who accompany them on these trips. Eight-eighteen News holds training sessions for new members three times a year. Our next training for new members will be in February. If you, or someone you know, is interested in joining, call Director Den Ley at 01622 657874 for more information. The Eight-eighteen program is suitable for children with reading and writing skills at all levels. Membership is free and there is no test to join.

**Antarctica Sightseeing Flights Website**

Welcome to our website. Here is what you need to know before booking a flight. During the short Antarctic summer, Antarctica Sightseeing Flights takes tourists in a large passenger plane (Boeing 747) from Sydney, Australia, over Antarctica and back. Flight dates for next year are not confirmed yet, but if you book now, your deposit can be moved to another date if we need to change the flight day.

**Questions**

These are answers to the most common questions about Antarctica Sightseeing Flights.

**How long is the flight?**

The flight usually lasts 12 hours. About four hours into the flight, we start seeing the first sea ice and icebergs. We spend four hours flying over Antarctica and the rest of the time returning home. On the way to and from Antarctica, experts who have lived at research stations there give talks about the environment and history, and answer questions. A camera near the pilot, connected to the video system on board, shows you the pilot's view from take-off to landing.

**Will I get a seat next to a window?**

All passengers receive two boarding passes. Halfway through the flight, passengers switch to the seat on their second boarding pass. Business and first class passengers will have a window seat for half of the flight and a seat next to a window for the other half. Economy passengers will have a window seat or a seat next to a window for half of the flight and an aisle seat for the other half. While over Antarctica, we encourage passengers to walk around the plane so everyone can enjoy the views. The pilot flies in long 'figure 8s' over interesting spots so both sides of the plane can see the sights well.

**What happens if the weather is bad?**

We have 17 different approved flight routes. Our captain checks the satellite cloud images on the morning of the flight and chooses the route with the clearest views.

**Will I see penguins and other wildlife?**

Most Antarctic wildlife lives at sea level, over 3,000 meters below the plane, so we can't see them clearly. We do not land on Antarctica, mainly for environmental reasons. To see Antarctic wildlife, you would need to join a boat tour.

**Can I take photographs?**

Yes, you can! All cameras are welcome. We even offer some fun photo opportunities on board where you can try on Antarctic cold weather clothes.

Text: 'Little Chefs For a group of children aged between ten and fifteen, Saturdays are spent learning how to cook seriously. Their weekly lessons in small classes are so popular that there is a waiting list of 30 children who want to join the course. Parents pay £280 for the course where their children can have fun and learn to make good food. Class member Bill, aged ten, says, 'I love my mum's cooking and now I can do it better than her. The teachers make us laugh, especially when we sit down with them to share the food we've made.' Flora is twelve, and she's having trouble preparing onions. 'I love cooking. I made a meal for ten friends which they really enjoyed. Then my mum suggested I take up a hobby, instead of doing nothing at weekends. I was happy staying at home, so I wasn't too interested at first. I'm really glad I decided to come, though.' Their teacher, Philippe, says, 'It's great fun. Children pay attention and remember things better than adults, although the kitchen isn't always as tidy when they're cooking! As adults, we're always learning more about food. If parents interest their children in cooking while they are young, they'll have enough skill to make food for themselves when they leave home.''

Text: 'Winter Driving Winter can be dangerous because it's hard to predict what will happen, and accidents can occur easily. Fog might appear suddenly over a hill. Ice can be hidden under melting snow, ready to make you lose control. The car coming towards you might suddenly slide across the road. Rule Number One for driving on icy roads is to drive smoothly. Sudden movements can make a car hard to control. So, whenever you turn the wheel, use the brakes, or speed up, do it gently and slowly. Imagine you have a full cup of hot coffee on the seat next to you. Drive in a way that you wouldn't spill it. Rule Number Two is to be aware of what might happen. The more ice there is, the further ahead you need to look. Test how long it takes to stop by gently braking. Remember, you might be driving faster than you think. In general, allow double your normal stopping distance when the road is wet, three times this distance on snow, and even more on ice. Try to stay in control of your car at all times to avoid trouble.'

Craigie Aitchison

The painter Craigie Aitchison was born in Scotland. He moved to London planning to study law, but instead, he went to art school. There, he found traditional drawing classes hard, but he continued painting. In his late twenties, the Italian government gave him money to study art, and he became interested in early Italian artists, which is visible in some of his work. He loved the greens and browns of the Italian fields and the clear light there, and he wanted to capture this light in his paintings. This led him to paint colors thinly, layering them from light to dark, but he says he's never sure what the results will be. He explains, 'It's a secret - because I don't know myself. I don't start by painting yellow, knowing I'm going to put anything on top.' Like many talented people, Aitchison makes it sound easy. 'Anyone can do the colors - you can buy them. I simply notice what you put the colors next to.' Unlike some artists, he never makes drawings before starting a painting, as he feels that if he did, he might get bored and not finish the painting. Instead, Aitchison changes his paintings many times before they are done. This is why his favorite models are people who don't ask to see their pictures while he's painting them. 'If I feel they're worried and want to look at the painting, I can't do it.' Since moving to London years ago, he has not felt part of the Scottish painting scene. He says he is not interested in following any tradition, but just paints the way he can. However, his work still influences young British painters.

Text: 'Rock Band Two years ago, our 14-year-old son, Ben, asked us for a set of drums for his birthday. At first, we were against the idea because of the noise. 'It's better than watching television or playing computer games in my free time,' Ben argued, 'and it'll keep me out of trouble.' In the end, we agreed. 'All right,' we said, 'but you must think about the rest of the family and the neighbours when you play.' That was just the start. Because drums are not easy to move, the other members of Ben's band started coming to our home with their guitars and other electrical equipment. So, for several hours a week, the house shakes with the noise of their instruments and their teenage singing. At least Ben's hobby has been good for our health: whenever the band starts practising, my husband and I go out for a long walk. And I must admit that, although their music may sound a little strange, they are a friendly and polite group of young men. I cannot judge their musical skill - after all, I didn't expect my parents' generation to like the same music as I did when I was a teenager - but they do play regularly in local clubs for young people. Our main worry is that they won't spend enough time on their school work because of their musical activities, though this hasn't happened yet. I am always telling Ben how important his studies are. But one thing is certain - Ben was right: it has kept him out of trouble and he is never bored.'

Atlantic College

Last week, I visited Atlantic College, a top private school in Wales. This school is special because it gives students important experiences outside the classroom, along with preparing them for exams. The students, aged 16 to 18, come from all over the world. They study in the morning and in the afternoon, they do useful activities like helping on a farm, assisting people with learning difficulties, or checking rivers for pollution.

One great thing about Atlantic College is its diverse student body. Students come from different social backgrounds and countries. Since the fees are PS20,000 for two years, many students need financial help. Grants are available, and a quarter of the students are British, with many receiving government support to attend.

"I really admire the college for promoting international understanding among young people," said Barbara Molenkamp, a student from the Netherlands. "You learn to live with and respect others, even those you don't like. During the summer holidays, my mother noticed I argued less with my sister."

In conclusion, Atlantic College provides an excellent education with methods that truly work.

Text: 'Being an older student At 32, I have just finished my first year at university. I attend lectures regularly, and I have learned to read books quickly and write long essays. I decided to go to university after being away from school for fourteen years. As a secretary, I was earning a decent amount of money, but I was bored because the job didn't challenge me. I felt stuck and became more and more unhappy. I envied the students at the local university because they seemed happy and full of hope. I wanted to be part of that.
